story: Covid cases rising in % of the UK - see full list with one region soaringA total of  of the  local authority areas in the UKrecorded a week-on-week rise in rates in the seven days to October , with reports of hospital bed occupancy up %Englands rate stood at . as of October , down week-on-week from .. Image: Mark Thomas REX ShutterstockByAbigail OLearyReporter:,  Nov  recorded a week-on-week rise in rates in the seven days to October , with reports of hospital bed occupancy up %" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Royal-London-Hospital-Whitechapel-London-UK--Feb-.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" recorded a week-on-week rise in rates in the seven days to October , with reports of hospital bed occupancy up %" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Royal-London-Hospital-Whitechapel-London-UK--Feb-.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" recorded a week-on-week rise in rates in the seven days to October , with reports of hospital bed occupancy up %" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Royal-London-Hospital-Whitechapel-London-UK--Feb-.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsCovid cases are rising in almost a fth of local areas in the UK, with sharp increases recorded in the East Midlands, latest figures show. A total of  of the  local authority areas in the UKrecorded a week-on-week rise in rates in the seven days to October , while saw a fall, according to PA news agency analysis of Government data. South-west England continues to have the highest rates of any part of the UK, but they are now falling in  of the  local authorities in the region. In Tewkesbury in Gloucestershire, the rate is down from ,. cases per , people to ., while neighbouring Stroud has seen its rate fall from ,. to ..  Rates are also dropping in nearly all areas of eastern England, London, north-west England and the West Midlands, while every area in Wales is currently recording a week-on-week fall. By contrast, of the  local areas with the biggest week-on-week increase in rates, five are in Leicestershire: Blaby , Leicester , Charnwood , Hinckley  Bosworthand Harborough . Nearby Rutland has also recorded an increase , as have other areas in the East Midlands including South Holland in Lincolnshireand Nottingham . This pattern is not the same for the whole of the region, however, with all areas in Derbyshire and Northamptonshire recording a fall. There is a similarly mixed picture in other regions, such as south-east England, where parts of Kent and West Sussex are currently seeing a rise in rates but all areas of Hampshire and Berkshire are falling.The data suggests a sht in the third wave of coronavirus, from a broad rise in new cases across most of the country to increases that are limited to pockets of areas.It is too soon to saythis sht has been caused by specic events or changes in behaviour, such as the recent school half-term holiday or the rollout of Covid- vaccine booster doses. The Orkney Islands in Scotland have seen the biggest week-on-week increase in rates in the latest figures, up from . cases per , to . - though because of the small population size, this is the equivalent of  new cases, up from . In  of the  local authorities in Scotland rates have increased, along with three of the  authorities in Northern Ireland.  Rates remains at a relatively high level across the UK, with only one areacurrently below  cases per , people. But with a majority of local authority areas seeing a fall in new cases in the latest figures, all four nations are now showing a clear downwards trend in rates for the first time in several weeks. Englandaposs rate stood at . as of October , down week-on-week from .. In Scotland the rate is ., down from . Wales is down from . to . and Northern Ireland has fallen from . to .. news uk-news final-moments-mum-who-drank-"Dawn Voice-Cooper discusses dying with peace and dignityByAmy-Clare MartinNews reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsSurrounded by her friends, Dawn Voice-Cooper sips ­champagne, has a cigarette then listens to her ­favourite song one last time.Just minutes later, she is dead. The mum-of-one had got her final wish for an assisted death at an organisation in ­Switzerland, where she released a fatal dose of ­barbiturates into her bloodstream.Her tearful last words to the emotional pals and medical staff at her bedside were simply: “Thank you, thank you everyone.” The sick -year-old had spent her last years fighting for the right to die, in the hope that one day the UK may enact assisted dying laws of its own.Facing a daily battle with a litany of incurable health problems, including severe arthritis, repeated brain bleeds and epilepsy, Dawn was determined to end her le on her own terms before the quality of her le, which she described as “at times unbearable”, deteriorated further. And she invited the Mirror to cover her journey to show people on all sides of the debate the realities of an assisted death. The former mental health worker described her existence as an “endless, often dficult, and usually painful, daily management of several, incurable issues”. But without suffering a terminal illness, her decision to die is hard for some to understand. Dawn said: “People often tell me, ‘Oh you look fine, you look young, you’ve got a bit of a limp.’ “But they don’t know what’s really going on inside me, the pain and the dficulties. “The daily management of my ailments and my injuries.”  Her story comes as campaigners mark World Right to Die Day across the globe. Assisting suicide is punishable by up to  years in prison in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. But prosecutors will decide whether it is in the public interest to take anyone to court. For Dawn, who lived alone in Sevenoaks, Kent, with decreasing mobility, the law also pushed her to end her le earlier while she was still fit to travel.  She added: “Part of me wants to go on campaigning, but the rational part of me knows that this could lead to not even being able to travel. I am going before I want to, but this will never get better, it will get worse.” Proposals for an assisted dying law brought by Baroness Meacher would only be available to those with less than six months to live. It last week passed its second reading in the Lords and progressed to the Committee stage for the first time in seven years. But it still has several stages to clear. And Dawn believed this model is too restrictive and has instead called for an evidence-based Parliamentary inquiry into assisted dying. It was her hope that the UK will build a model like Canada, where those with a grievous and irremediable condition can also apply for an assisted death.  Opponents of assisted dying fear any legalisation will push disabled and elderly people into ending their lives early out of fear of becoming a care burden. But Dawn hoped by sharing her journey she can show that rigorous safeguards can be in place to stop abuse. She added: “I would like to dispel all the myths around assisted dying, that people could be coerced. That it’s against God. I would just like people to know it is a dignied choice. It gives people dignity. It gives people peace that they can do it and they have this offer. It gives you autonomy. “And it enables people whose quality of le is low and can’t get better to take control of themselves and their lives.“Why must people suffer  Why is it acceptable  We wouldn’t let our pets suffer or animals suffer.” The children’s writer, who lived in Penzance, Cornwall, before ing to Kent, first began considering an assisted death in . She made her application to the Lecircle clinic in Basel two years ago. The application process required her to submit her medical history, explain her reasons for wanting an assisted death and to prove she was mentally competent. And once in Switzerland she was assessed by two separate doctors before being taken to the clinic, where up to two people end their lives each week. Unlike the better-known Dignitas, where patients drink a lethal cocktail of medication, Lecircle sets an IV drip which recipients operate themselves. Inside the clinic, in an industrial area which backs onto woodland outside the city, Dawn signed her own death ­certicate. She hugged her friends, fellow campaigners Alex Pandolfo and Miranda Tuckett, before a nurse ­positioned her bed in front of the window to look out at the trees. She said: “It’s beautul here surrounded by the trees. I think it must be the most beautul place to die.”  Lecircle’s president, Dr Erika Preisig, then asked Dawn four final questions on camera. Q: What is your name  A: Dawn Voice-Cooper. Q: What is your date of birth  A: th June . Q: Can you tell me why you came here to Lecircle  A: I want an assisted death because the quality of my le is not good and it will get worse. Q: We have set an intravenous needle. Dawn do you know what is going to happenyou open this profusion  A: Yes the drug will go into my body and I will go into a deep sleep and then I will die. Dr Preisig then said: “If this is your last wish you can open the profusion.” Listening to Nick Drake’s Day is Done, with her friends holding her hands, Dawn then released a valve on the IV. Following a police report, which takes place after every assisted death at Lecircle, her body will be cremated and her ashes scattered by Dr Preisig. Alex, who has early onset ­Alzheimer’s and will also die at Lecircle before he deteriorates, said: “It was one of the most beautul and loving deaths I have witnessed in contrast to the unacceptable and prolonged tortured deaths of my beloved mum and dad and the death my Alzheimer’s may bring to me. “Dawn’s story and experience of both pain and then peace through the support of Lecircle will be used as I continue to ask for an evidenced based parliamentary inquiry into humane voluntary assisted dying in the UK. “I live in peace knowing that when it’s my time to die comes I can rest in the arms of Dr Erika Preisig at the start of my journey into the unknown.” Figures show up to one Brit a week travels to Switzerland to end their le – a journey which costs around £, and can leave family members at risk of ­prosecution for helping a loved one. Assisted dying is legal in a number of places across the world, including the Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, eleven US jurisdictions, Canada and parts of Australia. New Zealand and Spain have passed legislation which is set to come into force this year. Campaigners say it’s high time that Britain ends its blanket ban on assisted dying, but there is strong opposition, amid fears a new law could lead vulnerable people to feel pressure to end their lives. Christian charity CARE fears that “giving assent to assisted suicide would undermine the caring ethic which underpins our medical profession”. The group also believes there is a “huge risk” that changing the law would see patients who already face challenges in accessing good palliative care “reluctantly opting for an assisted death when they would have preferred to live”. Following a debate in the Lords last week, Nola Leach, CEO of CARE, said: “We believe that giving assent to assisted suicide would undermine the caring ethic which underpins our medical profession and society at large. “Introducing such a regime would integrate into our culture the belief that certain lives are no longer worth living, and would legitimise the involvement of doctors, society’s preservers of le, in the procurement of death. “This debate is not just about personal freedom for the dying, who of course deserve our sympathy and concern it is about giving medical practitioners the legal power to facilitate the ending of another person’s le and the societal implications of such a move. “Whilst for some the bill may be perceived as granting choice, marginalised groups are concerned that it will lead to others seeing the option as a duty to end their lives.” There is also a debate around who should qualy under any law change. The House of Lords bill brought by chair of Dignity in Dying Baroness Meacher would be limited to mentally competent, terminally ill adults with six months to live. However Dawn, who was a long term member of campaign group My Death, My Decision, believed this legislation is too restrictive. MDMD chair Trevor Moore said: “Dawn’s story also highlights the critical need for politicians not to lock those with incurable suffering outside of efforts to change the law on assisted dying. “As a longstanding member, campaigner, and friend of My Death, My Decision we are glad that Dawn has finally been able to find peace. “But we urge lawmakers to ensure that she is the last case of someone forced to leave their home in the UK in order to do so. Now is the moment to change the law on assisted dying.” Comment MORE ON Mental healthArthritisPoliticsAssisted suicide" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how green area data reveals
story: How green is my area   most eco-friendly places in England - and the worstNew data has revealed which areas are the most eco-friendly in England and which are lagging behind as London pushes ahead as the greenest area whilst the north of England lags behindMarsh Marigolds on the banks of the River Eden in Cumbria is in one of the least eco-friendly local authorities in England Image: Getty ImagesByClara MurrayKieren Williams:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsData has revealed which areas in England are the most eco-friendly, as this week’s COP climate conference kicks off in Glasgow. Using seven environmental indicators, local authorities have been ranked across the country on their commitment to going green. Figures include data on how often people walk or cycle, carbon emissions per person, and how much the local council spends on the environment. The analysis, published by In Your Area, shows London’s Tower Hamlet is the greenest of England’s  local authorities. The area has the lowest carbon emissions in the country, with each person living there responsible for . tonnes of CO - half the national average of ..  It also ranked number one for energy-efficient homes, with . per cent of houses in Tower Hamlets rated as efficient, almost twice the national average of . per cent. England’s renewable energy capital, Selby in North Yorkshire, was the second greenest. Another London local authority, Hackney, came third, thanks to spending the highest amount on the environment. Hacknet spends £. per person on the environment, more than triple the England average of £.. Of the ten greenest local authorities, six of them are in London.  The Isles of Scilly scored highest for the percentage of adults who walk or cycle at least five times a week, and on how easy it was for residents to access green space. Rochford in Essex, was best for recycling, reusing and composting household waste. Meanwhile, Bolsover in Derbyshire was the least eco-friendly place in England according to the ratings. As well as receiving poor scores on most ratings, it had the second-highest carbon emissions per person. Only Eden in Cumbria, which was the second worst rated area, had higher carbon emissions per person.  All of the least-green areas were located in the North of England, with Sevenoaks in Kent being the worst rated local authority in the South, ranking  of . The data used was taken from government sources, including the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. The City of London was excluded from the rankings due to its low population, while carbon emissions from industry, travel, business and agriculture were not counted towards an area’s total to reduce the impact of major roads and factories on the rankings. The greenest areas in EnglandTower Hamlets, London Selby, North Yorkshire Hackney, London Southwark, London Camden, London Milton Keynes Islington, London Greenwich, London Vale of White Horse, Oxfordshire PeterboroughThe least green areas in EnglandRossendale, Lancashire Harrogate, North Yorkshire Hyndburn, Lancashire South Lakeland , Cumbria Burnley, Lancashire Mansfield, Nottinghamshire Bassetlaw, Nottinghamshire Pendle, Lancashire Eden, Cumbria Bolsover, DerbyshireComment MORE ON Eco-friendlyEnvironment" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news kate-middleton-dazzles-royal-blue-"COP: Royal family arrive at Kelvingrove Gallery and MuseumByAbigail OLearyReporter:,  Nov | commentsKate Middleton dazzled in a royal blue dress as she and William stepped in for the Queen at COP. The Duchess of Cambridge wore a Eponine coat dress as she and Wills attended the Earthshot reception in Glasgow tonight. Pairing the £, gown with navy heels, she walked alongside the Duke of Cambridge for their arrival at the Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum. Kate and William joined Prince Charles, Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall and Boris Johnson as well as key members of the Sustainable Markets Initiative and the Winners and Finalists of the first Earthshot Prize Awards.In a rare public expression of emotion, the Queen, speaking in a pre-recorded video message, said it was a source of great pride the important role he played in encouraging people to look after the natural world, and she could not be more proud of the Prince of Wales and Duke of Cambridge who have continued his work. Acknowledging her own mortality, the Queen, whose health has caused concern after she decided not to attend the Glasgow conference when advised by doctors to rest, said not all would benefit from the leadersapos actions as none of us will live forever. Earlier today, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were described as a real inspiration to Scouts whom they joined in a workshop about how to lead a greener le.William and Kate made vegetarian burgers, repaired bicycles, and helped to re-wild a grassy bank with the boys at Alexandra Park in Dennistoun, Glasgow, while world leaders met at Cop nearby. The workshop was part of the international Promise To The Planet campaign, which aims to teach  million Scouts how to lead more environmentally friendly lives. Both sporting red poppies on their lapels, the royal couple had travelled to Scotland by train and were driven to the park in an electric Jaguar I-Pace, where they met  members of the th Glasgow Scout Group.  Kate, , who is joint president of the Scouts, jokingly threatened to slap her husbandaposs face with her dirty gloves as they made wildflower seed-bombs with the youngsters. While making vegetarian burgers with the boys, William askedthey had ever tried one before and whether they liked them more than meat burgers. Meanwhile, Kate, wearing a Scout neckerchief with a khaki gilet and black trousers, helped to prepare ingredients and asked the boys: Do you get enough veg at school   The couple helped the youngsters tighten bike brakes and fix loose handlebars before joining the children mixing flour, soil and wildflowers into seed-bombs, which they threw at a grassy bank to encourage natural growth. Taking advice from one Scout about re-wilding, William, who wore a navy jumper and trousers, told him: Youaposve done this a few times before, havenapost you  Youaposre doing well. Youaposre leading us very well. Eddie OaposRourke, who supports Scout groups in Glasgow and Lanarkshire as district commissioner, described the royal couple as a real inspiration to the boys. He said: They were a real inspiration to all the Scouts who are working hard to make changes to protect the planet. The royal couple also met -year-old Cop ambassador Lewis Howe, who is among  Scouts who have been selected by the Government to showcase how ordinary people are taking action to combat climate change. Lewis, from the st Laurencekirk Scouts in Aberdeenshire, has been challenging Scottish schools to cut food waste by using surplus stock to provide meals for vulnerable people. He said: I have been inspired by my Scouts leaders and the amazing actions of my fellow Scouts. Kate is the first woman to hold the role of president of the Scouts, which she shares with Prince Edward, the Duke of Kent. news uk-news kate-middleton-dons-woggle-prince-"Prince William and Kate meet with Scouts as part of COP eventByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have visited Scouts in Glasgow to celebrate its Promise To The Planet campaign. The couple met and chatted to some of the Scouts and learned about the new campaign at the Alexandra Park Sports Hub in the Dennistoun area of Glasgow - the city where the COP climate change summit is taking place. The pair were dressed casually for the visit, with Kate wearing slim black trousers, a black rollneck jumper and a gilet. She also wore a Scouts woggle and neckerchief due to her role as joint president of the Scouts Association. William was dressed in navy and they both sported poppies.During their visit they learned how Scouts around the world have been raising awareness of climate change and doing their bit to address it.They also cooked veggie burgers, learned about sustainable transport and joined the youngsters in scattering wildflower seed bombs. Scout Leader Eddie OaposRourke said: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge met Scouts taking part in our Promise To The Planet Planet campaign. They were a real inspiration to all the Scouts that are working hard to make changes to protect the planet.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. It’s great to see The Duke and Duchess to work with our young people and recognise that everyone is capable of helping and everyone’s effort is important in the fight against climate change.” The Scoutsapos Promise to the Planet initiative, will see them spend million hours per month on planet saving activities. William and Kateaposs visit comes ahead of them attending a reception this evening, where they will meet with the winners and finalists of the inaugural Earthshot Prize. The initiative, set up by William, aims to find solutions to the planetaposs environmental problems and overcome the pessimism felt by many on its future.Earlier today, William marked the start of the COP summit by sending a rare personal tweet from the official Duke and Duchess of Cambridge Twitter account. He wrote: #COP is a landmark moment for the future of our planet — I’m proud that our @EarthshotPrize Finalists will be joining me in Glasgow to show the world that there is reason to be optimistic. I’m hopeful about what can be achieved. William signed off the tweet W, showing it was a personal message. Later, William and Kate will also join Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall at a reception for world leaders. The Queen had been due to attend too but pulled out following her stay in hospital almost two weeks ago. Instead, she has recorded a video message for the event.Meanwhile, earlier today, Prince Charles attended the COP opening ceremony, where he also gave a speech addressing delegates.He told the conference in Glasgow: The scale and scope of the threat we face call for a global, systems-level solution based on radically transforming our current fossil fuel-based economy to one that is genuinely renewable and sustainable. So ladies and gentlemen my plea today is for countries to come together to create the environment that enables every sector of industry to take the action required. We know this will take trillions, not billions, of dollars. We also know that countries, many of whom are burdened by growing levels of debt, simply cannot afford to aposgo greenapos. Concluding his speech, he added: I can only urge you, as the worldaposs decision-makers, to find practical ways of overcoming dferences so we can all get down to work, together, to rescue this precious planet and save the threatened future of our young people. title: motorists baffled after signs show
story: Motorists baffled as markings show two dferent speed limits on same roadWorcestershire County Council said it would launch an investigation as markings on Ombersley Road in Bevere, Worcester, tell drivers not to exceed mph but on the opposite carriageway they are ordered to keep to mphResidents have been left confused after road marking give two dferent speed limits Image: Tristan Potter   SWNSByBradley StokesShiler Mahmoudi:,  Nov | commentsMotorists have been left baffled after road markings show two dferent speed limits on a residential street. On the left hand side of Ombersley Road in Bevere, Worcester, drivers are told not to exceed mph, but on the opposite carriageway they are ordered to keep to mph.The mix-up has left drivers confused and seeking clarity.Grace Taylor, , said: Itaposs completely stupid. On one side of the road you can go at mph while leaving you have to stick to mph. The council need to make up their minds. The mph and mph road markings are even next to each other.Surely someone would have noticed when they were painted An already very busy road has been made more confusing.My Sat Nav almost had a nervous breakdown when I drove to see my mum in one direction but had to slow right down on the way out. The stretch of road had been mph between Green Lane and Claines roundabout until it was reduced to mph after a new housing estate was built.Despite this change, only one side of the road had its mph markings painted over, creating a confusing situation for motorists.The roadworks were carried out by contractors last Thursday on behalf of Bellway Homes which has a development along Ombersley Road.Councillor Mel Allcott said: It has caused confusion especially with the new housing estates which is why they changed limit.I would advise people to stick to the mph speed limit until Perrins Way because that is what all the signs used to say.We had a nasty accident before near the farm shop and it is a road where people should drive carefully.I think the contractor based it on previous speed limit but the mph section was extended a couple of years ago.It is a bit of an unusual one because the houses donapost back onto the road so Highways didnapost have to lower the limit but did it out of good will.I have spoken to a Highways officer and they are aware as well.Worcestershire County Council said it would launch an investigation into the oversight.A council spokesman said: The work was undertaken by Bellway Homes, who are the developer responsible for the new housing development on that road.We are investigating any errors and will request that these are corrected as soon as possible.Comment MORE ON Sat-navHousingWorcester Council" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum living breadline just four
story: Mum living on breadline has just four weeks to find new home to avoid living on streetsA desperate mum with six kids has been given just four weeks to find a new place to live after her landlord decided to sell their home, meaning she could potentially be made homeless just weeks before ChristmasI want to give my kids everything... but I can’t afford to do that,” Vicky Gillott says, pictured with Destiny , Anton  and Eric,  Image: www.manchestereveningnewsByPaige OldfieldKate Buck:,  Nov | commentsA mum-of-six who struggles to make ends meet has been dealt another blow after her landlord decided to sell their home - meaning she has just four weeks to find somewhere  to live.Vicky Gillott, , rents a house in Eccles, Manchester with a private landlord.But the property has just been sold, meaning she has just four weeks to find somewhere to live.I want to give my kids everything... but I can’t afford to do that. We struggle with food, shopping, heating and electric, Vicky told the the Manchester Evening News.“With winter coming, we are going to have to use it more. “It’s one of those things. You just have to try and get by.” “I’ve had to go to the doctors for my mental health,” she added. “I could be homeless. It’s the younger ones I’m worried about – near Christmas as well.”  As well as the possibility of facing le on the streets, Vicky also worries about basic necessities such as food. She relies on free school meals and her mother who helps her when running low. She also uses Wood Street Mission, a charity for low income families, to access toys for the children. “We’ve had to lessen things like taking the kids out,” she says. “It’s good when we get holiday vouchers for the kids. “We want to take them on trips to Blackpool but you can’t afford it. “I want to give my kids everything. It makes me feel like sh**”.On Wednesday, Rishi Sunak unveiled his second Budget of , which cuts the UC taper by eight per cent, allowing claimants to keep more of their benefit.But .million households have seen their income fall by £, a year after the £ uplt was recently scrapped. The vital cash could put new shoes on a childaposs feet, or pay for a week of food. The decrease means some are having to choose between basic necessities. There are people living in Eccles, Manchester, who barely manage to keep their heads above the water – with some living day-to-day on the very edge of disaster. Reporter Paige Oldfield spoke to some of those barely getting by.  Nearby, a woman sits in the grounds of Eccles Parish churchyard. When speaking of her plight, the mother-of-four says she is “struggling” to keep her head above the water in recent times. She tells us can’t afford to buy birthday presents for her children - something that upsets her deeply. “Everything goes up but the benefits don’t go up,” she says. “We’re still struggling. I can’t buy birthday presents for my kids and grandchildren. “It does get to me. It’s a big worry. I have four children and I just want the best for them.” Sat on a bench within Eccles Shopping Centre, Peter O’Connor reads a leaflet.  Beside him is a walking stick and a shopping trolley with an umbrella, insulated blanket and other belongings. The -year-old, who has struggled with addiction from a young age, says he has had his benefits slashed by £ a month. Due to his health conditions, he once received Employment and Support Allowanceand Personal Independence Payment .But following an assessment, he has since been placed onto Universal Credit.“I’ve lost everything,” he said. “I’ve got to go on Universal Credit and that’s what has done it to me. “My le was pretty sad before, but now it’s going to make it worse. “I just get from one day to the next.Peter, who says he has been an alcoholic since the age of , suffers from crippling arthritis, a liver condition and depression.“I’ve got six conditions, and each one will lead to death,” he continues. “All of my friends are dying. Two have died in the last two weeks. “You don’t get better. You just get worse.” Elsewhere in the town, Emily Johnston sits on a bench drinking a can of lager. The -year-old says she “looks for a bargain wherever she can” in a bid to save as much as possible. She also spends as much time out of her home as she can to save on using gas. Next to her is her friend Leo Owen, aged . He says: “You put money in for gas and electric and it goes down quicker than it used to. “I can’t switch it off because of my food, so it’s on constantly.” Hugh Mortimer, who is busking on a nearby street, finishes for the day and starts packing away his guitar. He counts the collection of coins he has made and puts them into a small plastic bag. He tells us busking is currently his only form of income. The -year-old says: “In the s, the future was exciting. “Now, the future is frightening.“It’s just gone extortionate. “You worry about the future. “Busking is my only way of making money. “I’m worried about bills – council tax, electricity and petrol. “You dread getting a plumbing bill oryour car breaks down. “I just try and be sensible – Iaposm a busker, you have to try and survive.” Comment MORE ON EnergyCouncil taxMental healthShopping centresArthritisHomelessnessUniversal Credit" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: postman organises surprise boy whose
story: Postman organises surprise for boy whose bird died after finding letter he sentKind-hearted neighbours rallied around after postman Billy Freshwater learnt about Ale Whitehouses distress after his pet parrot died and helped him get a new birdAlfie with Stanley - the parrot Image: SWNSByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Nov | commentsKind-hearted neighbours rallied around a distraught schoolboy whose pet parrot died and helped him get a new bird. Postman Billy Freshwater heard about Alfie Whitehouseaposs heartbreak over Milly the parakeetaposs demise after the devastated -year-old wrote a letter to aposHeavenapos. The postie then wrote a plea on social media in a bid to raise funds in order to help Alfie. Parents Zoe Springate and Clinton Whitehouse said their son, who was diagnosed with ADHD three years ago, was heartbroken when his albino monk parakeet - also known as a Quaker parrot - passed away. After losing his feathered friend, Alfie who lives in Sheerness, Kent, wrote a letter addressed to aposHeavenapos, which he posted in his nearest post-box. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter herePostman Billy found the note on his collection round and shared it with his colleagues, Samantha Marshall and Graham Benham, after reading the address.They decided to share the letter on Facebook in a bid to find Alfie and get the islanders to come together and support him.After contacting his mum, Mr Benham set up a fundraising page in the hope of raising enough money to replace the youngsteraposs pet bird. Soon after Stephen Platt, of funeral directors, Palliser Platt and Sons in Sheerness, askedAlfie would like to have his late motheraposs parrot, called Stanley.  He even bought a new cage for Stanley from the Cuddles and Bubbles pet shop in the town, which gave him a discount after hearing about the cause. Mum Mrs Springate said the family are just so overwhelmed with everything after the generosity of their neighbours. She added: “Alfie understands the bird has been given to him but he doesnapost quite understand why – he is just really grateful that he has got him. He spends all his time with Stanley now. He sits with him for about an hour each night reading him a bedtime story.The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. We will celebrate the people, places and movements that are bringing good into the world and, more than that, we will dig beneath the surface of important issues with the aim of finding hope.We will be firm in our convictions - but always fair-minded. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook Heaposs got a friend back. Itaposs not the friend he had but heaposs now got another friend. “I want to say a massive thank you, although that doesn’t seem like enough to show our appreciation.” Mr Platt and Alfie met up in person earlier this month for the first time. Dad Mr Whitehouse, , added: We just want to thank every single person who has helped make this happen. “Itaposs more heart-warming than anything . There are some really kind people on this Island. news uk-news princess-eugenie-shares-rare-snap-"Princess Eugenie shares sweet video of baby August in England baby growByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsPrincess Eugenie has shared a rare snap of her nine-month-old son August in a cute costume for Halloween. She delighted royal fans by posting the adorable photo of her baby on Instagram showing him dressed as a little monster while playing with a soft Minion toy.Eugenie captioned the sweet snap: Wonder what they are talking about... alongside a pumpkin and ghost emoji. She also shared several Instagram stories, one showing August in his costume and another showing her attempt at carving a pumpkin.Among those commenting on her posts was her brother-in-law Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi, the husband of her sister Princess Beatrice, who put a pumpkin and a crying with laughter emoji.  One royal fan said: Aww so sweet! Happy Halloween. While another wrote: Awwww so cute. Always fun trying to figure out their conversations too. Eugenie and husband Jack Brooksbank welcomed their son, whose full name is August Philip Hawke Brooksbank, earlier this year in February.His middle name Philip is in honour of Prince Philip, who died at  in April.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.In a documentary about her late grandfather, which was broadcast earlier this year, Eugenie revealed August got to meet Philip - his great-grandfather - shortly before his death.Holding back the tears, Eugenie explained: We named August, August Philip because grandpa has been such a huge, inspiring character in my le. I brought little August to come and meet him and told him that we had named him after him and it was such a lovely moment. We were very lucky to do that. Meanwhile, in September, Eugenie was among one of the first people to congratulate her sister Beatrice for giving birth to her first child. Beatrice and husband Edoardo welcomed a daughter named Sienna Elizabeth - with her middle name a nod to her great-grandmother the QueenEugenie wrote on Instagram at the time: To my new niece, I love you already and think youaposre just awesome from the photos.. weaposre going to have so much fun together. Love your Auntie Euge. title: queen looking hire maid official
story: Queen is looking to hire a maid for her official Scottish residence - paying minimum wageThe housekeeping assistants job at the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh, will pay £. an hour - the same as the new Living Wage, which will come into force in AprilThe housekeeping assistants job at the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh, will pay £. an hour Image: WireImageByEllie ForbesAlice Peacock:,  Nov | comments The Queen is looking to hire a maid for her official Scottish residence, but the successful applicant shouldn’t expect to be royally remunerated as the gig pays minimum wage.The housekeeping assistantaposs job at the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh, will pay £. an hour - the same as the new Living Wage, which will come into force in April. The advertisement on the monarchyaposs website has two types of contracts available - one offers  hours a week, the other  hours a week. The advert says: This is a career pathway in hospitality that will develop your housekeeping skills and expertise. Joining our professional team, youaposll upkeep, clean and care for a wide range of interiors and items, ensuring that they are presented to their very best. With attention to detail you take pride in your work and aim for the highest standards.  In an environment where training is commonplace, you will be able to grow your skills.” The responsibilities attached to the role also involved welcoming and taking care of guests at s. Her Majesty is in residence at the Palace of Holyroodhouse at least once a year. It also plays host to the annual Garden Party where invited guests have an opportunity to meet and greet the monarch. The Firm has previously come under fire for being “out of touch” in offering their workers salaries that fall below the average UK wage while costing taxpayers tens of millions a year. Earlier this year it was announced that the Queen was looking for a new security to work at Buckingham Palace - offering a relatively meagre salary of £,. The .-hour-a-week job, spread over five days and on a one-year fixed term - also requires a degree and experience in security. title: revealed beloved mcdonalds items worst
story: Exclusive: REVEALED: The beloved McDonalds items that are the worst for the environmentAnalysis by the Mirror shows which items from the McDonalds menu require the most amount of carbon dioxide to be dumped into the atmosphere during their productionThe Double Big Mac is the biggest offender, analysis suggestsByMilo BoydReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe most polluting burger on the McDonaldaposs menu is as bad for the environment as driving  miles, analysis suggests. The Big Mac - inarguably the most iconic McDonaldaposs burger - requires .kg of CO to be pumped into the atmosphere during its production, a carbon footprint calculator shows. That is the equivalent of driving . miles in an average UK petrol car. Its younger sibling, the Double Big Mac, is responsible for the dumping the same amount of CO as a . mile journey, the analysis suggests.Millions of tonnes of CO are released into the atmosphere by humans every day in a process which traps heat and has led global temperatures to increase at an unprecedented rate.If the world population does not control its carbon emissions, a disaster scenario of environmental collapse, unbearable heatwaves and climate driven conflicts could be just decades away. The analysis attempts to show how much of an impact on the environment  of the most iconic McDonaldaposs menu items have.These figures are worked out by putting ingredients and their weights through a carbon calculator called Plate up for the Planet.It is run by the Vegan Society in conjunction with Planet Friendly Food, two organisations that argue moving away from meat based diets will have a positive impact on the environment. An important part of the calculation is where the product was sourced, due to the emissions produced transporting food from the field to plate. The Big Mac, for example, is a global burger, with a gherkin from Turkey, lettuce from Holland or France, beef from Ireland or UK, and mayonnaise made in Lancashire, among other ingredients.  By far the biggest CO emitters in the Big Mac are the beef patties, which weigh g and emit .kg CO. In contrast, the McPlant - McDonaldaposs latest UK burger made from pea protein - requires just .kg of CO to be released in the production of its patty. These figures are not official but calculations based on publicly available information provided by McDonaldaposs and other sources. Its worth noting that dferent carbon calculators produce dferent figures, due to the dficulty in working out the emissions released by the many steps of the food production process.For example, campaign group Less Meat Less Heat has calculated that one Big Mac has the same carbon footprint as using an electric hand dryer  times, watching  hours of TV, and drinking  cappuccinos. What is clear is that the items with the most meat produce the most CO, due to inefficient nature of rearing animals compared to growing plants.Beef generate  kilograms of greenhouse gas emissions per kilogram of meat produced - dozens of times more than grown produce like nuts, apples and potatoes. McDonaldaposs was asked to provide its own carbon emission calculations, but it declined. McDonaldaposs items with the biggest carbon footprintsDouble Big Mac : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car Quarter Pounder : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car Bacon double cheeseburger : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car Big Mac : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car Twenty McNuggets : .kg COe COe -. miles in an average UK petrol car Chicken Legend with mayo : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car Three Chicken Selects : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car Fillet OaposFish : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car McPlant : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car McFlurry : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car Large fries : .kg COe - . miles in an average UK petrol car A McDonaldaposs spokesperson said: “We take our responsibility around the climate incredibly seriously, and recently launched our Plan for Change which sets out a series of ambitious goals that will help us accelerate our efforts to reduce our impact on the planet. This includes our aim to achieve net zero emissions across our entire business and value chain in the UK  Ireland, by . We are committed to leading the change on beef sustainability Our Better Grazing research project is helping us understand the benefits of using regenerative principals when it comes to beef farming, and we were founding members of both the UK Cattle Sustainability Platform and the European Roundtable for Beef Sustainability. We continue to share our learnings with our farmers and suppliers to ensure we’re working as sustainably as possible.” Comment MORE ON McDonalds CorporationFoodClimate change" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: self isolating teacher spotted airport
story: Self-isolating teacher spotted in airport queue by pupil who posted to SnapchatAlicia Reid, , was allegedly snapped at Glasgow airport two days before the official October break despite reportedly telling colleagues she had been “pinged” as a close contact of someone infected with CovidHeadteacher of Stranraer Academy, Alicia Reid Image: Daily RecordByJackie Grant:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA headteacher who was believed to be self-isolating was spotted by a pupil in an airport queue about to go to Turkey for a holiday, it is alleged. Alicia Reid, , was allegedly snapped at Glasgow airport two days before the official October half term despite reportedly telling colleagues she had been “pinged” as a close contact of someone infected with Covid. Widely viewed video footage appeared on social media site Snapchat captioned: “Miss Reid is that you  It looks so much like her.”Ms Reid is now set to be replaced by an acting rector at Stranraer Academy in Dumfries and Galloway while education chiefs carry out a probe, according to the Daily Record. The local council’s director of skills, education and learning, Dr Gillian Brydson, said: “Miss Reid will not be in school for a period of time. An acting ­headteacher is due to be appointed as soon as possible.”  It is understood Reid had been due to work on the last two days of term before the two-week school break began on October . But it is claimed she called colleagues to say she would not be at school because she had been notied she had come into close contact with someone who had tested positive for Covid- and would have to self-isolate at home. However, she was allegedly filmed at Glasgow Airport later that day, on October , masked and queuing at a check-in desk for a holiday flight. The dad of the pupil who made the recording said: “There were two flights to Turkey around the same time on the Thursday night. We were on one and she was on the other. “My daughter was really shocked to see her headteacher there. I heard her say, “It’s Miss Reid. What is she doing here  She started filming and posted the images to let her friends see. We had no idea of the effect it would have because we didn’t know the teacher was supposed to be off self-isolating.” A spokesman for Dumfries and Galloway Council – who advise parents not to take unauthorised holidays during term time, said: “We do not comment on matters related to inidual staff. “Good progress in learning continues to be the priority for the school community of Stranraer Academy and we will provide leadership and support to the school management team.” The school did not comment when contacted by The Mirror and directed us to the council. The Mirror has contacted Dumfries and Galloway Council for further comment. title: tell tale signs you could
story: Tell-tale signs you could be suffering from vitamin D deficiency - and how to fix itLower levels of daylight between October and early March mean we do not make enough vitamin D from the sun, and so need to get it through our diet, the NHS saysVitamin D is naturally gained from sunlight but staying indoors can lead to a deficiency and the winter months Image: Getty ImagesByHarriet WhiteheadGraeme Murray:,  Nov | commentsA tell-tale sign on your head could be an early sign of vitamin D deficiency, say health experts. The vitamin is naturally gained from sunlight, but staying indoors can lead to a deficiency and the winter months are also an issue. The majority of the population will get enough vitamin D through exposure to sunlight and a healthy, balanced diet.But between October and early March mean we do not make enough vitamin D from sunlight, so need to get it from our diet, the NHS says.CoventryLive reports that one sign of lack of vitamin D is head sweats, which are an “early sign” of the deficiency. It is estimated that around % of adults may have low vitamin D status, and there are several main risk factors for vitamin D deficiency.  As far as diet is concerned vitamin D is available in foods such as oily fish, cod liver oil, red meat, fortied cereals, fortied spreads and egg yolks. In some countries milk is not fortied with vitamin D but this is not the case in the UK. As such, dairy products contain only small amounts of vitamin D. A lack of sunlight exposure, darker skin, being housebound, malabsorption, and being pregnant or breastfeeding are risk factors according to the NHS. Symptoms can include muscle aches and weakness, waddling gait, chronic widespread pain or bone pain in lower back, pelvis and foot.Health food retailer Holland  Barrett says % of the vitamin D in our bodies needs to come from getting out in the sunlight and only  percent is from our diet, Thereports. It says: “Evenyou eat fortied foods, you could be at risk of vitamin D deficiency. Symptoms of low vitamin D y from person to person.” The website also lists a number of other signs to be mindful of. Falling short of the required amount could weaken immune defences, butlow levels are left untreated, discomfort may also arise. Over-supplementation of vitamin D, however, can also be harmful and should be avoided.  The NHS says taking too many vitamin D supplements over a prolonged period can cause too much calcium to build up in the body which can weaken the bones and damage the kidneys and the heart. However people cannot overdose on vitamin D through exposure to sunlight.Vitamin D has been linked positively to coronavirus -gtcoronavirus, but the NHS says reports about it reducing the risk of coronavirus are not backed by enough evidence to know whether this is the case.“There is currently not enough evidence to support taking vitamin D solely to prevent or treat Covid-,” the Express says. In April , the NHS issued a statement, based on recommendations from Public Health England , that we should all consider taking  mcg a day of vitamin D as a supplement, to keep our bones and muscles healthy.  This advice was issued largely because of the restrictions imposed by quarantine and lockdown. Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding should ask their midwe or health visitor for information around vitamin D intake. If you or someone you care for is in a higher risk group they may need to take vitamin D supplements. Vitamin D supplements are widely in pharmacies, other high street stores and supermarkets and can be taken in tablet, liquid or spray form. title: three changes your normal toilet
story: Three changes in your normal toilet habits that could be a warning sign of bowel cancerThe number of people dying of bowel cancer has fallen in recent years as early diagnosis has become more likely and access to effective treatment has improvedLooser poo or constipation can be a warning sign of bowel cancer Image: Getty ImagesByAlice Peacock:,  Nov | commentsBowel Cancer UK has outlined three changes in your normal toilet habits that could be a sign of the cancer, which is the fourth most common iety in the UK. The charity has said it is treatable and curable, “especiallydiagnosed early”. The number of people dying of bowel cancer has been falling since the s as early diagnosis has become more likely and access to effective treatment has improved. Cancer Research UK has flagged a number of potential signs of the cancer, many of which may show up when you go to the toilet. Blood in your poo, or a change in your normal bowel habit, can be a symptom in both men and women.  A change in bowel movements could mean looser poo, pooing more often or constipation. Another sign could be a lump in your back passage or tummy, or feeling you need to strain your pack passage asyou need to poo - even after youaposve opened your bowels. According to Bowel Cancer UK, you may also feel as though youaposre not able to fully empty your bowels While blood in poo can be a warning sign of bowel cancer, it is often due to other causes, the Express reports. Cancer Research says: “See your GPyou are worried about any symptoms that you think could be caused by cancer in the bowel.” Your doctor wonapost think you are wasting their time,” the charity continued. Other conditions that could bring about these symptoms include piles or inflammatory bowel disease. According to figures from Bowel Cancer UK, more than , people are diagnosed with bowel cancer every year in the UK. It says that one in  men and one in  women will be diagnosed with bowel cancer over the course of their letime.While the exact cause of the cancer is not known, there are several things that can increase your chances of getting it.  According to the NHS, smoking is one habit that can increase your risk. It is also more common in overweight or obese people, the health body added, as with in those who have had another condition - such as extensive ulcerative colitis or Crohnaposs disease in the colon  for more than  years. Everyone aged  to  who is registered with a GP and lives in England should automatically be sent a bowel cancer screening home test kit every two years.Treatments for bowel cancer will y depending on what form of the cancer a person has, how advanced it is and where it is. The bowel is a very long organ that goes from the end of the small bowel to the anus. Most bowel cancer is diagnosed in the rectum, which is just above the anus. At its most simple, you could have surgery to take away the affected bowel and then you’d go back to normal. As bowel cancer progresses it becomes more dficult to deal with, and is treated by chemotherapy or radiotherapy.Sometimes this is before surgery, sometimes after. This would depend on whether the cancer has spread at all. title: underground nuclear bunker sale 550000
story: Underground nuclear bunker on sale for £, hides three luxury apartmentsA Grade II listed bunker built in  during the Cold War has been completely transformed into a series of stunning apartments - and they even still have the original reinforced doors and wallsThe bunker apartments seen from the air Image: Jam Press AllsopByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Nov | commentsThis nuclear bunker up for sale may look like any other from the outside, but on the inside, it hides three luxury apartments. The Grade II listed building in the seaside area of Shrublands Road, Mistley, Essex, was built in  during the Cold War. It was originally designed to serve as the communications aposhubapos of the county in the event of an attack. Now, it has been carefully restored and converted into a series of luxury apartments - one four-bed and two three-beds. Developers at BuildVantage have created the homes over two floors, centred around a beautul light-filled atrium. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. All three still have the original reinforced doors and walls made from military-grade tank steel and protected by thick reinforced concrete walls, and one of the properties even features an original ventilation system housed behind a glass wall. The homes have a luxurious feel with Italian marble bathrooms, granite worktops and underfloor heating.  And each apartment comes with its own off-road parking and enclosed garden.The properties are a stoneaposs throw from the historic village of Mistley and its train station, which has direct links to London Liverpool Street.Mistley offers ious local shops, a popular restaurant and train station whilst the walk to Manningtree will take you along the picturesque River Stour and lead you into the town centre where you can discover ious local shops, eateries and other amenities. The properties were originally listed inidually with prices starting at £, but are now being sold together at auction. The auction, through Allsop, will take place on  November.Property agent Max Turner from Savills in Ipswich said: Effortlessly stylish, the developers have found the perfect balance of combining modern-day luxury with restored original features to create an extraordinary transformation. It’s a truly unique development – connecting the past and present in a landmark building that’s part of the area’s heritage and which will of course make a great talking point when friends and family visit. We’ve already received a lot of very positive feedback and people are obviously interested in the bunker’s history, but it also ticks a lot of the boxes that buyers are continuing to look for – tucked away on the edge of the village with plenty of access to outdoor space, yet within a short distance of shops, restaurants and the nearby station.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news uk-news we-need-more-leaders-like-"Earthshot Prize: Prince William delivers speechByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsWhen Gator Halpern was studying environmental science at university, he admits he felt like he was writing the obituary of the natural world.Having grown up in San Diego, Calornia, with a deep connection to the oceans and natural world, he knew he wanted to do something to make a change amid the climate change and environmental crisis. So along with fellow Yale student Sam Teicher, he co-founded Coral Vita - an organisation based in the Bahamas that creates high-tech coral farms to grow and restore damaged coral reefs.Last month, Coral Vita was among one of the inaugural winners of the Earthshot Prize awards - an initiative set up by Prince William to find solutions to climate change and other environmental problems.Today, William will be at the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow along with the Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Charles and will meet some of the winners and finalists of the Earthshot Prize .And for Gator, he believes that the world needs more leaders like William willing to speak up and bring the climate change crisis to the fore. He told the Mirror: I think itaposs very clear that climate destabilisation and environmental issues are affecting every corner of our planet. They are the most important issues to address as they affect all of the other social issues we care so deeply about. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Without solving the climate crisis, thereaposs no way we can properly solve all of the other issues we care about. So for a leader like Prince William to spend his time, his energy and his influence in order to elevate that conversation is an incredible step in moving towards real tangible change in this space, and we need more leaders and politicians from the likes of Prince William to corporate leaders and other politicians around the world to step up and take this issue as serious as it needs to be taking, no longer paying lip service to what we are going to do with climate change goals we set at Cop but really making impactful and urgent changes to the systems we need to. We do understand the solutions and understand the problems, and know the steps we need to take but to date, there has not been the political will to address climate change at a meaningful level and in my opinion it is incredible that Prince William has been at the forefront of this and has elevated this issue out on the Earthshot stage and we need more leaders like him to play a leading role as well. Although Gator himself has not travelled to Glasgow for Cop, his co-founder Sam has and he will be attending talks and seminars on climate change - specically those that focus on the oceans and coral reefs.But Gator, a huge Liverpool FC fan, will still be keeping an eye on what is happening at the conference and says that we all must hold world leaders to account in order to force them to keep the promises they make there. He explained: I donapost think the commitments that countries make at events like Cop are the solution, we need to ensure that those commitments are both followed through on and expanded upon where successful. Too often these Cops have happened and politicians and leaders have used it as a  to say very progressive things that look like they are making progressive actions that later fall by the wayside and are never really followed upon. There are no mechanisms to hold anybody accountable for meeting any of those goals so I think itaposs very important for us to set ambitious goals at meetings like Cop, but it is even more important for us to hold our politicians accountable to meet those goals because to date it has been used as greenwashing far too often.  Indeed, itaposs fair to say that coral reefs, something that the Coral Vita team care deeply about, are at a critical point. Gator explained that half of the worldaposs reefs are already dead, with scientists projecting that primarily due to climate change and warming and acidying ocean conditions, over  per cent of the worldaposs reefs will die by . He said: In its own right, this is an ecological tragedy as coral reefs are one of the most magical ecosystems on earth. They cover less than one per cent of the earthaposs floor but they actually have a quarter of all marine le inside of them so they are one of the most bioerse habitats. But as well as being a serious ecological tragedy, it is also a serious socio-economic issue for up to a billion people around the world whose livelihoods directly depend upon coral reefs. At Coral Vita, Gator, Sam and the team are trying to restore these damaged reefs through the process of reef restoration.  Gator explained: We create innovative, high tech coral farms, which are on land, where we circulate a bunch of seawater through aquarium tanks. In those tanks we take small fragments of corals that have broken off the reef naturally, bring them into our coral farm, and we can grow them in mass. Right now our farm in the Bahamas grows around , corals a year that we have planted, but we aim with this Earthshot Prize to expand our work here towards , corals and eventually we envision having a global network of farms, each of which can grow millions of corals to distribute around restoration projects in a particular island or country. We want to accelerate coral, grow a much wider ersity and boost the resiliency of the corals against warming and the growing acidity of oceans that threaten their survival. At last monthaposs Earthshot Prize awards, both Gator and Sam couldnapost contain their delight when their organisation was named the winner of the protect our oceans category, scooping a £million prize.  And Gator said: To find out that we had won was truly the highest honour of our lives. It was an overwhelming experience where we were filled with such gratitude and pride in what weaposve done as a Coral Vita team but for all of the supporters who have enabled us to get to where we are today. It was a very special moment to speak with both Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge. They were both kind enough to spend a few minutes on a zoom call with us and the other winners and it was an incredibly special day all around to say that we even got the chance to meet and speak with the Duke of Cambridge. We are just so grateful for the vision that he has shown in creating this award, which we feel can be very inspirational in the climate crisis movement as there is a lot of doom and gloom and fear. It is is very much warranted in my eyes when we talk about the issues of climate destabilisation, and thataposs part of it that needs to be discussed, but the other end of it, what I think Prince William has done an amazing job doing, is showing the hope and optimism and the solutions and ways that we can make a dference in solving the issues that we are all so worried about. I completely agree that there is a lot to be grateful for, human beings are incredibly innovative and adaptive to quickly adapt to conditions and while the future will likely never look like the past, we can create a thriving future where humans and society are in balance with nature. But we must act urgently to do so, otherwise that balance will be skewed further and further away from thriving bioerse eco-systems that are essential for the true magic of le on earth. So there is optimism but the optimism needs to be coupled with urgency because every year we continue to not act on these climate commitments, and not make substantial changes, the outcomes that we are fighting so hard to create will be less and less positive. We know what we have to do, we know how to do it and we can be hopeful we can get it done, but we need to act as soon as we can in order to make the changes necessary. title: woman who vomits up 30
story: Woman who vomits up to  times a day has missed  Christmases with conditionEmily Webster, , suffers from ‘agonising and debilitating’ pain and said her whole le started ‘crashing down’ when she began to feel violently ill in , forcing her to spend three years in hospitalEmily Webster, , was initially diagnosed with IBS before doctors realised she had a rare condition Image: Emily WebsterByJoe PagnelliShiler Mahmoudi:,  Nov | commentsA woman who vomits up to  times a day has been told she has a rare stomach condition. Emily Webster, , suffers from agonising and debilitating pain and said her whole le started crashing down when she began to feel violently ill in . She was forced to take nine months off work and has spent three of the last five years in hospital. Emily has missed the last four Christmases and has seen the walls of a hospital more than her own home. She was initially told by doctors that she IBS, a common condition which causes indigestion. But it turned out to be a rare incurable condition called Gastroparesis which affects just six percent of people in the UK.  The condition causes Emily to vomit as her stomach cannot naturally empty itself of food as it is in partial paralysis.Emily, from Leeds, told LeedsLive : “I had my le taken away from me.“The past five years have been so dficult and lonely, but the worst part has been missing every single occasion of every year. “I missed four Christmases, I missed my best friend’s wedding, my best friend having a baby. “The surgery would make my le better, and it would improve the quality of my le. “I felt like I was in a never-ending cycle where I was told there was no cure and there was nothing anyone could do. Thankfully, she was handed a leline after she was told she would be a good candidate for a gastric pacemaker. The device would regulate her stomach and improve her le dramatically - but it’s not offered by the NHS and costs a staggering £,.She said: “But this is a chance. It would be incredible, even just that. “I’m planning all the things I want to do, the people I want to see.” She added: “If all goes well I should recover in time for the Christmas holidays. “It would be the best Christmas present I could ever get.”  When Emily went to her GP in , they asked her what her symptoms were and touched my tummy and told her to see a dietician. But the former bank worker said she could not go a day without feeling physical pain or vomiting - and would be sick up to  times a day. She saw her weight plummet, and at one stage tipped the scales at just five stone - the average weight of a -year-old girl.  Emily said: “It was so dficult, I was just sick every day. I went misdiagnosed for so long. “I spent most of the time in bed not being able to do anything. I kept losing weight as well. “I remember being so scared and worried how I would cope in le, even financially.” Despite her condition deteriorating, tests were unable to explain Emily’s condition and it was suggested her symptoms were caused by mental health issues. Emily was admitted to the national inpatient centre for psychological medicine at St James Hospital in  where she underwent therapy. She said: “I knew in my heart there was something wrong, but I felt so helpless because the tests were showing I was fine. “Sothere was nothing, I started telling myself maybe it’s true that it’s my own doing. “That’s when I started struggling with mental health, because I was spending so much time in hospital.  “I couldn’t work, I lost my house. My whole le came crashing down, and I felt so helpless.” But she finally had a breakthrough in , when a staff member at the hospital noticed her vomit was undigested and tests revealed she had the rare condition. She said it was the biggest relief to know she had not imagined all the pain over the last few years. The pacemaker is considered successfulit improves her condition by  percent, but Emily said she’d be happy with any improvement. She struggled with suicidal thoughts towards the end of her time in hospital, and said she was proud of herself and the journey she had taken.  She said: “It’s considered a successit improves the situation by  percent, but any improvement I would be happy with. “It would make my le better, and it would improve the quality of my le. The last five years have just blurred because so much has happened. “It’s been so lonely and scary and even terrying and heart-breaking at times. “I didn’t think I would be here now, so I’m proud of myself to have made it. I can’t believe I now have a glimmer of hope.”You can donate to Emily’s fundraiserhere .Comment MORE ON NHSHospitalsMarriageMental healthTherapy" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: american woman 21 wakes up
story: American woman, , wakes up with strong New Zealand accent after two weeks in comaSummer Diaz was hit by an SUV as she crossed a road on November  last year. After the accident, she spent two weeks in an induced coma and her family and boyfriend were not able to visit regularly due to the pandemicSummer Diaz in Hawaii in September  before her accident happened Image: Jam PressByLaura AbernethyGraeme Murray:,  Nov | commentsA woman woke up with a strong New Zealand accent after being in a coma for two weeks. Summer Diaz, , was hit by an SUV as she crossed a road on November  last year, which caused her to develop foreign accent syndrome - a rare condition where damage to the brain makes someone speak dferently. “I don’t remember anything about that day,” said the -year-old from Los Angeles, Calornia. “I came home from my job working with children who have autism. I didn’t have a parking space at my apartment so I had parked where and was walking across the street. “I don’t know what happened but apparently I was halfway across the crosswalk and I was hit by the SUV.” The driver called for help and Summer was rushed to the nearest hospital, where they discovered she had suffered a host of injuries including a broken pelvis, broken shoulder and a brain injury. After the accident on November  last year, she spent two weeks in an induced coma and as it was during the pandemic, her family and boyfriend weren’t even able to visit regularly. When she woke up, she was very disoriented and confused. She said: “I could hear people saying ‘you’re at the hospital, Summer.’ “They asked me to say the alphabet and I knew quite a bit of sign language, so I signed it. I could not speak vocally when I woke up. “I was able to do the whole thing and the staff actually asked my parentsI was deaf because of the sign language. My parents said no but I did know how to sign from taking classes in university. As Summer slowly started to talk again, one of the things she picked up on was changes to the way she was speaking but initially thought it was just due to being intubated while she was in a coma. She said: “I pulled out my tubes when I woke up causing some damage. Due to this I also have a condition called dysphagia, making swallowing dficult. “I remember trying to speak to people and my voice sounded dferent. “Then my boyfriend got special permission to visit me and he has an accent as he is from England. “He was talking to me and I felt like I was enunciating quite a bit and that it sounded dferent, but he said he couldn’t quite hear it. “Then I went to rehab and my voice started to get a bit better. I was working with speech therapists but I was still speaking quite slowly, so it was hard to hear anything. “As my voice got stronger people started to hear the accent more.” As Summer was talking more and more, people would question where she was from as she didn’t have an American accent. She said: “My nurses would come in and say ‘where are you from ’ and wouldn’t believe me when I said ‘I’m from here.’ “I would explain I was born here but they would say ‘but you have an accent.apos “I had to explain that it wasn’t my accent and I just started doing it.” Throughout her recovery, Summer has gone through a range of accents, with some lasting just a few hours and others staying for months. She said: “I had a very British accent, close to my boyfriend’s for a while. I had a French one at one point and briefly, I was Russian. “At the minute, it’s settled on an Australian or New Zealand accent.”  Summer has never even been to Australia or New Zealand but frequently people assume she was born or grew up there. She said: “I went back to the fire station to meet the people who brought me to hospital the other day and give them cake. “I saw the fire chief and I could tell on the phone he had an accent, but when I met him, he said ‘is that an Australian or New Zealand accent ’ “I explained it was New Zealand but he asked where I was from and I had to say I’m from here and he laughed. One thing that was hard for me was figuring out how to answer back when people ask about the accent. Do I go with where they think I am from or tell them the truth and get into talking about a whole incident with a stranger  Although it is a little unusual, Summer actually really loves having foreign accent syndrome. She said: “If I get hit by a car but get to the keep the accent, I’m ok with that - thataposs the best part. Thataposs fun. “I was always texting my friends telling them I really want to keep it because I really like accents.” After spending around a month in hospital and rehab, Summer was well enough tohome and was able to go back to university to finish the four classes required to complete her degree in psychology, while continuing with outpatient treatment.  This allowed her to access the university library to research more about her condition, which helped her officially get a diagnosis with an MRI on  August . There isn’t much treatment available and for some people, it does eventually go away but Summer is happy to wait and see what happens. Now, almost a year on from the accident, Summer’s accent is still far from what it was like before and her traumatic brain injury has caused a permanent disability. She said: Iaposm exhausted often. I am left with a lelong disability. I cannot work long hours at work, my stamina is poor, and I cannot do simple everyday activities. I rely on a cane when my leg aches and a wheelchair for long distances or for areas where I would have to be standing for a long period of time. I have a caregiver that helps me with my regular household chores and meal prepping. Every task requires energy andI am too exhausted I cannot perform some tasks later on in the day or the next day. Certain things will improve over time but other things will remain the same. As well as the physical side of her injury, the accent has had an impact on her work caring for children with autism. She said: I often pronounce my name as sum-mah and sometimes they hear it as So-Mah. I have had kids be confusedmy accent switches the next day, so much to the point where they have asked where the other Summer went as they donapost quite understand my condition. Learning how to navigate with a disability in the workplace has been a bit tricky for me. While this has had many downsides, it has caused my health to be more of a priority to me. I almost died so I try to enjoy the things I want to enjoy and be kind to others. I appreciate art and books more and enjoy the company of my loved ones more. I see the accent and what happened as something that will always be a conversation starter and a story to tell.
