title: elon musk says sell tesla
story: Elon Musk says he will sell Tesla stocks and use the money to solve world hungerThe worlds richest man has said he is prepared to sell of some of shares in electronic vehicle powerhouse Teslathe UN provide him with a clear and accountable plan of how to solve world hungerElon Musk has said he would sell of around % of his shares in Teslahe was provided with a clear route-map to end world hunger by the UN.ByHarry Thompson:,  Nov | comments The worldaposs richest man, Elon Musk, has pledged he will sell his Tesla stocks and use the proceeds to end world hunger providing the United Nationsare able to provide an open plan of where how the money will be used. Muskaposs sensational statement came after David Beasley, the Director of the UNapos World Food Programme, claimed is could be done with % of the Tesla founderaposs net worth.It is understood % of Muskaposs wealth equates to around  billion , at the time of writing Forbes reports Musk is worth some  billion .Responding to a tweet questioning whether this sum could actually solve world hunger, Musk wrote: If WFP can describe on this Twitter thread exactly how B will solve world hunger, I will sell Tesla stock right now and do it.  But it must be open source accounting, so the public sees precisely how the money is spent. In response Beasley wrote: We’ve never said B would solve world hunger. This is a one-time donation to save  million lives during this unprecedented hunger crisis. We need B plus NOW on top of our existing funding requirements due to the perfect storm from the compounding impact of Covid, conflict and climate shocks.  With your help we can bring hope, build stability and change the future. Let’s talk: It isn’t as complicated as Falcon Heavy, but too much at stake to not at least have a conversation. I can be on the next flight to you. Throw me outyou don’t like what you hear! Musk then said: Please publish your current  proposed spending in detail so people can see exactly where money goes. Sunlight is a wonderful thing. The exchange comes a a little over a month after the UN Secretary-general António Guterres lamented billionaires joyriding to space while millions go hungry on earth. Later in the Twitter conversation, musk linked to an article from the Express from , reporting that UN officials had been exchanging food for sex. The discussion came weeks after Muskaposs space tourism rivals, Jeff Bezosapos Blue Origin, launched former Star Trek actor William Shatner out of the earthaposs atmosphere, making him the worldaposs oldest person in space and ushering a new ear of celebrity-focused space travel. The move came under harsh criticism from the Duke of Cambridge, Prince William, who said: We need some of the worldaposs greatest brains and minds fixed on trying to repair this planet, not trying to find the next place to go and live. news us-news tiktok-user-discovers-hidden-part-"TikTok user discovers secret room in his apartment pantryByChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov | commentsA tenant was shocked after he noticed a wobbly wall in the pantry that led to a hidden part of his property he had no idea existed. Logan Hunter shared a video of the spooky discovery on TikTok, leaving hundreds of thousands of viewers baffled. The man, from the United States, filmed himself removing a light switch cap to examine the wooden wall behind it. In doing so, Logan realised the plywood had been installed poorly. In the clip, he said: I literally think I just discovered a hidden room in my apartment. I realised that this wall is really wobbly [and] thereaposs nothing behind it. So I’m going to take it apart and see what we can find. Then, as he removed part of the wall, he found a set of stairs leading to the ceiling of the house. But at some point, Logan paused the video, leaving viewers feeling curious, before filming another clip to reveal what he discovered. As he made his way up the stairs, he said they were kind of nice and sturdier than I thought theyaposd be. Upstairs, there was nothing to see other than huge piles of dust, but going further up he discovered what he described as a cute room.  The space was empty with two boarded-up windows. On the floor, there was an old dusty bandana and a bucket of woodchips. In the clip, Logan - who rents his house but does not have any flatmates - said: Why would they have this closed off  You can even stand up. This is such a cute room. Wait, maybe the floor is not safe.  While he said he wanted to make the space liveable, some people warned him of potential dangers such as unstable flooring and asbestos. One viewer commented: Landlord probably didnapost want to invest in making it livable. So, closed it off. Another added: Youaposre really brave because I would not be going up there at night, but Iaposm glad it turned out so cool! One joked: I was waiting for the demon in the corner to push you back down the stairs. But another suggested: Please decorate it and make it look nice, it would be so cute. Some viewers also encouraged Logan to make a series of videos showing how he renovates the newly discovered space. news weird-news glam-tiktoker-shares-before-after-"TikTok user gives proof that social media is fakeByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsWhile social media is no doubt a great tool for staying in touch and up to date with loved ones, itaposs no secret that it can have a detrimental effect on peopleaposs self-esteem.Itaposs often noted that apps such as Instagram only showcase the highlights of peopleaposs lives and not the reality, but that doesnapost stop us from feeling envious from those who appear to have the perfect le.In fact, more young people than ever before have a negative body image of themselves, and itaposs highly likely that seeing perfectly posed influencers and celebs all over our timelines has an impact on that. But, as we become increasingly aware of the importance of body positivity for all shapes and sizes, more and more influencers are getting real with their followers about just how fake social media can be. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.Danish TikTok influencer Josephine Livin @josephinelivinnrecently joined the long list of content creators offering up evidence that not all is as it seems, when it comes to what people post online.Josephine shared a series of photos of herself looking perfect and posed, which had all been posted to social media, before switching to photos taken immediately after, when she allowed her body to relax. The people you compare yourself to online don’t look like that  , she wrote, alongside the clips of herself tensing and relaxing. She later added in the comments section: A reminder that we can all pose and tense and find the right angle, the right light and look amazing in a new outfit and wear the prettiest makeup. But at the end of the day weaposre all human beings and nothing is as perfect as it can sometimes seem on social media. Youaposre beautul. Youaposre enough. This is the influencer realness everyone deserves to see on their timeline.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: mum leaves sassy note pavement
story: Mum leaves sassy note on pavement for neighbour who moaned about son’s chalk artAshley Woodfolk hit back at her neighbour after they complained about seeing her son’s drawings on the pavement – by writing her a note in chalk in their courtyardThe neighbour complained to building management and got pavement chalk bannedImage: Getty Images Brand XByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Nov | commentsMany of us will have played with chalk when we were children and some of us will also remember using special pavement chalk to draw hopscotch lines and other fun doodles outside. Pavement chalk is designed to wash away in the rain, but one person has been left so annoyed at the sight of the temporary drawings outside their flat that they contacted the building management.Ashley Woodfolk, from New York, USA, took to Twitter @AshWrites to share her story after she allowed her son to draw with pavement chalk in their building’s courtyard, and was met with resistance from one of her neighbours.And after building management listened to the neighbour’s complaints and stopped the use of chalk outside the property, the mum hit back – by writing a note to her disgruntled neighbour in chalk across the courtyard. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. A picture of the note was shared on Twitter, which reads: “Good evening to everyone except the woman at my co-op who complained to the board about me and my toddler using sidewalk chalk in the courtyard. “So I wrote her a little letter. In sidewalk chalk. In the courtyard.” In the letter, Ashley explained using the pavement chalk had brought her toddler “joy” amid the COVID- pandemic, as she’s wary of taking her son to public places. She continued to say: “This will be my last time using sidewalk chalk in the courtyard since it seems to be such a problem for you . “Iaposm sorry such harmless fun that brought my toddler joycauses you so much distress that you have to complain to the board and waste everyoneaposs time when our building has much bigger real problems. “I think youaposre aware that weaposre in a pandemic and while Iaposd love to take my kid to museums and the movies, I donapost feel doing that, and sometimes even local parks are more crowded than Iaposm comfortable with.“The courtyard was a safe space but now there are limits on that too. “There are only a few weeks of nice weather left, and I sincerely hope that you enjoy the use of the sidewalk-chalk free courtyard for the remainder of the fall. And I hope that every time it rains, rain that would have washed away any colourful ABCaposs I wrote on the ground, you think of me.” Ashley’s post has received more than , likes and many people can’t believe the cheek of the mum’s neighbour. One person said: “I very much applaud your response to a ridiculous prohibition of your child’s creativity.” While another wrote: “Before I became disabled, I would hop every single chalk hopscotch that I came across. Sidewalk chalk art is art for everyone and is so temporary that to get upset about it is a symptom of a sad existence. Chalk on, little one!” Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. story: Specsavers win Twitter with COP tweet to reporter that has people laughing out loudSpecsavers have left Twitter users laughing out loud with their reply to a CNN reporter who is covering COP from Edinburgh - instead of Glasgow where the conference is being heldCNN reporter Wolf Blitzer in EdinburghByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Nov | commentsThe  United Nations Climate Change Conference, also known as COP, has kicked off in Glasgow and reporters from all over have flocked to the city to cover it.However, not all reporters are in the city, some are working from other areas nearby, including CNNaposs Wolf Blitzer who posted on Twitter to show he was in Edinburgh. He wrote: I’m now reporting from Edinburgh in Scotland where , world leaders and delegates have gathered for the COP Climate Summit. COP, by the way, stands for aposConference of the Partiesapos. It’s the th time they have gathered to discuss and take action on this critical issue.Many people were amused by the tweet and couldnapost resist pointing out that the news organisation was in the wrong city. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.One person replied: American TV channels going aposlookwe’re going to report from Scotland our viewers are gonna wanna see a big castleapos. Another said: Forgive meI get my information from a news organization that managed to go to the right city. A third asked: You know they are in Glasgow, right But the best response came from Specsavers who posted: Shouldaposve gone to Glasgow.Their reply went viral, with thousands liking the tweet and many people proclaiming that they won Twitter and it was the tweet of the day.You win Twitter, joked one user. A second agreed, saying: Definitely the winner. Well done @Specsavers. A third admitted: Actually laughed out loud in the middle of Morrisonaposs cafe..... Quality. While a fourth person added: Specsavers, your social media work is done. Take the rest of the week off. However, others were more sympathetic towards Wolf, with someone  sharing how his tweet just needed wording a little better. They posted: Heaposs not saying COP is being held in Edinburgh... He is saying he is reporting from Edinburgh which is in Scotland where COP is being held.... and he is correct... COP IS being held in Scotland... could have been worded a bit better tho...What do you think  Let us know in the comments below.Comment MORE ON SpecsaversCNNCOPViralFunny ha ha viral" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman most right swipes tinder
story: Woman with the most right swipes on Tinder failed to find love on the appEliana Silver was among the most right-swiped women on Tinder in , yet the journalism student failed to find love on the dating app, meeting her boyfriend offline insteadEliana was among the  women with the most right swipes in  Image: Kennedy News and MediaByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Nov | commentsA student who was listed as one of the most popular women on Tinder back in  has revealed she had absolutely no success in finding love on the dating app. In fact, Eliana Silver, who was one of the most swiped right people two years ago, ended up meeting her boyfriend offline. The -year-old, who originally hails from the United States, moved to Aberdeen in Scotland for university, and decided to download the app in a bid to meet new people. But, despite having to much interest from potential matches, the journalism student confessed she was very apospickyapos over who she swiped right to, so she didnapost actually end up getting many matches. I set my Tinder account up in my last year of high school just to see what would happen but I didnapost use it much and only went on one date. Then when I got to uni people were using it a lot more - everyone had it, Eliana explained. I wanted to seeI could meet someone and it was a way of meeting people to make friends as well because I was completely new, Iaposd never been to Scotland before. However, she was left stunned when she was contacted out of the blue in  and told she was in the top  aposswiped rightapos people on Tinder in the UK and Ireland that year - making her in the top  women within this. When the ranking was published, along with a link to Elianaaposs Tinder profile, this rocketed even more to where , people were swiping right on her in a week. The summer after my first year of university a magazine contacted me about the top  swiped right people on Tinder that year. At first I thought it was a scam email because I thought thereaposs no way out of all the amazing, beautul people in the UK that Iaposm in the top  - it was definitely an ego boost, she recalled. I was shocked as I didnapost have too many matches because Iaposm quite picky and I only really spoke to and met up with two guys, but it was based on how many people swiped you. Iaposve never seen myself as someone who is extremely attractive or interesting enough for people to swipe right on. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. But despite this, things never worked out or lasted more than two dates with anyone she met on the app, as she says most singletons seemed only interested in a aposquick hook-upapos. Eliana said: My goal was not one night stands like it is for a lot of people and some of my friends, but to meet people and establish connections. Thereaposs two sides of the app - thereaposs the side trying to meet up with people for a quick hook up and then never talk to them again and then thereaposs the other side of people genuinely looking to meet someone and that side is much smaller. There were so many people that contacted me that I didnapost end up going on dates with because they would use a bad pick-up line or there just wasnapost an instant connection. I got asked to be a sugar baby a few times and some people outright askedI wanted to come over and have sex, it was really creepy.  One of the guys I met up with from Tinder clearly was just there because he thought he had a chance of hooking up later and he even got his phone out to show me his other matches and was saying how fit they were. She has since abandoned online dating, saying meeting people in person aposworks  times betterapos and is  months deep in a happy relationship with her boyfriend, Jordan Benson, , who she met through mutual friends. Eliana said: We met through mutual friends - we were under Covid restrictions at the time but you were allowed six people in a house so I said to my friend you bring two friends over and Iaposll have two friends here. The first one and a half months of knowing each other we were just friends and met up as a group and then it blossomed into something more. I think the best romances come from friendship and establishing connections in person works  times better for me because you find out who they are and see what theyaposre like. You donapost have that awkwardness of knowing youaposre meeting someone to try and be together and the fear of going on a first date. Elianaaposs boyfriend Jordan said: We definitely clicked well as friends at first and after being friends for a while I just started to feel more of a romantic connection and she did too but we didnapost say anything for a while. I donapost like dating apps. I donapost like the idea of looking for people online as youaposd look for clothing. Iaposve never used them.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: hermit cat living building roof
story: Hermit cat living on building roof for over  years and refuses to come downThe cat has refused to come down from the roof for anyone and local people and firefighters have been unable to persuade him as he runs away when anyone triesThe cat that has been living on the roof of a building in Corums Sungurlu district in Turkey for more than four years Image: NewsflashByFeza UzayGraeme Murray:,  Nov | commentsA hermit cat that has been living on a roof for over four years and refuses to come down. The cat lives in the district of Sungurlu in the northern Turkish province of Corum, where local residents keep him well fed and provide water every day. Local cobbler Ahmet Koylu said: I know this cat has not left the roof for at least four years. Even the efforts of local fire brigades were all in vain. Bazaar shopkeepers bring it food and water. Along with normal cat food, we also leave liver, chicken and fish. He comes for it after we leave. When the cat is out of food, he calls down to us like he is begging.  Koylu added: The cataposs story is very well known around here. He has refused to come down from the roof for anyone including firefighters from the area, and has become a local attraction. Other residents said they have been trying to get the animal off the roof for a long time, but he runs away as soon as he sees someone. Tea shop owner Muttalip Yavuz, who also helps to feed the feline, said: The cat jumped there from an opposite roof two or three years before the pandemic and we cannot get it off the roof to this day.  He really does not like people. He decided to stay away from everyone and live on the roof on its own. Yavuz added: The fire brigade have come three or four times to rescue it from the roof, but with no luck. As a result, shopkeepers around here decided the best option was to put food and drink on the roof. title: man detained after two girls
story: Man detained after two girls,  and , thrown ft from high rise to their deathsNeighbours of the property in Kyzyl, the capital of Russia’s mountainous Tyva republic, heard terrible screams as the girls fell to their deathsThe window from which the girls are believed to have been thrown Image: Tyva ByWill Stewart:,  Nov  A -year-old man has been detained after two girls, aged nine and , were thrown from the eighth floor of an apartment block in Russia.One of the sisters died after the ft fall, while the other died at hospital as a result of her injuries. Neighbours of the property in Kyzyl, the capital of Russia’s mountainous Tyva republic, heard terrible screams as the girls fell - several minutes apart - in the early hours of the morning. Ochur Sanchat, the detainee, was a relative of the girls’ mother. He had claimed they were ‘making too much noise’ in a flat where he rented a room while being on the run from police, law enforcement sources said. The children’s mother was working a night sht at a cafe when her daughters were killed, while her third daughter, a twin sister of the nine year old, was in bed at the time and remained unhurt. Sanchat has been detained for two months on suspicion of committing a double murder.The man confessed to throwing the girls from a window, law enforcement said. He was described as being on the run from police over a car theft. He had fled from court and was on Russia’s federal wanted list. A neighbour called Irina heard the terrible screams as the girls were thrown out. I woke up from a slammed balcony door and terrible screams,” she said. “While I was trying to figure out what was happening, literally a minute passed, there was a strong roar, terrible screams, and then everything subsided for three or four minutes. “Then it happened again… “I was alone at home with my children.” Irena said she didn’t stick her head out, but instead called the police. The Russian Investigative Committee confirmed the  year old had been detained for two months. Detectives are also checking reports that police had been called to the family home multiple times in the week leading up to the tragic deaths. title: mysterious car parked same italian
story: Mysterious car parked on same Italian street for  years becomes tourist attractionAngelo Fregolent, now , parked his Lancia Fulvia  outside the newsagent he ran with his we, Bertilla Modolo, in Conegliano in  - the couple then retired and left the car there and it has since become a local landmarkThis Lancia Fulvia was parked in the same place for  years in Conegliano in Veneto, Italy Image: Google Maps NewsflashByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | comments A mysterious car that has been parked on an Italian street for  years has become a tourist attraction. The old Lancia is now going to be removed, restored and turned into a monument as it has become part of the townaposs landmarks.Angelo Fregolent, , parked his Lancia Fulvia  outside the newsagent he ran with his we, Bertilla Modolo, in Conegliano in .Angelo told Il Gazzettino: I ran the newsstand under the house for  years together with my we Bertilla, ten years younger than me.When I opened the business, I was happy to have the Lancia Fulvia parked in front of it because I had the newspapers unloaded in the trunk and then I took them inside.  When the couple retired they left the car and it has since become part of the townaposs aesthetic. Tourists and residents started snapping selfies with the old car and it became a landmark as photos on social media went viral. The townaposs officials have now decided to move the car after nearly five decades. It was removed on October  and transferred to the Auto e Moto daposEpoca Motorshow in Padua where it was on display alongside dozens of other timeless classic cars.  It was then sent to a workshop to be carefully restored and to fix the damage from sitting outside for  years. Once fully restored, it will be placed outside a local school just next to Angelo and Bertillaaposs house which means they will be able to admire their old car from their window whilst tourists pass by to snap selfies. Luca Zaia, a -year-old resident, told Il Gazzettino: The car has been parked there since I was going to school. The Fulvia was designed by Piero Castagnero and became renowned in the world of motorsport after successfully competing in the  International Rally Championship. title: three egypt hotel workers detained
story: Three Egypt hotel workers detained after almost  tourists struck by food poisoningThree workers at a five-star hotel in the Egyptian city of Hurghada have been detained after  tourists were hospitalised with food poisoning - the hotel has now reportedly shutUp to  people staying at a five-star hotel in Egypt were hospitalised after being struck by food poisoning Image: Getty ImagesByClaire Gilbody-DickersonNews reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThree workers at a five-star hotel have been detained after  tourists got food poisoning while staying there. A total of  Russians,  Estonians and four Czech Republic nationals were taken to hospital after falling ill at the AMC Royal hotel in Hurghada, Egypt, over the weekend. As a result of the widespread illness, the Public Service Prosecution in Egypt decided to detain the assistant director of food and beverages, the hotel’s quality officer and the chief chef for four days, pending investigations. According to local reports, the public prosecution first received reports of  people from Estonia falling ill on October .It then emerged how more tourists had been taken to hospital with food poisoning after dining at the hotel in the city of Hurghada, a popular hotspot for scuba ers. Have you stayed at this hotel and suffered from food poisoning  Email webnews@mirror.couk  An inspection has reportedly been conducted at the hotel, and samples were taken from the hotel’s food in the kitchen and freezers. Various water sources and locations where the food got processed were also examined. Results of the investigation will be included in a report, the Egypt Independent reports. According to Russian news agency Tass, which puts the number of Russians who fell sick to  rather than , the tourists have been relocated to dferent hotels.While the Egyptian Federation of Tourist Chambers told Tass: Forty people turned to the hospital for assistance. By now, four have been discharged from it and  others are undergoing medical treatment. The health condition of all the patients is satisfactory, stable and not le-threatening. Doctors can discharge them from the hospital on Monday, it said. The hotel doesnapost just face big financial penalties, but also indefinite closure. The hotel may face not only big financial penalties but also its full closure with the revocation of its license for failure to comply with sanitary requirements for foodstuffs, beverages and services, the Federation added. title: see inside aberdeens under the hammer ahead of its opening next week
story: One of Aberdeen’s beloved pubs, which closed in March last year, will reopen under new ownership next week following an extensive refurbishment. Under the Hammer has been taken over by independent hospitality operators, The McGinty’s Group, and will open on Friday November  at pm. The popular basement bar located on North Silver Street, just off Golden Square, will reopen with a stylish new look with a new hand-crafted bar and modern interiors with a nod to the venue’s heritage throughout.

title: its going to be transformational what changes are coming to buckie harbour from moray west offshore wind farm
story: Confirmation that Buckie Harbour will become an operations and maintenance base for the Moray West offshore wind farm will lead to huge changes at the port. The existing harbour office will be demolished to make way for a new building that will manage the turbines as well as their construction and upkeep. The new command centre is just one of several massive changes due at Buckie Harbour following the Moray West announcement.

title: angus macneil i certainly would not bet on the scottish government managing to hold a referendum
story: Events in politics may now mean for certain that a referendum on Scottish independence is blocked and the only avenue to ask the population the question on independence is at an election, says SNP MP for the Western Isles, Angus MacNeil. This month’s Supreme Court decision on blocking Scottish Parliament bills was a seismic event which could affect the independence process for Scotland for years to come.
