.dct-cta__content@media only screen and .dct-cta--subscribe--contained .dct-cta__flex.dct-cta--subscribe--contained .dct-cta__image-wrap@media only screen and @supportsor .dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remBoss Stephen Glass admits he faces a selection headache amid Aberdeen#s revival in form.Hit with a defensive injury crisis, the Pittodrie boss brought Dean Campbell and Dylan McGeouch back in for rare starts.Both started, and impressed, in the - draw at Rangers and then the - defeat of Hearts as the Dons ignited a faltering season.Glass admits Campbell and McGeouch have made it dficult for them to be dropped when the injury crisis ends.The draw at Rangers was the first start for Campbell and McGeouch since August.Campbell, , excelled in an unfamiliar left-sided defensive role at Ibrox and also impressed in the - defeat of Hearts when retaining his starting spot.McGeouch, , provided an assist for Scott Brown#s goal at Ibrox and also set up Lewis Ferguson for the winner against Hearts with dead-ball deliveries.Glass insists they have given him a welcome selection dilemma for when the defensive crisis alleviates after the international break.He said: #Dylan and Dean have not played a lot, but for them to put on the performance they did at Rangers and then do it againis fantastic.#For them to produce that in two huge games shows how well they are training and their professionalism.#When players perform like that they make it dficult to leave them out#It is a great problem to have.#Campbell had started just one game this seasonprior to being named in the starting line-up to face league leaders Rangers.McGeouch had started only twice before facing Rangers, with his last game time the - loss to Celtic on October  when he was introduced as a substitute for Scott Brown in the nd minute.Glass hailed their professionalism for never adopting a negative attitude despite lack of game time and for their continued focus and hard work in training to push back into his starting plans.Glass said: #They have been giving me something to think about all year.“When players like that come in then their professionalism shows or it doesn’t“You can see how professional Dylan has been over the piece when he hasn’t really played.“He has been in and out and had to sit and wait his turn.“Dylan has been brilliant. He  kept the ball for us really well,  has been defensively sound and got around the pitch, so I’m really pleased with him.#In defeating Hibs -, Aberdeen ended a confidence sapping -game run without victory.However, the three points against Hibs came at a cost as full-back Calvin Ramsay and Scotland international centre-back Declan Gallagher both picked up injuries that will rule them out until after the international break.Full-back Jack MacKenzie missed the Hibs game with an injury suffered in training that will also rule him out until later this month.With Scotland international centre-back Andy Considine out until the new year following cruciate ligament surgery, Glass did not have his defensive problems to seek.With a daunting trip to Ibrox looming, he turned to Campbell and McGeouch # and insists he always had complete trust they would rise to the occasion.McGeouch operated in midfield to allow Scott Brown to drop into a centre-back role with Campbell slotting into the left of defence.Aberdeen have now taken seven points from the last nine against Hearts, Rangers and Hibs.Glass said: “People asked me before the Hearts game about trust in the players and I trust them  per cent or they wouldn#t be selected.#I am delighted by them all.#I have % trust in a player like Dean.#Glass oversaw a major overhaul of the squad in the summer with  players signed and  exiting Pittodrie.The Dons manager was quick to shoot down comments players were sitting frustrated in the stand.He insists the positive impact of McGeouch and Campbell is proof of a harmonious squad with players, whether playing regularly or not, all focused on contributing to the cause.He said: “I’m delighted with the competition we have for places.“I was told there was comments out there that it is dficult to keep that number of players happy when you leave seven or eight in the stand.“But we have never done that because there is health issues going around, injuries, so there have been times I have left none out and have the  I have.“Managing a group is a challenge, but it is one we are capable of and I think you saw, let’s say fringe players, you saw their reaction to coming in and the work they are asked to do.“We are in a good place at the minute.”Glass confirmed Ramsay, MacKenzie and Gallagher will definitely miss Saturday#s clash with Motherwell at Pittodrie.He said: #The three of them won’t be back until after the international break.”

title: darcy-graham-set-20th-cap-bt-murrayfield-saturday
story: FORMER Hawick player Darcy Graham has been selected for Scotlandrsquos opening match of the  Autumn Nations Series against Tonga at BT Murrayfield on Saturday  October ndash kick-off :pm.This will be the Edinburgh flyer Grahamrsquos th international appearance having earned his first cap coming off the bench against Wales in Cardf for the Doddie Weir Cup in November .He starts at full-back and is joined in the back three by Glasgow duo Kyle Steyn, who will add to his single cap won against France in the last match at BT Murrayfield played in front of crowds in March , and Rufus McLean who will make his first Scotland start.Joining McLean on Scotland debut will be clubmate Sione Tuipulotu who lines up with fellow Glasgow Warrior Sam Johnson as the centre partnership.Co-Captain and Lions scrum-half Ali Price teams up with Edinburghrsquos Blair Kinghorn at fly-half to form a brand new half-back pairing.In the pack fellow British  Irish Lions Zander Fagerson starts at tighthead prop with Hamish Watson at openside flanker, as they feature for Scotland for the first time since the South Africa tour this summer.Edinburgh Rugbyrsquos Jamie Ritchie, also named as Co-Captain, packs down on the blindside of the scrum which is anchored by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo Matt Fagerson at number eight.Youth and experience combine in the second row which sees Rob Harley earn his rd cap for Scotland and joined by Edinburgh lock Jamie Hodgson, who will win his first cap.Up front George Turner starts at hooker with Fagerson and with a debutant on the loose-head side in Edinburgh Rugbyrsquos Pierre Schoeman.Edinburgh Rugby provide forward replacements on debut in the form of lock Marshall Sykes and back-row Luke Crosbie.Glasgow Warriors half-back partners Jamie Dobie and Ross Thompson are the uncapped backs.Former Scotland Captain Stuart McInally is available off the bench alongside Glasgow props Jamie Bhatti and Oli Kebble in the front row, with backrow forward Nick Haining of Edinburgh completing the matchday squad..removeScotland Head Coach Gregor Townsend said: ldquoAs a playing and coaching group we are looking forward to ing to international rugby over the coming four weeks in the Autumn Nations Series.ldquoThis week has been our first opportunity since the Six Nations to come together as a team, and our goal is to become a better team over the next month. Saturday will also be a huge occasion for a number of players in our squad who have the honour of playing for their country for the first time.ldquoTonga will be very dangerous opponents for us, as they pose a ferocious physical challenge in attack and defence. They performed very well on their last visit to Scotland and Irsquom sure they will be highly motivated to take the game to us once again.

title: excellent-performances-gala-harriers-scone-palace
story: A NUMBER of runners from Gala Harriers took part in the Scottish National Cross-Country Relays at Scone Palace on Saturday.Kirsty Rankinegot off to a great start over the fast .k course to hand over to Erin Grayin th. Erin had an excellent run, pulling the girls back to th, leaving U Isla Paterson for the final leg. This brought the girls home in a very well-deserved th. In this event, Gala also fielded an incomplete team ndash with Kacie Brownand Poppy Lunngetting their first taste of national relays and running very well at this level of competition.Next up were the boys. A total of  teams toed the starting line and Archie Dalgliesh set off for the Us, fighting his way through the field and handing over to U Zico Field in th. Zico had a strong run and pulled back a few places to th, leaving Ewan Christie for what was possibly the Gala run of the day. He charged through the field and held on for a fantastic th overall  The second Gala team ndash consisting of Charlie Dalgliesh, Ross Christie and Cameron Rankine ndash also ran strongly and finished th overall.The Senior and Masters teams raced over a scenic km loop.Three teams featured for Gala in the omens race. The A team were given a great start by Sara Green with a strong opening leg of : minutes. Fantastic support was then provided by Lizzie Macleish , Lisa Dalglieshand Charlotte Hendryfor a th place finish overall.On paper the W team looked to be well-balanced with strong runners in all positions and so it proved. Gill Lunn , Pamela Baillieand Katy Bardencombined for th place overall ndash just over  seconds outside of the medal spots.The highlight of the day for the Gala team was a bronze-medal winning performance from the W team. Terric performances from Julie Johnstone , Lindsay Dunand Carole Fortuneproved good enough for rd place.The M team of Gary Trewartha , Brian Aitchison , Graeme Murdochand Wayne Mcintoshgave their all and left the course happy and with a bronze medal around their necks. However, subsequent revisions to the results relegated the team to th place in the M category..removeDarrell Hastie led the senior mens team out in typically fast fashion with a : minute leg. The baton was then passed to Fergus Johnston , Paul Hendersonand Iain Buckley , resulting in th place overall. club.The forever-young Bob Johnson completed the teams efforts running a solid solo leg in :.

title: peebles-man-lost-father-covid-formed-ppe-company
story: AN INTERNATIONAL company formed by a Peebles man in the wake of the pandemic to manufacture vital PPE has sponsored local National Hunt Jockey Ryan Mania.Cameron lsquoCammyrsquo Young felt the brunt of the global pandemic early on when he tragically lost his father to COVID-.Further impacting him, his mother was then hospitalised only one month later but has since made a full recovery.Having seen first-hand the overwhelming effects of this disease, Cameron decided to put together a plan to make a dference.In just a few months, it became apparent that the lack of PPE in Scotland and hospitals all over the world was becoming a signicant problem and he decided to step in and be a part of the solution.He founded Envelicus Ltd an international firm focused on the manufacturing of Nitrile and Latex gloves.Utilizing a factory-direct model, Envelicus has established capacity contracts and partnerships with some of the best factories in the world for global production and distribution.The Envelicus mission is ldquoPutting gloves on the hands of the people who need them.With strong ties to the region, Envelicus decided to sponsor Borders jockey Ryan Mania.The pair met during their time as common riding principles in  and have remained good friends.

title: colleges-get-work-key-climate-actions
story: Throughout history, signicant change has taken strong leadership. We will see somewhere in the region of  world leaders in Glasgow next month for the COP climate change conference, and that will occupy the front pages for its duration.However, itrsquos clear that the scale of action needed in the face of catastrophic climate change requires strong collective leadership at every level. Where better to begin than education to relay the message of how urgently our behaviours need to change.With that in mind, Scotlandrsquos colleges are providing leadership on a strong collective front. Not only do they need to be the messengers, but they also need to pay attention to the message, with shts in their own working models and practices.Many colleges in Scotland have been working on this steadily. Following the Paris agreement at COP in , colleges have been making good progress in reducing carbon emissions. In fact, since reporting began in  . The sector has achieved an overall % reduction in emissions. This is better progress than the whole of the public sector, which has reduced by % over the same period.Clearly % is impressive but there is work to be done towards achieving the Scottish Government reporting expectations, and the sectorrsquos own statement of commitment, to achieve Net Zero climate emissions by  or earlier.Bringing together the current thinking and setting out a joint agenda, College Development Networkrsquos Climate Emergency Expert Group hosted the inaugural College Climate Change Conference, earlier this month.Held online with representatives of the college expert group and partners, it gave a strategic overview of the climate change actions that the college sector should be engaged in.It follows the development of the Scottish Colleges Statement on the Climate Emergency, which lists  key actions that colleges have committed to delivering.ldquoThe college sectorrsquos role in this is going to be huge, says Jim Metcalfe, Chief Executive of College Development Network . ldquoWe have a role to make sure that our own institutions, campuses, and staff and student travel is Net Zero. We have a role to provide the skills to ensure the economy can reform itself to be Net Zero ndash how we teach and train and develop people. And we have a role in how to influence change in our communities ndash we are crucial anchor institutions across the country that can influence the way our regional economies can change for the better..removeSkills development is something that is absolutely crucial in the contribution of colleges. The vocational courses that many offer, those that have an impact on our everyday lives will clearly need to change in line with green technologies as well as manufacturing and building practices.ldquoTo achieve Net Zero wersquoll need new green jobs, which in turn means wersquoll need to ensure we have people with the right skills to take up those jobs, says Dr Mike Cantlay OBE, Chair of the Scottish Funding Council.Providing an idea of scale, at the conference he pointed out that one change, the sht to electric vehicles, will require , people to be trained or retrained to support the new technology.ldquoThat means we have huge reskilling and upskilling tasks ahead of us. Through initiatives such as the National Transition Training Fund, colleges are already providing great opportunities for reskilling and upskilling ndash and these examples demonstrate the responsive-ness and agility of the college sector. But our success will rely on our ability to inspire future learners to consider these new career options, and I commend the work of colleges in this crucial task.Its clear that colleges are playing a crucial part in our rapidly changing landscape and as Angela Cox, Principal and CEO of Borders College, explained at the conference, colleges, perhaps more than ever are acting as catalysts of change.Also a lead Principal on the Climate Emergency within the College Principals Group, Angela Cox details some of the changes happening at Borders College.ldquoAll students at Borders college will complete a carbon literacy module at the start of their programme but this is only a small part of their development, she explains. ldquoHowever, that needs to be brought to le in their subject learning. A small but good example is a project with Bordersrsquo hairdressing students looking at the choice of dye products ndash synthetic versus organic and what happens when the waste product including peroxide is rinsed and flows into the water system.Angela Cox points to projects that are initiated by students, and through creating employer partnerships are also powerful catalysts for change. An example is a former Borders College plumbing student who invented a device to stop water leaks immediately while the fault was found. His company Kibosh now operates globally.She says, ldquoWe are also sharing our carbon literacy module with our schools and housing associations and supporting the delivery through a train the trainer approach. Over time this means that students progressing to the college already have the basics and our projects become more innovative and collaborative through our community partnerships.Angela Cox adds, ldquoColleges are in a unique and privileged position to take a leading role in achieving Net Zero. We have the power to influence the behaviours and values of our students, staff and communities. I am proud that Borders College is seizing the opportunity to help secure a sustainable future for the Scottish Borders and beyond.College staff and students have spent a considerable amount of time creating this new culture for colleges, where the consideration of climate impact isnrsquot a tick box but goes to the heart of everything they do.In November  Dundee and Angus College was invited to take part in the pilot of the College Learning for Sustainability Champions course, run by EAUC and Learning for Sustainability Scotland.Christine Calder, Academic Development Lead at the College explained at the conference how important it was for Dundee and Angus to be involved.ldquoOne lecturer from each of our  curricular departments attended the course. This gave us a real opportunity to know who a friend of sustainability was in each department.  lecturers, working with an average of  students. Thatrsquos  people directly affected. Thenwe add in the conversations that have happened in those studentsrsquo homes and with friends or the conversations that the lecturers had within their departments let alone their friends and families as well as students in other classes. Thatrsquos the ripple effect.Dr Katie Paget, Science Lecturer and Learning and Teaching Skills Mentor at Dundee and Angus College was one of the lecturers who was part of the pilot for the science team. She says, ldquoIn many ways the pandemic has brought the themes within the UNrsquos Sustainable Development Goalsinto the limelight, and this gives us a powerful opportunity.ldquoThis academic year we have embedded the SDGs into our Lecturer Professionalism Pathway. Within the course lecturers can reflect on, and share ways that they can embed such themes within their teaching and have the opportunity to try out ideas in a supportive environment.ldquoOur hope is that by weaving these into our curriculum with new lecturers during their early career, linking SDGs in their classrooms can become a foundation within their teaching, and not an extra.Its clear that the sector has put time and effort into creating a climate change strategy with clear goals and is working with a greater shared purpose than ever before.ldquoThe sector is now focused on operationalising those actions and achieving against that statement of commitment, on campuses and in teaching across the country as a sector, adds Jim Metcalfe, Chief Executive of CDN. ldquoIrsquom hopeful and aspirational about this agenda. ____________________________________________________________________Roadmap outlines path towards Net Zero futureWORKING towards the same ends takes collective knowledge and purpose. To that end a Climate Action Roadmap for colleges has been developed by the Climate Commission for UK Higher and Further Education, to support colleges at all stages of their progress towards Net Zero.The roadmap was developed closely with college leaders, students, and partners to ensure that it was relevant to every college, no matter what stage it hasreached on its sustainability journey.Itrsquos a tool that can be a useful gap analysis, to show where you are doing well, but identy where improvements are required. The roadmap alsofactors in cost and time commitments for each action, which helps in that planning.It covers all areas of the college, so you look at distinct areas in detail, such as leadership and governance, teaching and learning, estates and partnerships, and engagement.The Climate Action Roadmap illustrates clearly what an emerging college could look like. It helps colleges to tailor actions to match strategy. This is seen as an opportunity, in advance of COP to show how Scottish colleges are leading the way on climate change.From the date that every college commits to the roadmap, it has a full year to develop targets and show how those will be implemented.Workshops to develop the roadmap were carried out in June, attended by staff, and partners of Scotlandrsquos colleges. Billy Currie, Head of Corporate Services at Dumfries  Galloway College attended those workshops and says he could identy benefits for reviewing climate change plans immediately.Some colleges across the sector havebeen working in this area this since . Billy believes that one of the roadmaprsquos great strengths is its flexibility, where it can strengthen and consolidate the work that has already been done.At the College Climate Change Conference he explained, ldquoAt Dumfries  Galloway we carried out something of a progress review. We have used the Colleges get to work on key climate actions roadmap to reflect on our previous climate change action plan, to see where we could identy successes.ldquoWe could identy elements such as using renewable technologies in new builds, looking at our electric fleet vehicles, and identying partners for our student transport. We also have an established waste network with zerowaste goals for going to landfill.Billy Currie adds that an area that they could strengthen was governance. ldquoWe had already taken steps at Dumfries  Galloway in terms of setting our targets and annual reporting, both to the board and the cross-college Climate Action Group.ldquoBy using the roadmap we were able to declare a climate emergency, signed by the Principal, the Board Chair, and the Studentsrsquo Association President. ldquoThe declaration document commits the college to taking continued action on climate change matters. ldquoClimate change is now embedded into our systems and infrastructure strategies. We also have key performance indicators measuring what wersquore doing year on year ndash these are monitored by the Board, senior leadership and the climate action group.Billy Currie adds that working on awareness among staff and students, particularly in subject areas, is crucial to achieving the sustainable development goals.ldquoClimate change action is embedded at Dumfries  Galloway College, and we now have a revised plan, which is more focused because of the roadmap. As well as identying the key areas where we need to make changes, we can look at not only the college itself but how we fit in to the wider plan, regionally and nationally.

title: eyemouth-man-involved-two-domestic-bust-ups-borders
story: A MAN involved in two domestic bust-ups within the space of a month has been ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Aleksandrs Kravcovs, , was abusive to the woman at a party in Eyemouth on Christmas Eve and then followed it up by assaulting her a month later.Describing the first incident Depute fiscal Alison Atkins said: "The accused attended at the locus with a number of people on the evening of Christmas Eve."People were consuming alcohol and in good spirits."However as the evening progressed the accused became aggressive and wanted to go home and take his young daughter with him.:lsquoMajor incidentrsquo stood down but number of roads still lsquoaffectedrsquo by flooding"A witness and his partner both said this was not a good idea due to his level of intoxication."This caused the accused to become even more aggressive and was shouting and swearing in an aggressive manner."He was prevented from entering the daughters bedroom and the police were contacted."In January the fish processing factory worker got involved in another argument with his partner which escalated and resulted in him slapping her face and seizing hold of her by her arms.Ms Atkins said: "She was knocked to the ground. An older child heard the disturbance and came to assist her mother."He was very distressed and emotional."The police were called and saw bruises on the complainers left arm and a blooded mouth.PHOTO GALLERY:Flooding in the Borders following amber rain warning"She was offered but declined any medical attention."Defence lawyer Colin Severin said his client had been in a relationship for  years and have five children together.He added Kravcovs had not come to the attention of the authorities since the second incident last January.Sherf Donald Corke admonished him on the Christmas Eve incident.But he said the second offence was more serious as it was an assault to injury..removeThe sherf imposed a Community Pay Back Order involving  hours unpaid work to be carried out over  months as an alternative to custody.After taking into account the partners views, Sherf Corke said a non-harassment order was not required.

title: mundell-back-duty-water-firms-reduce-river-sewage
story: PEEBLESSHIRErsquoS MP has said he will now back an amendment calling for a legal duty to be placed on water firms to reduce the amount of sewage that ends up in rivers.Last week David Mundell, who represents Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale for the Conservatives, voted with his party on an amendment of the Environment Bill which did not include a proposal from the House of Lords to put a duty on ldquosewerage undertakers to take all reasonable steps to ensure untreated sewage is not discharged from storm overflows into inland and coastal waters.However, the UK Government has now said it will write into law that firms will have to make a ldquoprogressive reduction to the amount of sewage discharged into UK rivers and waterways ndash something Mr Mundell says he will support.:lsquoHeavy and disruptiversquo rain could impact Peebles as fresh warning issuedldquoRather than by means of the Lordsrsquo amendment, the government is instead proposing to place a direct legal obligation on water companies to reduce the impact of sewage discharges, said Mr Mundell. ldquoThis obligation will put it into law that water companies make progressive reductions in the adverse impacts of discharges from storm overflows.ldquoWater companies will be obliged by law to show a reduction in sewage overspills over the next five years.Although the Scottish Government oversees environmental issues in Scotland, the River Tweed flows from the Borders into Northumberland.On Tuesdaythe House of Lords voted in favour of the amendment from the Duke of Wellington asking that a duty be put on ldquosewerage undertakers to take all reasonable steps to ensure untreated sewage is not discharged from storm overflows into inland and coastal waters.:Photo gallery: Flooding in the Borders following amber rain warningThe amendment requires water firms to ldquodemonstrate improvement in the performance of sewerage systems and ldquosecure progressive reductions in the harm caused by untreated sewage discharges into inland and coastal waters..removeThe Lords vote passed with  peers voting lsquocontentrsquo and  lsquonot contentsrsquo.The dukersquos amendment will now be debated by parliament at a later date.Amendment  of the Environment Bill means that the government will have to make a plan for how to tackle discharge from storm overflows by September , .The proposal made by the House of Lords which was not included in the amendment of the Environment Bill voted on last week asked that a duty be placed on ldquosewerage undertakers to take all reasonable steps to ensure untreated sewage is not discharged from storm overflows.:Spanish activists joined by Borderers on -mile trek to KelsoStorm overflows are designed to protect buildings from flooding during heavy rainfall.According to Surfers Against Sewage, across the UK untreated sewage was discharged into waterways , times last year.Mr Mundell added: ldquoWe all want to see action taken to protect our coastlines, waterways and rivers, including here in the Tweed valley where such a vital contribution is made to the le of the community.ldquoPlacing new legal obligations on water companies to reduce any impacts from discharges from storm overflows is the way to do it, and that approach will have my support.

title: borders-public-toilets-kept-open-council-u-turn
story: A NUMBER of public toilets set to close across the Borders will now be kept open following a U-turn by the council.Having reopened last month,  loos were due to shut again on October  with the local authority citing a lack of staffing and financial resources as reasons for being unable to keep them available.However, Scottish Borders Council says the  toilets will now remain open until the end of December.John Curry, SBCrsquos director for infrastructure and environment, said: ldquoA decision has been taken to extend the opening period of the  additional public toilet facilities that were reopened in September this year.ldquoOriginally these facilities were due to close on October , however this period has now been extended until the end of the year ndash December , .ldquoThis has been made possible by the reduction in cleansing requirements for the  facilities open since October .ldquoThis has freed up existing budget to allow these facilities to open for longer and be maintained to the required levels of cleanliness.The  toilets set to remain open are West Linton, Broughton, Earlston, St Boswells, Newtown St Boswells, Yetholm, Denholm, Chirnside, Greenlaw and Cockburnspath.Public facilities were closed in March last year following Scottish Government guidelines for battling coronavirus.On the toilet extension, Mr Curry added: ldquoAs we approach the winter months, COVID- still poses a serious threat to our communities and continues to remain a factor in how public facilities like toilets operate.ldquoWe have to remain extremely vigilant throughout this period to balance the needs of our communities against the precautions required to suppress the virus and will be keeping a close eye on the national statistics and adhering to any guidance from Scottish Government in relation to these facilities in the coming weeks.

title: black-history-month-lecturer-discovers-link-borders
story: ITS not everyday you find yourself on holiday and discover your name on the gates of your destination.However, this was the reality for Dr Melrose Stewart MBE when she visited the Borders recently.A physiotherapist and lecturer, Dr Stewart has worked as one of the experts on the multi award-winning Channel  series ldquoOld Peoplesrsquo home for  Year Olds.A black woman who was born in Jamaica and then moved to the UK when she was -years-old, she made the stop at her namesake, Melrose, while on holiday here in Scotland."It was absolutely wonderful," said Dr Stewart, "I think Melrose just set the scene, we arrived and it was a glorious day."I didnt know what to expect."It was absolutely beautul and I didnt expect to see my name on the entry to the town."But as well as enjoying the sunshine and the sights the area has to offer, Melrose had another reason to visit the town bearing her name ndash its connections with her ancestry.Dr Stewart added: "Id spoken to Sir Geoff Palmer [OBE, chancellor at Heriot-Watt University and human rights activist] ndash who is doing a lot of work in Scotland around the slave trade and the history of Jamaica and its connections with the slave trade. Id spoken with him a few times and he said Melrose has connections in Jamaica and Scotland."I wasnt too aware that there was a Melrose in Jamaica, but he said Melrose in the Borders is a lovely place to visit."Although she knows of no direct connection to the town ndash "I think my mother told me it was my sister who chose the name, I dont know where she got it from," ndash Melroseand Jamaica have a shared history.The local National Trust of Scotland attraction, Harmony House, will be known to many in the region.The house was built in  by Robert Waugh.Melrose said visiting Harmony House was a "seminal moment" in her trip, not only because of the link between Waugh and her name, but also how he profited from her ancestors..removeIn the s Waugh used the profits he brought back with him from Jamaica, where he owned lime and pimento plantations ndash named Melrose and Mount Nelson ndash and slaves, to build his home in the Borders and the nearby chain bridge.Waugh was also financially compensated when slavery was abolished."He had built this house out of profits made from my ancestors in Jamaica," said Dr Stewart.She added: "But all in all, in such a short period, the couple of hours we spent there [Melrose], there was just so much to capture about my history and for me it was well worth a visit."Dr Stewart explained that she has been able to look back on her history up to the late s."Its very dficult as a black person to begin to trace your ancestry because names changed, there was lots of cruelty and all the things going on in terms of how iniduals were treated."And this is the sort of history ndash which is painful for all of us from Jamaica because I really dont know where my journey started. It was probably the west coast of Africa. Im not sure who bought my ancestors, how they arrived ndash its just something I started touching the tip of the iceberg really."As October marks Black History Month in the UK, Dr Stewart hopes that by addressing the connections we all have to slavery and Britains colonising history, we can have more open and honest conversations about race.She said: "I think everyone needs to know their history ndash I wasnt taught it at school ndash I knew nothing about my name and its connections with Scotland when I was growing up as a child in England."I came here when I was  so all of my secondary schooling was done here and so all of the history I have learnt has been me finding out for myself."And obviously things have moved on a bit since then ndash not much."I dont think people really know how to manage it [discussions on slavery]."Because of the sensitivities, people probably think, I didnt do it, its the people that went before me that did that."We need to have those sorts of discussions because you might not be personally responsible, but it helps explain in depth why were in the position we are in now."The last  months during the coronavirus pandemic have been marked with a number of events where the topic of race has been very prevalent ndash namely the death of George Floyd in America in March , which sparked worldwide Black Lives Matter protests.In the UK this brought about conversations on how we view commemorative statues, plaques and other memorabilia to figures known to have profited from the slave trade.Some call for the figures to be removed from their literalpedestals.The statue of Edward Colston, a slave trader, was famously toppled and thrown into Bristol Harbour in June last year and a statue of Winston Churchill in London was also defaced last year.But others feel the statues could remainmore is done to make their connections to slavery clearer."We hope that by learning about the past we dont repeat these atrocities in the future," said Dr Stewart."We just want history to be told as it was.""We can make it [learning about the slave trade] really interesting for children in schools."There are lots of interesting ways in which the curriculum can be changed, and should be changed, the narrative made factual from dferent perspectives."Especially in places like Melrose where they probably can even connect with a school in Melrose in Jamaica."Making connections is something I would strongly encourage, for children to have the conversation so they can share stories."You can imagine how dferent the children in Melrose in Scotland are from the children in Melrose in Jamaica ndash yet theres this strong connection."

title: ticket-sales-going-well-borders-book-festival
story: TICKETS for this yearrsquos Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival are selling well with a number of shows already sold out and people are being advised to book early to avoid disappointment.The popular annual event which normally takes place in June at Harmony House in Melrose is being held at Abbotsford House between  -  November.A host of famous names are appearing including Alexander McCall Smith, Ian Rankin, former Prime Minister Gordon Brown and Hilary Mantel, winner of the th Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction for her book The Mirror and the Light.Also attending are crime writer Val McDermid, former politician Ed Balls, Labour MP Ed Miliband, rugby star Gavin Hastings, and travel writer Michael Palin.Discussions during the festival will also include Jonathan Dimbleby on how Hitler lost the war, political journalist Robert Peston on his new thriller The Whistleblower and Pat Nevin on his autobiography The Accidental Footballer.Festival Director Alistair Moffat told us: ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to it now. Itrsquos been such a long time. Irsquoll be opening the event interviewing Neil Oliver about his new book, The Story of the World in  Moments and Irsquom also really looking forward to interviewing Ed Balls about his book Appetite which is about how food conjures up of childhood, like your mumrsquos mince and tatties.ldquoBut there are so many great shows on offer and ticket sales are going well. Some are already sold out so I would advise people to get online and book although itrsquos worth pointing out that tickets are being sold at the box office on the day.ldquoThe Festival is taking place over six days this year rather than the normal four as we have strict Covid protocols in place which means limited spaces and a longer turn round between shows.ldquoItrsquos so good to be able to help Abbotsford, which is probably the most famous houses in the country celebrate the th anniversary of the birth of Sir Walker Scott but next year hopefully we will be back at Harmony House in June..removeThe Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival takes place at Abbotsford, Melrose, in the Scottish Borders, between nd-th November . The full programme and tickets are available at www.bordersbookfestival.org or by calling   .

title: netherurd-house-holiday-accommodation-plans-filed-sbc
story: PART of a Borders mansion which was previously used by Scottish Girl Guides may soon be available to holidaymakers.In August  it was announced that Netherurd House, near West Linton, was closing.Earlier this year, Scottish Borders Council approved plans for the -bedroom Georgian mansion to be made into a residential home.And now a proposal to turn the single storey wing to the north of the house ndash formerly used as a ldquoshop and adjacent staff sleeping accommodation ndash into a holiday retreat has been filed with the local authority.ldquoWe aim to undertake a series of sympathetic interventions to the existing building at Netherurd House, a report submitted by Jefcoate Anderson Architects Ltd on behalf of the owners states. ldquoThe property has a history of change with alterations to the plan,and elevation being able to be read, for the most part, in the buildingrsquos remaining structure.ldquoThese changes have been driven by the user requirements of the property and also of technological advances in building services.ldquoWe are keen to reinstate traditional details wherever possible and upgrade insulation and services to improve the environmental performance of the building.ldquoAllowing the conversion of the existing shop and staff sleeping accommodation to form a two-bedroom residential property suitable for holiday lets, will not only provide a revenue stream which will assist with future restoration works and upkeep at Netherurd House, but will also allow the history of people being able to visit this unique and beautul property to continue.Netherurd House ndash built between  and  ndash is situated .km away from West Linton and just over one kilometre from Blyth Bridge.The mansion was used by generations of Girl Guides as a holiday and training centre, before the coronavirus pandemic contributed to its closure.Among the changes proposed are to upgrade the existing insulation levels, and install a new kitchen and dining area in the existing shop.

title: another-successful-sale-peebles-auction-house
story: A RARE helmet has sold for more thanpound, at the Peebles Auction House.The Siebe Gorman  Co. coal mine rescue smoke helmet is thought to be from Monktonhall Colliery in Midlothian.The item was in excellent condition with a clean olive green leather finish.The mica  were both intact and free from cracks.Air would have been supplied through y hoses and provided by the rescue team outwith the mine by means of a foot pump.Monktonhall was one of the Scottish super pits sunk in the s intended to supply the new generation of power stations.It was sunk to a depth of  meters, making it one of the deepest mines in the country.In addition, on a successful day at the auction house, a  stamped gold charm bracelet sold for pound a mainly Victorian, Edward VII and early Georgian coin collection sold for pound a pair of antique red carsphairn granite curling stones sold for pound an oil on canvas lsquoHeading to Marketrsquo by David Cox sold for pound, a Laurence Broderick rearing Pegasus bronze statue sold for pound and an oil on canvas painting by Mary Armour sold for pound.

title: borders-house-prices-latest-government-figures-show-jump
story: THE Borders saw a . per cent jump in house prices in August, new figures show.The increase contributes to property prices in the region having the largest annual growth of any local authority in the UK, according to statistics from the Land Registry.The average house price in the Borders in August  was pound,.In August this year, the average price was pound, ndash a . per cent increase.A . per cent rise in August is signicantly higher than . per cent seen across Scotland, as well as the . per cent for the UK as a whole.

title: coronavirus-borders-recorded-40-new-cases-last-day
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There remain  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: massive-game-vale-raydale-park
story: VALE OF Leithen face arguably their biggest game in years this Saturday when they take on fellow Lowland League strugglers Gretna at Raydale Park.The Dumfries and Galloway side, who replaced manager Rowan Alexander with Stephen Hatfield last month, are currently six points ahead of Vale.New Vale head coach Grant Sandison is looking forward to the challenge after witnessing signs of encouragement against Edinburgh University in his first game in charge.After a string of heavy defeats, the club, with four new faces in the starting line-up, limited the students to three goals.But the Innerleithen side created a number of chances of their own and were unlucky to go in at half-time one goal down.Sandison told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoI was happy with the first-half performance against Edinburgh University."We set up to be organised and to stop conceding goals and I think we limited them to one shot before they scored from a direct free kick just before half-time. We created two or three good chances but in the second half we conceded early from a mistake and then ran out of steam but overall I was happy with the performance.ldquoWe had four players making their debut, Andrew Mackay, Ben Viola and Lewis Grahame who all signed from Penicuik and Ben Brady, who had just been released by St Mirren played as a trialist.ldquoBenpicked up an injury the second-half and had to go off. Hersquos had issues with his ankle all season and went over on it. He didnrsquot train on Monday night, so wersquoll see how he is for Saturday.ldquoWe have another three players lined up that we like the look of but whether they will be signed and available for Saturday, I donrsquot know right now. Hopefully one or two may be able to play.ldquoSaturday will be a massive game for the club. The Edinburgh Uni and Gretna games probably came a bit too early for us."It would have been betterwersquod had three or four weeks with the players first, but it is what it is. I watched Gretnarsquos Scottish Cup game against Berwick Rangers and have received some reports on them but they have a new manager so their style of play may have changed..removeldquoBut Irsquove been delighted with the response of the players so far. There has been a good reaction and there was a real enthusiasm in training. I am really looking forward to the game and it would be great to claw back some points to bring back up the road.

title: peebles-community-trust-forum-help-future-town
story: PEEBLES residents are invited to stake a claim for the future at an Open Forum at the Burgh Hall on Saturday, November .The forum offers locals the chance to help take ownership of the future of the town by helping to update the Town Action Plan.And residents will be able to catch up with the Ideas Map of Peebles, developed through the Community Land Scotland as a stimulus to debate on the way ahead.The event has been organised by Peebles Community Trustin partnership with Peebles Community Council and the townrsquos Civic Society, who joined forces to produce the original Action Plan in .:lsquoHeavy and disruptiversquo rain could impact Peebles as fresh warning issuedAlex Wilson, administrator for PCT, said it is an opportunity for people to have their say on the work of the trust, to speak with those involved in its operations, and find out how to join in any of the trustrsquos projects.ldquoPCT is all about owning our future, and we want the community to come along and find out more about the main issues affecting our town, both from the point of view of local developments and the wider perspective of Scottish government policies, said Ms Wilson.ldquoWe want as many people as possible to engage with the work we are doing and help us to get it right.Projects run by the trust include the refurbishment of the School Brae Hub , Eshiels Community Wood, the Railway Heritage Project, and the Tweeddale Re-Use Hub.:International PPE Company founded by Peebles man sponsors local jockeyThe PCT also acts as an administrative umbrella for March Street Allotment Holders Association, Bonnie Peebles Plus, Cycling Without Age, the Multi-use paths ndash Peebles to Cardrona and Peebles to Leadburn ndash Peebles Salmon Angling Club Glebe Assisted Gardening, Keep Peebles Clean, BEG , Peeblesshire Paths group and Bonnie Peebles.The Open Forum will feature an exhibition on recent and projected developments in the town. People in attendance will be invited to comment and ask questions. Active volunteers from the trust, community council and civic society will also be there..removeCrick Carleton, co-author of Peeblesrsquo Town Action Plan, said there had been some notable successes in the five years since the plan was published, including the establishment of the community trust.He said: ldquoThe first Town Action Plan was an important summary of local opinion and aspiration that aimed to advise decision-makers at every level and one-third of priority actions it outlines have been achieved, along with signicant progress on most of the other actions.ldquoWe are now developing our second plan, and topics of particular interest are likely to be jobs, housing and wellbeing, getting around town, the multi-use paths to the east and north of town, and the future of the March Street Mills site.:Man was involved in two domestic bust-ups in the Borders within space of a monthThe Action Plan is an important grassroots initiative in line with the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Empowerment programme.It will also feed into the new Regional Economic Partnership .The government says REPs can bring together regional interests, focus on, and align, resources, share knowledge, and identy new joined-up plans to accelerate inclusive economic growth at a local, regional, and national level.The Ideas Map of Peebles was developed in association with a creative practitioner as part of a project by led by Community Land Scotland in six communities: Coigach Community Development Company in Wester Ross, Kinning Park Complex in Glasgow, South West Mull and Iona Development, Urras Oighreachd Ghabhsainnin Lewis and Viewpark Conservation Group in North Lanarkshire.The Open Forum will be held at the Burgh Hall on Saturday, November ,am-pm. You can contact the trust on the website www.peeblescommunity.org or by email on admin@peeblescommunity.org

title: biggar-museum-shares-local-history-1900-albion-dogcart
story: ONE of Scotlandrsquos earliest motorcars has ed to its first home in Biggar.In March last year Biggar and Upper Clydesdale Museum acquired a  Albion Dogcart ndash one of the first models produced by the Albion Motor Car Company in the early th century.However, due to the coronavirus pandemic, the car has only now gone on display at the venue, where its strong connections with the town are also highlighted.:lsquoHeavy and disruptiversquo rain could impact parts of Borders as fresh alert issuedElaine Edwards, manager curator of the Biggar and Upper Clydesdale Museum said: ldquoThis is an iconic vehicle which fits perfectly into the part of our museum where we have reconstructed street scenes of Victorian and Edwardian shops and businesses which once served Biggar so well: the apothecary, bootmaker, printer, dressmaker, clockmaker and telephone exchange for example.ldquoIt is the icing on the cake. Its arrival has generated enormous enthusiasm in the town and amongst Albion enthusiasts.ldquoWe can anticipate a wave of visits from those who visit Biggar on an annual basis to attend the Albion Vintage Car Rally.:Photo gallery: Flooding in the Borders following amber rain warningThe model now on display in the museum was first owned by John Lamb Murray, an architect who lived near the town.When owned by the Murray family, the Dogcart was driven by John Lawson.Mr Murrayrsquos son, Thomas Blackwood Murray co-founded the Albion Motor Car Company in  with his brother-in-law Norman Fulton.:International PPE Company founded by Peebles man sponsors local jockeyJohn Murray owned the Albion until  when he sold it. By  the car was housed at the Motor Museum in London where it remained until  when the collection was dispersed.The Albion was then gted to the National Museums Scotland .The Albion has been loaned to the Biggar and Upper Clydesdale Museum by the National Museums Scotland, where it had undergone a series of restoration works including corrosion removal, leather upholstery was repaired, and paintwork was retouched..remove:Peeblesshire MP to support duty on water firms to reduce sewage in UK riversA total of  hours were spent restoring the Albion Dogcart.Meredith Greiling, senior curator of transport at the National Museums Scotland, said: ldquoThe Albion Dogcart is one of the most important vehicles in the national collection.ldquoWe are delighted to have conserved it to a condition where it can be displayed and wersquore particularly pleased to be bringing it lsquohomersquo to Biggar where its first owner came from.Ms Edwards added: ldquoWe are very appreciative of all the work carried out by National Museums Scotland in conserving the car and lending it to us, and also the support of local engineering company James A. Cuthbertson of Biggar Ltd in helping to bring this project to fruition.

title: aldi-lidl-middle-aisles-kitchen-toy-deals-weekend
story: This article contains affiliate links. Newsquest may receive a commission on any sales generated from them.Aldiand Lidlhave announced a range of new items that you can pick up in the middle aisles of their stores this weekend.If yoursquore just popping in for milk and sugar, be prepared to walk out with bags of bargains as the supermarkets are stocking everything from kitchen appliances to kids toys.Update your kitchen and get some Christmas gts ticked off early this weekend at Aldiand Lidl.Weve rounded-up some of the highlights to look out for in each supermarket.AldiHalloween is over soon which means it is time to start thinking about Christmas. title: ednam-pensioner-admits-involved-domestic-disturbance
story: A PENSIONER appeared in private at Jedburgh Sherf Court on Friday and admitted being involved in a domestic disturbance with his long-term partner.Seventy-three-year-old Kenneth Cooper pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner at a house in the village of Ednam on Thursday.Sentence was deferred until next month for the production of background reports.Cooper, who gave an address in Galashiels, was released on bail.You might also be interested in:High Street parking issue in Borders town lsquodriving customers awayrsquo, meeting hearsRare coal mine smoke rescue helmet sells for more than pound,at Borders auctionPlans submitted to turn part of Borders mansioninto holiday accommodation

title: phenomenal-line-up-first-class-speakers-coming-borders
story: THE HOME of Sir Walter Scott opens its doors tomorrowto the Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival, bringing together a host of big names from politics, sport, history, crime and current affairs in more than  live events over six days.The Book Festival kicks off in style with a stellar line-up: Ed Balls sharing his very personal Appetite: A Memoir in Recipes of Family and Food acclaimed author of Rose Nicolson, Andrew Greig sports giants Tom English, Jim Telfer and Finlay Calder reliving the  British and Irish Lions tour of South Africa festival favourites Neil Oliver and Richard Holloway sharing their most recent works, The Story of the World in  Moments, and The Heart of Things and the BBCrsquos Gavin Esler challenging festivalgoers to consider the rise of nationalism south of the border in the FTWeekend event, Itrsquos About English, Stupid.Alistair Moffat, Festival Director, said: ldquoPutting a book festival together during a pandemic is no easy task, but we have got the most phenomenal line-up of first-class speakers and cannot wait to get our audiences along to beautul Abbotsford to give them a thoroughly intoxicating reintroduction to the live book events we have all missed so much. And of course, safety remains our key priority, so our extended -day extravaganza allows us to adhere to all Government Covid- guidelines without detracting from the sense of occasion and excitement at our .ldquoAs always, we are bringing to the Borders stars from the worlds of politics, sport, history, crime writing, acclaimed literature and current affairs. And the venue this year seems particularly fitting, given the th celebrations of Sir Walter Scott, our countryrsquos greatest-ever storyteller.ldquoIrsquom beyond excited at the prospect of six days of immersion in great writing, in all its forms, and scintillating, inspiring debate -- in person!Political highlights include: Ed Miliband with his Go Big: How To Fix Our World former Prime Minister Gordon Brown on his manesto to change the world Robert Peston, straight from the Cop summit in Glasgow a unique record of history as it was made in Downing Street from Theresa Mayrsquos Chief of Staff, Gavin Barwell and the inimitable James Naughtie with his annual political round-up ..removeFor history and crime enthusiasts: Jonathan Dimbleby discusses his Barbarossa: How Hitler Lost the War Booker Prize winner, and this yearrsquos winner of the prestigious Walter Scott Prize For Historical Fiction, Hilary Mantel, makes a very special festival visit with The Mirror and the Light and crime-writing royalty Denise Mina, Ian Rankin, Ambrose Parry and Val McDermid talk about their latest novels.Sports fans have plenty to enjoy with footballing legend Pat Nevin, on his memoir The Accidental Footballer one of Scotlandrsquos finest rugby players Gavin Hastings Rory Bremner sharing classic moments of sporting commentary with his indomitable take on the likes of John Motson, Murray Walker, Peter Allis and of course Geoffrey Boycott and for something entirely dferent, Finlay Wilson with his Wild Kilted Yoga.This year, foodies can feast their ears on Great British Bake Off winner Peter Sawkins and Suzanne Mulholland, The Batch Lady, with her new and delicious ways to cook wholesome, homely food in bulk ndash perfect for an autumnal day in the Borders!Michelle McLeod, Sponsorship Manager at Baillie Gford, said: ldquoIt is fantastic to be back to live events, all in the grounds of stunning Abbotsford. The festival team have worked tirelessly to deliver this yearrsquos programme. Come along and enjoy everything the festival has to offer, including an incredible iety of events and an opportunity to hear from some of our most treasured writers.Giles Ingram, Abbotsford CEO, said: ldquoWhat a fantastic line up of authors and public figures spanning current affairs, sports, food and more, as well as my favourite theme, historical fiction. We are delighted that the Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival has chosen Abbotsford as their venue during the th anniversary year of Sir Walter Scott. Do make sure you take time to savour Scottrsquos study, where the great man sat at his desk for countless hours with quill pen in hand, dreaming up stories which still stir the imaginations of readers today. With such celebrated writers visiting us for the Book Festival, one can only imagine how excited Scott would be were he alive and at home today!The McInroy and Wood Lecture will this year feature Dailyjournalist Joe Shute exploring how, where and why our weather is changing and delivering a timely and important forecast for us all, in his Diary of the Lost Seasons.The book festival is delighted to welcome the Financial Times as its new media partner, and this yearrsquos festival programme will include FTWeekend events addressing some of the biggest political and economic issues of the day ndash Afghanistan, defining Scottishness and Englishness, and the question of a Scottish sovereign currency ndash with some of the brightest minds from the worlds of journalism, politics, economics, diplomacy and academia including Gavin Esler, Ailsa Henderson, Sebastian Payne and Sir John Kay. Lionel Barber, former editor of the Financial Times, will replace Tom Tugendhat MP, who is, unfortunately, unable to attend in-person.The weekendsees theof the always-popular Family Book Festival, sponsored by Saltire Roofing  Building, and including: Kristina Stephenson and her Museum of Marvellous Things Alan Windram and his latest One Button Benny adventure a relaxing colouring session with Eilidh Muldoon Blue Peter Award-winning Pamela Butchart with A Monster Ate My Packed Lunch! and a series of outdoor exploration events at Abbotsford, taking inspiration from Sir Walter Scott himself and his beautul home.Adults get to go free to any Family Book Festival event so long as they are accompanied by at least one child!The book festival welcomes the continued support of Title Sponsor Baillie Gford and Key Sponsor McInroy  Wood, as well as Cullen Kilshaw, Saltire Roofing  Building Ltd, Davidson Chalmers Stewart, DM Hall, and the on-going funding of Scottish Borders Council, Creative Scotland, Culture  Business Fund Scotland and EventScotland .Paul Bush OBE, Director of Events for VisitScotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to support the Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival through Scotlandrsquos Events Recovery Fund, established by EventScotland in conjunction with funding from the Scottish Government.This -day festival, brimming with over  events, features high-profile and wide-ranging literary talent from all walks of le. The venue, Abbotsford, the home of Sir Walter Scott, is the perfect stage for this yearrsquos festival, making it even more special and celebratory for the th anniversary of Scotlandrsquos most renowned novelist.Tickets for this yearrsquos Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival are available via Citizen Ticket, at www.bordersbookfestival.org or on   .

title: queen-calls-world-leaders-work-together-tackle-climate-change
story: The Queen has issued a rallying cry to world leaders attending Cop urging them to work together in ldquocommon cause to tackle climate change and ldquosolve the most insurmountable problems.In a video message played during a welcoming reception for presidents and prime ministers, she hoped the summitrsquos legacy would be that they recognised ldquothe time for words has now moved to the time for action.The Queen paid a heartfelt tribute to ldquomy dear late husband the Duke of Edinburgh for his environmental awareness in raising the issue more than  years ago.In a rare public expression of emotion, the monarch said it was a ldquosource of great pride the important role he played in encouraging people to look after the natural world, and she ldquocould not be more proud of the Prince of Wales and Duke of Cambridge who have continued his work.Acknowledging her own mortality, the Queen, whose health has caused concern after she decided not to attend the Glasgow conference when advised by doctors to rest, said not all would benefit from the leadersrsquo actions as ldquonone of us will live forever.But any determination to confront the planetrsquos environmental problems would benefit ldquoour childrenrsquos children.Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge listened to her message which was recorded on Friday at Windsor Castle.vw,vw,px, px"The Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall watching as the Queen makes a video message The Queen said: ldquoIn the coming days, the world has the chance to join in the shared objective of creating a safer, stabler future for our people and for the planet on which we depend.ldquoNone of us underestimates the challenges ahead: but history has shown that when nations come together in common cause, there is always room for hope. Working side by side, we have the ability to solve the most insurmountable problems and to triumph over the greatest of adversities..removeThe head of state added: ldquoI, for one, hope that this conference will be one of those rare occasions where everyone will have the chance to rise above the politics of the moment, and achieve true statesmanship.ldquoIt is the hope of many that the legacy of this summit ndash written in history books yet to be printed ndash will describe you as the leaders who did not pass up the opportunity and that you answered the call of those future generations.ldquoThat you left this conference as a community of nations with a determination, a desire, and a plan, to address the impact of climate change and to recognise that the time for words has now moved to the time for action.vw,vw,px, px"In her video message, the Queen stressed how Philip had been such a keen environmentalist .Philip was an environmentalist before the word came into common use and he championed the natural world long before it was fashionable.He was president of the WWF ndash World Wildle Fund ndash from  to  and famously drove an eco-friendly taxi around the streets of London decades before green vehicles were more widely used.The Queen wore a butterfly brooch as she spoke, seated in front of a photograph of Philip admiring butterflies in Mexico in .vw,vw,px, px"A photograph of her late husband during a visit to Mexico in  was on display during the Queenrsquos video message In her message the Queen said she was happy to welcome the delegates as the ldquoimpact of the environment on human progress was a subject close to Philiprsquos heart.She added: ldquoI remember well that in , he told an academic gathering: lsquoIf the world pollution situation is not critical at the moment, it is as certain as anything can be, that the situation will become increasingly intolerable within a very short timehellip If we fail to cope with this challenge, all the other problems will pale into insignicance.rsquoldquoIt is a source of great pride to me that the leading role my husband played in encouraging people to protect our fragile planet, lives on through the work of our eldest son Charles and his eldest son William. I could not be more proud of them.vw,vw,px, px"The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge during the first Earthshot Prize awards ceremony at Alexandra Palace in LondonWilliam recently held the inaugural prize-giving ceremony for his environmental Earthshot Prize which aims to find solutions to the worldrsquos problems like providing clean air or clearing plastics from the sea.While Charles has spent much of his adult le highlighting the threat posed to the environment by human activity and trying to mitigate it.Teenage activist Greta Thunberg who galvanised a generation of young people across the globe with her climate change strikes joined youth climate protests outside the ldquoblue zone where the leaders were meeting.The Queen added: ldquohellipI have drawn great comfort and inspiration from the relentless enthusiasm of people of all ages ndash especially the young ndash in calling for everyone to play their part..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: The Queen calls for world leaders to work together to tackle climate change

title: countries-make-commitments-deforestation-methane-emissions-cop26
story: Countries are outlining commitments to curb deforestation and cut methane emissions at Cop as part of efforts to drive efforts to tackle the climate crisis.The announcements come after the Queen issued a rallying cry to world leaders attending Cop urging them to work together in ldquocommon cause to tackle climate change and ldquosolve the most insurmountable problems.In a video message played during a welcoming reception for presidents and prime ministers, she hoped the summitrsquos legacy would be that they recognised ldquothe time for words has now moved to the time for action.More than  world leaders will sign up to a landmark agreement to protect and restore the Earthrsquos forests, the UK Government has said.On the second day of the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow on Tuesday, leaders covering % of the worldrsquos forests will commit to halt and reverse deforestation and land degradation by .Downing Street said the pledges were backed by pound. billion of public funding with a further pound. billion in private investment.The commitment, to be formally announced at an event convened by Boris Johnson, has been welcomed by campaigners and experts, in particular the recognition of the role of indigenous people in protecting forests.The Prime Minister is expected to say: ldquoThese great teeming ecosystems, these cathedrals of nature, are the lungs of our planet.ldquoForests support communities, livelihoods and food supply, and absorb the carbon we pump into the atmosphere.ldquoThey are essential to our very survival.ldquoWith todayrsquos unprecedented pledges, we will have a chance to end humanityrsquos long history as naturersquos conqueror, and instead become its custodian." data-title"Autumn weather Oct th " data--holder"PA Wire" data--notice"PA Wire PA Images" data-credit"Andrew Matthews" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"The New Forest Meanwhile the US and EU are launching an initiative that aims at driving globalefforts to cut emissions of methane, a powerful but relatively short-lived greenhouse gas which comes from sources including fossil fuel extraction and livestock farming, as a signicant short-term contribution to climate action..removeDozens of heads of state will take part in the launch of the pledge, which commits countries to cut their emissions of the gas by % by .The announcements are part of efforts at Cop in a range of sectors,characterised by Mr Johnson as ldquocoal, cars, cash and trees,to drive momentum on reducing missions, alongside national plans by countries to cut climate-warming pollution in the next decade.Current national action plans to curb emissions leave the world way off track to meet global goals to keep temperature rises to ldquowell below C above pre-industrial levels and to aim for a less dangerous .C limit.Countries at Cop are under pressure to keep the .C goal in reach, deliver on climate finance to support poorer nations tackle the crisis, and finalise parts of the global Paris climate treaty.Cop will not close the gap between the action needed and what countries have promised, even with countries such as India bringing forward new commitments on the first day of the talks, so there will also be a push to negotiate a road map to increasing ambition in the next decade..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Countries to make commitments on deforestation and methane emissions at Cop

title: teleconsultations-doctors-worse-convenient-study-shows
story: Phone or video consultations with doctors are ldquoworse but more convenient than face-to-face appointments, according to a new study.Rheumatology patients perceived so-called telemedicine as to have ldquoincreased misdiagnoses, inequalities and barriers to accessing care.But more than % found them ldquomore convenient, according to a new analysis of telemedicine, led by researchers at the University of Cambridge.Researchers surveyed , patients, the majority of whom had inflammatory arthritis or lupus.They also polled more than  clinicians between April and July.Some of the findings, published in the journal Rheumatology, included:ndash Nine out of  medics and % of patients felt telemedicine was ldquoworse than face-to-face for building a trusting relationship.ndash Many patients felt that phone or video consultations followed an impersonal ldquotick list and felt more ldquorushed.ndash Patients and medics both said that video and phone consultations were worse than face-to-face appointments in terms of ldquoaccuracy of assessment.ndash But more than six out of  patients and doctors said telemedicine was ldquomore convenient, citing reduced waiting times, no travelling, and safety from infection as the main advantages.ndash Some doctors said that NHS technology was ldquoembarrassingly primitive for delivering telemedicine, though others cited improvements which were implemented as a result of the pandemic.ndash Telemedicine could lead to inequalities in treatment for people who had hearing, cognitive or speech dficulties and for those whose first language was not English, among others, the authors said.ndash Researchers also said that concerns were expressed that telemedicine would be ldquoover-used by NHS and hospital management as a cost and time-saving measure rather than in patientsrsquo best interests.ndash Only % of clinicians felt telemedicine was overall better than face-to-face.New measures will help GP practices improve availability so that patients who need care can get it and boost GP capacity to increase the proportion of face to face appointments. A big thank you to everyone who shared their experience of GP access with us. https:t.co bpqPPhkQJImdash Healthwatch EnglandOctober , .removeThe authors wrote: ldquoThe findings identied a place for telemedicine for certain patients, yet a strong overall preference for face-to-face consultations from both clinicians and patients.Melanie Sloan, lead author from the Primary Care Unit at the University of Cambridge, said: ldquoThe pandemic has had a major impact on the ability of healthcare professionals to see their patients face-to-face, and this has led to a signicant increase in the number of telemedicine consultations.ldquoAs the NHS develops a telemedicine strategy, we hope there will be a thorough assessment of the clinical and psychological risks and steps taken to mitigate those risks, as well as action to address the possibility of worsening existing health inequalities for those less likely to be able to benefit from remote consultations.Co-author, Professor Caroline Gordon, from the University of Birmingham, added: ldquoSome stable rheumatic disease patients can benefit from telemedicine but new patients, those with worsening symptoms or more complex conditions such as lupus, need quickly accessible, face-to face appointments to manage their conditions.Senior author, Dr Felix Naughton from the University of East Anglia, added: ldquoOf greatest concern was the great iability in accessibility to care.ldquoApproximately half of all patients felt they would not receive a prompt response when very unwell, often citing increased barriers due to some remote contact and administrative systems that are not yet efficient enough to cope with the sudden move towards telemedicine.The rise in teleconsultations throughout the pandemic has become an intense topic of debate in medical communities.Some patients have expressed preference for face-to-face appointments but others have been exasperated at not being able to see doctors when requested.The issue has been particularly fraught in GP surgeries and the NHS has mandated that patients are able to see a GP in personthey choose, and has threatened to publish league tables of practices which are offering the fewest in-person appointments.But the British Medical Association has rejected the ldquoaccess plan and said it proposes to ballot the profession on industrial action.Data published last week show some % of appointments in September were in-person. Before the pandemic this figure was about %..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Teleconsultations with doctors are  uworse but more convenient u, study shows

title: turning-70-can-double-price-travel-insurance-says
story: Turning  can double the price of travel insurance evensomeone is healthy, according to Which Policies can be markedly more expensive and harder to find once customers pass , eventhey are in good health, the consumer group said.Which  looked at common barriers to finding affordable cover, gathering the experiences of some members in the past two years.Medical conditions and age were most commonly identied as the source of problems and travel insurance was the most common problem area.In separate mystery shopping research, Which  searched for quotes for customers in perfect health buying an annual European policy, using a comparison website in September.It found that once a customer reached , they had fewer quotes to choose from and the average price of the cheapest five nearly doubled, compared with customers aged .The average of the cheapest five quotes offered to a -year-old was pound and for a -year-old this nearly doubled to pound.Posing as a -year-old travel insurance customer, Which  got  quotes, falling to just seven for an -year-old.One Which  member said declaring his wersquos irregular heartbeat resulted in ldquoeither a refusal to insure or astronomical premiums for the couplersquos annual worldwide cover ndash with one insurer quoting as much as pound,.Older, more experienced drivers are often rewarded with cheaper car insurance, butthis tends to creep up again after drivers pass their mid-s, Which  said.One Which  member, aged , was surprised to be offered quotes ranging from pound to pound, for car insurance.They said: ldquoI still run, jump in rivers and chase salmon, and run stables and horses. Itrsquos annoying to discover that at this age yoursquore deemed incapable of even driving.Which  said many specialist insurers and brokers, and even some mainstream providers, may be able to help customers struggling to find affordable deals on comparison websites..removeAnother port of call is the British Insurance Brokersrsquo Association , which helps people find specialist brokers through the ldquofind insurance service on its website.Jenny Ross, Which  Money editor, said: ldquoIf you struggle to get insurance because of medical conditions or your age, there are some resources that can help you locate specialist insurers that lie off the beaten track of comparison websites.ldquoIf therersquos relevant context to your history or circumstances that you canrsquot communicate on an online form ndash or yoursquore unsure how to accurately fill one out ndash contact the insurer directly by phone or email to speak with a human being.Sarah Brodie, senior policy adviser, general insurance at the Association of British Insurers , said: ldquoTravel insurers aim to offer competitively priced travel insurance to as many travellers as possible.ldquoThe cost of travel insurance will reflect a number of factors, including your age and travel destination.ldquoThe older you are, oryou have a pre-existing medical condition, the more likely you are to need to claim for what can be jaw-droppingly expensive overseas emergency medical treatment costs.ldquoTravel insurance remains competitively priced, so it can pay to shop around, always making sure that you buy the policy most suited to your needs, not simply on price, and that you answer all questions, especially on any pre-existing medical conditions, fully and honestly..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Turning  can double the price of travel insurance, says Which

title: winter-solstice-shortest-day-year-2021
story: As the winter months roll in, the nights are drawing longer and the days shorter - meaning thewinter solstice is just around the corner.The winter solstice marks the shortest day of the year in the UK when we have the fewest hours of daylight.The good newsis that after its over, the days continuously get longer until the summer solstice in June.Heres what you need to know about the shortest day in the UK in ...When is the winter solstice in  The winter solstice will take place on Tuesday December  .During this day, the northern hemisphere will only see around hours  minutes of daylight.Why does the winter solstice happen The winter solstice occurs in the UK when the north pole reaches its maximum tilt away from the sun.While it only happens once a year in the UK, it happens twice a year across the globe, once in the northern hemisphere and once in the southern hemisphere.The term winter solstice actually refers to the exact moment the earth is tilted furthest away from the sun, however it is also sometimes used to describe the day this occurs.During the winter solstice in the northern hemisphere, the further north you travelthe darker it will be.On December  , the north pole will remain dark for the entire day.From this day onwards, the days will gradually grow longer until the summer solstice six months later, following which the days will again begin to shorten.When is summer solstice The next summer solstice will take place on Tuesday June   in the northern hemisphere, marking the longest day of the year.Summer solstice is when the earth is tilted closest to the sun and is the opposite of the winter solstice.

title: scottish-fish-shops-need-visit-britains-best-revealed
