title: galleries-art-trying-save-planet
story: Therersquos a strong contingent across all these from the indigenous communities around the world whose lives are strongly impacted by climate destructive activities. In amongst all the pomp of world leaders, this is a reminder of the importance of the local in the fight for the global.Occupying a vacant space on the river front, it will act as a large collaborative venue for ious art events related to COP and social justice and climate movements, from film screenings to banner-making workshops and large scale installations, all in the hopes of encouraging action.Whilst there are a number of art installations, the most widely seen will be conceptual artist Robert Montgomeryrsquos large scale light poem ldquoGrace of the Sun, some  metres x  metres, which will be launched later today. Montgomery, with the help of local community arts organisations, has constructed it from ldquoLittle Sun solar lamps, which were originally designed by artist Olafur Eliasson ndash who many will know for his Weather Project at Tate Modern in  ndash and engineer Frederik Etteson as a lamp which can be distributed to off-grid communities to bring a bright, free light source to people and places which have no easy access to power.Montgomeryrsquos poem should shine brightly for roughly five hours after sunset,all goes as per the ldquoLittle Sun instructions, after which it may glow more subtly through the night, and should very much be worth a visit.At the other end of the spectrum, there is Katy Dyersquos Climate Grief Karaoke on th November, which the artist herself describes as ldquoa lsquopublic servicersquo for people experiencing Ecological Grief to express dficult emotions via the medium of cheesy pop. There must surely be a market.Perhaps more seriously, at least on the surface, is the architectural strand in the Landing Hub programming, which has a number of interesting talks and installations on sustainable building for the future, whether in Glasgow itself or, as per Paris-based Jakob+MacFarlane architects and artist Uili Louisirsquos somewhat eye-popping floating city in their project Tongabove, designed to raise the Tongan capital above the rising Pacic sea waters.In Brazil, it is not so much the water as the trees that are the issue, as the devastating deforestation that is occurring under Jair Bolsonaro continues apace, taking with it people and villages and ways of le. On th November, artists and ldquoland defenders from ious countries including Brazil, Cambodia, and the UK, take over the Landing Hub courtesy of Brightonrsquos ONCA Gallery for a series of films and talks on the direct experience of environmental and cultural destruction in those countries. And on Friday  November, representatives from the Xingu river area in the Amazon, including filmmaker Takuma Kuikuro, will stage a one-day Indigenous Occupation, in tandem with Peoplersquos Palace Projects, which includes a fascinating-sounding workshop on the Karib language by singer Yamalui Kuikuro ndash a language which is spoken in just six villages in a specic area of Xingundash and a showcase of Takumarsquos films.Kuikuro has been documenting his peoplersquos potentially endangered way of le in this area of the Amazon, despite their robust history in evading colonial powers, for the past decade, the works intimate and observational, gently humorous in places.Films such as The Day the Moon Menstruated and The Hyperwomen chart the Xingu stories and rituals, songs and dances, and a way of le that remains in harmony with nature. And you canrsquot help thinking, too, having watched some of Kuikurorsquos films, that the environmentally friendly Passivhaus which features where in the Landing Hub spaces, along with other innovative building structures, cannot hold a candle to the impressive, thatched and environmentally-at-one structures of the Xingu people of the Amazon.The Landing Hub,  Broomielaw, Glagow, www.thesustainableglasgowlanding thelandinghub Until  Nov, Opening times y throughout run, from am ndash pm, and pm on weekends . Entry freeCritics ChoiceSpeaking as someone who has an unwitting ability to time west coast holidays with major international naval operations, I feel some embedded interest in Alex Boyds absorbing and evocative collection of photographs at Stills. A reckoning of the military use that makes up a fair portion of our rural landscape ndash the bit thats not concerned with grouse and cocker spaniels ndash Tir an Airmis a stark and at times intimate portrait of a largely unseen world beyond those somewhat terrying red flags, a journey to the parts where walkers fear to tread. This is a land of big skies, big landscapes, big guns.It all might be so peaceful, on the surface. And yet here they are, dummy churches and dummy insurgents scattered about the dips and gullies, air reconnaissance targets and the wrecks of tanks littering the open expanses from Cape Wrath to Sgribhis Bheinn and roads south, parked on the edge of the land as target practice for warships, or abandoned in a spot of otherwise pristine peat bog. All around, the echoes of past lives, the relentlessness of the human potential for aggression and natures patience. For this is what perhaps interests Boyd, in the end, the meeting point between nature and human, our destructive war play bound to finish - repeated generation on generation - in an old infantry target, mown down, grass growing through the bullet holes. Nature reclaims, in the end, although not always in the way she began.Alex Boyd: Tir an Airm , Stills Centre for Photography,  Cockburn Street, Edinburgh,    www.stills.org Until  Nov TuemdashSat, pmmdashpmDont MissThe National Museum of Scotland investigates themes related to COP  this Autumn with three small exhibitions, from Luke Jerrams Extinction Bell, which rings out up to  times a day in the Grand Hall to mark when a species has been lost forever, to an immersive installation by Edinburgh collective "And If Not Now, When" showing how we can affect our environment, ideally for the better. Here, too, a small exhibition on work being done by ious organisations in Scotland on technological innovations to fight climate change.National Museum of Scotland, Chambers Street, Edinburgh,   www.nms.ac.uk And If Not Now, When  - Nov other exhibitions until Spring , Daily am - pm

title: spirited-conversation-atheist-scotlands-top-ghost-hunter
story: MALCOLM Robinson is sitting in his study with a portrait of a saucer-eyed alien staring down at him. He is recounting his greatest adventures with ghosts: there is the spectre in Stirling who gave him a slap, the spook who kicked him, and the spirit from Kirkintilloch who pulled his hair. And thatrsquos before he even gets to the Clackmannanshire poltergeist ndash- an ldquoentity he is still hunting.It is Halloween sothere is ever a time to indulge that most marvellous of species ndash the great British eccentric ndash itrsquos today: the spookiest, silliest, strangest season of all.Robinson is Scotlandrsquos most famous paranormal researcher. You may not have heard of him, but thousands around the planet have ndash he has travelled the world giving lectures about ETs and ghosts, Nessie and demons, and written a slew of books on weird phenomena.You donrsquot have to believe what Robinson says ndash I certainly donrsquot, Irsquom an atheist and sceptic ndash but hersquos fascinating company, andlike me yoursquore curious about why so many of us obsess on the paranormal then he is the man to talk to. After all, half the planet has probably had at least one odd experience they canrsquot quite explain.I have interviewed a fair number of paranormalists over the years and while I donrsquot buy into their claims at all, Irsquove always thought most truly believed what they are saying. In other words ndash charlatans aside ndash these people seem well intentioned and not deliberately lying, even though their claims are  to many.Someone can be genuinely convinced they have seen a ghost ndash even though there is no such thing as ghosts. I donrsquot view Robinson as a charlatan or a liar ndash I view him as a pretty decent guy who really believes what he says, despite folk like me viewing his claims as fundamentally impossible. Itrsquos a neat little paradox, given wersquore talking about the paranormal.Obviously, millions of people around the world would disagree with me ndash those who believe in ghosts and UFOs ndash and see Robinson as an important researcher in a much-mocked field.Anyway, whether you believe in the paranormal or not, itrsquos Halloween so letrsquos give him a hearing at least.Birth of an obsessionROBINSON says he started out as a sceptic and there are still some signs of healthy scepticism alive in him today. ldquoIrsquod like to impress this upon people, he says.ldquoWe laughed at John Logie Baird and said his invention [television] would never work ndashit did. We laughed at the Wright Brothers, saying lsquoitrsquoll never flyrsquo. Just because something sounds ridiculous doesnrsquot mean it is so. Mankind has much to learn, wersquore at the bottom rung of understanding.ldquoHowever, itrsquos quite right in these times that we question everything, but donrsquot turn your head away just because something sounds ridiculous.As a kid in the s, Robinson was fascinated by science fiction and spooky stories. While working in a glass factory as a young man ndash in between playing lead guitar in a band ndash he began reading about cases of so-called ldquoreal le hauntings and devoured books by Erich von Daniken, who has made outlandish and unsubstantiated claims about aliens visiting Earth.ldquoI started out to disprove these subjects. I thought there was no validity in them ndash that it was all nonsense, Robinson says. ldquoThen I began my own investigations. Irsquove seen things ndash unbelievable things. Thatrsquos when I came off the fence.UFO encounterTHE case which changed Robinsonrsquos le was the infamous incident which has gone down in the annals of ufology as ldquothe Dechmont Woods Encounter. In , Scottish forestry worker Robert Taylor was walking through Dechmont Woods near Livingston when what he described as a ldquoflying dome appeared, hovering over the forest floor. Taylor ndash who everyone claimed was a sober and serious man ndash said something like ldquosea mines emerged from the craft and seized him.He lost consciousness and later awoke, bruised, with this trousers ripped and the craft gone. Taylor tried to drive away but careened his car into a ditch. When he made it home to his we, says Robinson, he said these famous words: ldquoIrsquove been attacked.His we asked who attacked him and Taylor replied: ldquoA spaceship.Taylor received medical treatment ndash as he was genuinely hurt ndash and police were called. What makes the case remarkable is that this is the only alleged UFO incident where police recorded a criminal assault. Officers also found marks on the ground where Taylor said the craft had been.Now, there are plenty of facts that can be found to dismiss any notion of ET in this case. Taylor previously had meningitis and reported a strong smell during the incident. It could have been a mini-stroke or psychotic episode. Taylor is now dead so wersquoll never truly know.But Robinson ndash now the proud owner of Taylorrsquos ripped trousers ndash- believes the case to be a real alien encounter. At the time, the event was big news in Scotland. Robinson heard the story on the radio and went to interview Taylor.ldquoIt stands the test of time as a great case, he says. ldquoYoursquoll never meet a more genuine, sincere man who didnrsquot want any attention in his le. This was my first big investigation though Irsquove done so many since. You get to know peoplersquos body language ndash whorsquos telling lies. I saw the depth of honesty in this man.Robinson went on to write a book about the case. He does retain a sliver of scepticism, however. ldquoI do agree with the statement lsquocould it not have been a medical episodersquo ndash which meant Taylor believed hersquod been attacked. Thatrsquos the only other possibility. Other than that I do believe he saw what he saw that day.After investigating the Dechmont Woods Encounter, people began ldquobanging on my door and phoning me up, says Robinson. And thatrsquos when he began hunting ghosts hellipHaunted housesONE case involved an elderly woman in Stirling who had heard about Robinson, by now the founder of Strange Phenomena Investigations, with a team working alongside him. ldquoJust like with UFOs, I started out to disprove ghosts too, he says. However, once again, Robinson adds, as with his UFO investigations, his experiences turned him into a believer.ldquoThis old lady was getting bombarded with paranormal events, he says. ldquoThings were falling off shelves. Shersquod lost her husband. Chests were moving ndash all that stuff.One of Robinsonrsquos team was a psychic. In an upstairs bedroom, the psychic asked Robinsonhe ldquofelt a spirit in the room.ldquoI felt nothing, Robinson says. Then a lsquoghostrsquo slapped him. ldquoSuddenly, he says, ldquotherersquos this tremendous force, which pushed itself down on my hand ndash my hand actually hit my leg. Nobody was near me. It was incredible.At another case in Tullibody, Robinson was investigating a haunted bedroom. ldquoItrsquos always a haunted bedroom for some reason, he laughs.Nothing happened for hours and Robinson was questioning ldquowhy I do this to myself. One of his team was filming while the room was in darkness. Then out of nowhere, he says, ldquothe whole room illuminated with thousands of tiny pinpricks of light in the air, adding: ldquoIt only lasted  seconds before the room was catapulted back into total darkness.And was there evidence on camera  ldquoNothing. Nothing appeared. Robinson says that evenhersquod captured proof, ldquosceptics wouldrsquove said itrsquos a hoax.Clearly, no evidence has been found ndashanywhere or ever ndash to prove any haunting or alien encounter.Later, during another ghost hunt at Stirling Tolbooth jail, he ldquofelt a kick on the leg. I thought it was one of our investigators, but nobody was near me. I turned around and I can only tell you what I saw: a leg, from the knee down. It was only there for two or three seconds and it disappeared.Robinson is now rattling through his adventures at a rate of knots. ldquoTherersquos another case we were working in Kirkintilloch. It was an ex-police officerrsquos home. Every wall had a photostat copy of the Lordrsquos Prayer on it, there were crucixes everywhere. It was creepy. As wersquore walking into a room upstairs, it was like somebody grabbed my hair and pulled me back. I shouted for one of my colleagues to put the light on. I thought Irsquod walked into a childrsquos mobile or Airfix model or loose plaster, but there was nothing hanging down. It was like fingers going through my hair ndash it was extraordinary.Now, obviously, sceptics like me would say of these cases that perhaps some of the people seeking Robinsonrsquos services were a little disturbed, or that creeping around in a house yoursquove been told is haunted might play tricks on the most logical mind, or that even group hysteria might kick in. Robinson says he asks people who call on him to investigate whether they use drink or drugs or have mental health problems, and he insists he is seasoned enough not to let his imagination run away with him.Hoaxes and liesWHAT about being conned  Many well-intentioned or gullible ldquoghost hunters have been duped by charlatans and Robinson tells of one incident where he witnessed ldquothe most sensational thing Irsquove ever seen.Robinson has taken his investigations all over Britain ndash and this case happened in Chingford, north London. He was invited to a home where a medium sat behind a curtain in a darkened room. Bells tinkled, voices wailed, faces emerged from curtains and a chest of drawers rose up and flew across the ceiling. Robinson says he thought it all a hoax until he placed his hands on the chest of drawers, holding it down, and asked the medium to move it again. Once more it rose and flew through the air. ldquoI cannot stress enough that even though I believe in the paranormal, Irsquom still sceptical about every case I go on, he says.I point out that Irsquom a bit of an amateur student of stage magic and therersquos a history of such tricks played by phoney spiritualists going back to the Victorian period. Therersquos even a trick called The Spirit Cabinet which sounds a little like the event Robinson witnessed.Robinson accepts that ldquotherersquos wonderful magicians who can do wonderful spooky things but itrsquos all a trick. However, he insists that he cannot explain how the chest moved the second time as he held it down. ldquoDo I have evidence  No, the lady whose house it was wouldnrsquot allow cameras.As we talk through his cases, I tell Robinson that when it comes to events where he was present I wonrsquot call him a liar. He seems a genuine man who believes what he thinks he saw and what he thinks happened. However, that doesnrsquot mean those events really involved ghosts. Other explanations are clearly more likely ndash and when it comes to the Chingford event, itrsquos stinks of trickery, I say.ldquoI agree that you have to think that way, yoursquove got to think itrsquos a magic trick. The medium is behind a curtain. Why  Why did he have to do that  It makes you wonder. I couldnrsquot see any form of trickery but there are magicians, so people can be fooled. The phenomena was amazing but there mightrsquove been something there to fool me.However, his scepticism is clearly beaten by his need to believe, as he quickly adds: ldquoWhat happened after that was this tremendous cold gust of wind pervaded a small council bedroom. It was so cold you could see your breath. It was like being in an industrial freezer.Again, thatrsquos not a trick which is hard to pull off. Just ask Derren Brown. But Robinson has another encounter to tell of: the Sauchie Poltergeist.Scotlandrsquos poltergeistROBINSON has been down into the depths of Loch Ness in search of the monster in a mini-sub but therersquos only one thing that really scares him: the ouija board. He believes it can raise malevolent spirits intent on harming humans. Itrsquos a fear which the classic horror movie The Exorcist was built around.Events in  in the town of Sauchie in Clackmannanshire have weird echoes of the film. We donrsquot have to take Robinsonrsquos word for it ndash even though he recently wrote a book about the case and interviewed folk involved in the tale. We can just flick through Alloa Advertiser reports.The claims go like this: -year-old Virginia Campbell moves from Donegal to Scotland with her family. The move makes her unhappy. Strange noises begin to plague her, and one night she goes downstairs to tell her family but a terrying sound follows her. The sounds continue, ornaments move, a linen basket opens by itself.The family see a sideboard move.A local minister is called and is said to witness the linen basket move again. Virginiarsquos bedclothes, says Robinson, ldquowould ripple asa stone had been thrown into water.At school, Virginiarsquos desk lid begins banging up and down and her teacherrsquos pointer moves of its own accord. Then the teacherrsquos desk is said to move and a bowl smash in the class.The teacher, it is claimed, tries to let the children out of the class ndash as by now theyrsquore hysterical ndash but the door wonrsquot open. Later, a doctor is called to attend Virginia and shersquos sedated. The doctoris said to have witnessed Virginiarsquos pillow rotate on the bed. Virginia even moved house but the knockings followed her.In December , the Alloa Journal reported Virginiarsquos aunt being pushed off a bed and blankets rising up of their own accord. Not long afterwards, the story dies down and Virginia vanishes. Nobody knows where she is to this day.Robinson, who spoke to Virginiarsquos classmates for his book The Sauchie Poltergeist, tried to find her and traced her to Bedfordshire in the s but after that the trail goes cold.Robinson doesnrsquot believe that the Sauchie events were a con, or down to a mixed-up, unhappy child acting out, either consciously or subconsciously, or mass hysteria, or ldquoa child going through puberty and sexual energy projecting out and moving things like cupboards. I believe a bad spirit attached itself to her in Ireland and moved to Scotland with her and itrsquos been with her ever since. Therersquos a nasty side to the spirit world.What do you think ROBINSON says he has not made much money out of a letime as a paranormal researcher. Books donrsquot earn a fortune, he adds, and mostly he simply gets his expenses paid for travelling to and from lectures.Proof, he says, ldquois in the eye of the beholder. When it comes to the inidual theyrsquoll know themselves whether what theyrsquove experienced is true. Proof is always nice, but belief is personal. Wersquove seen so many photographs claiming to be ghosts or UFOs that were nothing of the kind.He accepts, though, that with so-called hauntings, creaky floorboards and cooling pipes could lead people to believe in the supernatural.For Robinson, around ldquo per cent or even higher of ghost cases are easily explained and not otherworldly. With UFOs, he says, only about % of sightings cannot be explained as either natural phenomena like planets or military aircraft.However, that %, he genuinely believes, are aliens.As long as folk donrsquot mock Robinson, he says, hersquos perfectly content to be the subject of doubt and questioning. ldquoMy raison drsquoecirctre is just to tell people about these subjects and say lsquothere you go, itrsquos up to you to believe it or notrsquo ndash thatrsquos all.If yoursquove got a paranormal experience yoursquod like to share why not write in and let us know to sunday-letters@theherald

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive accessas we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive pound for two months offer here.From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expectground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content ndash as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two monthshere.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as ldquounsatisfactory on pollution, according to data from the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oilcompanies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as ldquovery poor in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as ldquopoor.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotlandrsquos fish farms have been rated as ldquounsatisfactory" by the Scottish Governmentrsquos environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, wecan today reveal.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either ldquovery poor, ldquopoor or ldquoat risk because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sitesacrossScotland that have been officiallydeemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencydamnedthe performance of more than  sitesincluding Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nationrsquos protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species inScotlandare in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we canreveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandrsquos wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inScotlandare in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinclimate changeand wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandrsquos natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.#The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ndash the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.EnvironmentStandards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ldquoover a decade would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.##For years this city street ndash#with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ndash#has been amongst Scotlandrsquos most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotlandrsquos biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk ofhealthconditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.#Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leadinghealthprofessionals ndash including consultants, GPs and medical academics ndash are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, publictransportand green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotlandrsquos rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.New assessment methods used by the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as ldquobad between  and . There are ldquosignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures, Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotlandrsquos most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are ldquopoor, ldquovery poor or ldquoat risk, according to Scotlandrsquos environmental watchdog.Almost all these ldquounsatisfactory sites are considered to be among Scotlandrsquos critical national infrastructure ndash operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.Read the full story here.Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a ldquodisappointing picture of widespread failure on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.The Scottish Government must take ldquoradical action on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.

title: community urged to pull together as covid cases rise by 55
story: coronavirusCommunity urged to #pull together# as COVID cases rise by October ,  at : pmAs Orkney records  new COVID- cases, the county#s public health team has urged the community to remain cautious around busy winter events.According to NHS Orkney, not all of the  cases attributed to Orkney today are from the past  hours — but there is a signicant level of community infection across the whole county.A backlog in reporting test results is partly behind the high number of cases reported this afternoon, but NHS Orkney#s interim chief executive has said he anticipates that figures will continue to rise in the coming days.Part of the issue, according to Michael Dickson and NHS Orkney director of public health Louise Wilson, is that many of the folk who are experiencing COVID- symptoms are continuing to go to work and attend events.#This virus is just so infectious,# Dr Wilson said in a press briefing this Thursday afternoon.#We really to be careful about what we are doing and how we are interacting.#We are seeing people who have symptoms who are still going out and about and continuing with their daily lives. We would urge these people to please isolate and get tested.#The community has been so good about this before, so we are really asking everyone to pull together again at this point.#The health authority has confirmed that the COVID Assessment Centre in Kirkwall will be open on both Saturday and Sunday, in addition to its usual hours, for testing.If you develop COVID- symptoms, or have a positive lateral flow test, you must self-isolate and seek a PCR test. You can book this by phoning  .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: have your say on what matters most to you when it comes to your community
story: featured newsHave your say on what matters most to you when it comes to your communityNovember ,  at : pm vw, px"  A community-wide consultation to shape future aspirations and ideas is now under way.The LEADER Local Action Group, the council and Voluntary Action Orkneywant to hear what’s important to you about the place in which you live — whether that be development, the countryside, play areas, sports and leisure, shops and services, activities and connectivity, to name a few.Contained in the most recent edition of The Orcadian is a short and easy-to-complete questionnaire for the consultation, Orkney Matters — Your Place, Your Future, for the people of Orkney to fill in and send back.Your views will allow future work to be shaped to ensure your community aspirations and ideas are at the forefront moving forward for Orkney.There is a number of teams involved to try and ensure we reach as many people as possible, especially those “lesser-heard voices”.The survey can also be completed online. Paper copies of the survey are available on request. All completed surveys with names and email addresses included which are sent to Orkney Matters Survey, Orkney Islands Council, Development and Marine Planning, School Place, Kirkwall, KW NY by  January , will be entered into our prize draw with a chance of winning a £ local voucher.If you have any questions about the survey or the consultation, please email orkneymatters@orkney.gov.uk.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney group to highlight sea level rise
story: A group of Orcadian climate activists are aiming to draw attention to the threat of rising sea levels to island communities like their own. This Saturday#s creative demonstration will involve a human chain waving blue banners to symbolise sea level rises. By doing so, Orkney Climate Action aims to send a visual message to UK politicians and world leaders.“As island communities, we can see our climate changing. Coastal roads are overtopped by storm surges more regularly and the shorelines are eroding faster than before. We need a transition away from fossil fuels to end the melting of glaciers and ice caps that is feeding sea level rises. The COP summit in Glasgow next month needs to make firm commitments to tackle emissions and protect island communities worldwide” said a spokesman for the group.out binding targets in inidual countries.“Lots of people are making an effort to cut their personal CO contributions, both here in Orkney and worldwide. Yet governments and major industries are promising too little and delivering less. Plans to approve further fossil fuel exploitation in the North Sea are directly at odds with what the UK government is saying, just when it should be sending a clear message to visiting world leaders in Glasgow” said event organiser Graham.The event will start at noon on Saturday, October , with participants gathering in Ayre Mills car park, before spreading out in a human chain towards the town centre along the cycle path and sea flood defences by Ayre Road. Ayre Road was chosen as the location because of its risk of permanent floodingsea ice melting continues unabated.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney school staff set to strike over pay
story: Orkney school catering, janitorial and cleaning staff are poised to strike next month, as union members reach #breaking point# over a pay dispute.Workers feel “aggrieved by the way they’ve been treated” and are disappointed that they’ve had to resort to strike action, according to Karen Davidson, UNISON#s regional organiser for local services in Orkney.Meanwhile, Orkney Islands Councilhas said it will be #evaluating the impact# the proposed week-long strike, might have on service provision across the county.The industrial action, which is due to coincide with the COP Climate Conference in Glasgow from November  until November , has arisen from a dispute over a pay claim for  .On Monday, it was confirmed that council workers in Orkney would be among employees from  local authorities who will undertake industrial actionworkers’ demands are not met.Ms Davidson said this week that UNISON members in the isles were #at breaking point#.“Local government submitted the pay claim for council workers and it has taken COSLA quite some considerable time to come back with an offer,# she said.“It does not meet the request that we had put in.“We’re a bit disappointed that council workers seem to be the poor relation when it comes to the Scottish Government and COSLA – they always seem to lag behind any pay award that is given or recognition towards the work that was undertaken during the pandemic.“Our council members opened schools to allow other key workers to go to their work. We had council workers that took on additional and dferent duties and they’ve had no reward.”Responding to the announcement of the strike, an OIC spokeswoman said: “The council was informed in writing by UNISON on Monday afternoon that, following a ballot for industrial action, they would be calling their members who work in school catering, cleaning and janitorial services to participate in strike action during the period November  to November , .“Other trade unions have not established a mandate for industrial action in Orkney.“The action announced is in response to the ongoing national dispute in relation to a pay award for local government staff for the year - which is negotiated between the trade unions and COSLA as the umbrella body for local government.“The council will be evaluating what impact this announcement may have on service provision as a matter of urgency and will ensure appropriate communications are issued in due course.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: stronsay pulls together to keep covid at bay
story: As confirmed COVID cases continue to rise across Orkney, one island in particular is setting a stellar example to the community, by pulling together to prevent further spread of infection.While it is understood that Stronsay is not harbouring an exceptionally high number of confirmed positive cases, the community there is taking swt action to prevent an outbreak.This includes the closure of several businesses which may have come into contact with positive cases.Speaking to The Orcadian from self-isolation, this evening, Stronsay#s community council chairman, Ian Cooper, said that he is only aware of a single PCR-confirmed positive case in the island. However, there are a growing number of folk self-isolating, and the community has taken quick action to prevent any further transmission.#I think there has maybe been a few folk that have had positive lateral flow tests — myself included,# Mr Cooper explained.#A similar thing happened maybe back in August, where there was just one confirmed PCR case, and the whole island just closed down for a peedie while.#Mr Cooper has praised the population of around  for the way it has responded during the pandemic to self-isolation — particularly in terms of folk supporting each other when many are unable to leave their homes for essentials.#It#s a small community,# he said.#Everybody just pulls together. If anybody needs something, there is always someone there to help out.#As those who have received a positive lateral flow result now receive PCR testing via the Stronsay surgery, Mr Cooper anticipates that there may be a rise in confirmed cases. He is confident, however, that the community will remain on top of the situation by taking the appropriate self-isolation, social distancing and hygiene precautions advised by the Scottish Government.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: welcome to kirkwall no wait stromness oic to rectify halloween sign swap
story: Drivers between Kirkwall and Stromness have been getting mixed signals, this Monday, after an overnight Hallowe#en prank.Orkney Islands Council has said it is now in the process of ing two road signs marked #welcome to Kirkwall# and a #welcome to Stromness# to their correct positions, after they were swapped overnight.While any unfamiliar visitors to Orkney might have found themselves a bit confused today, the swapping of the signs has proved a viral hit on the county#s social media community.Asked about the incident, this afternoon, an OIC spokeswoman said: “We would like to thank members of the public for alerting us to the switching of Kirkwall and Stromness #welcome signs# which occurred on Hallowe’en.#They are being ed to their rightful positions now.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: queen-calls-world-leaders-work-together-tackle-climate-change
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Cop – GlasgowThe Queen has issued a rallying cry to world leaders attending Cop urging them to work together in ldquocommon cause to tackle climate change and ldquosolve the most insurmountable problems.In a video message played during a welcoming reception for presidents and prime ministers, she hoped the summitrsquos legacy would be that they recognised ldquothe time for words has now moved to the time for action.The Queen paid a heartfelt tribute to ldquomy dear late husband the Duke of Edinburgh for his environmental awareness in raising the issue more than  years ago.In a rare public expression of emotion, the monarch said it was a ldquosource of great pride the important role he played in encouraging people to look after the natural world, and she ldquocould not be more proud of the Prince of Wales and Duke of Cambridge who have continued his work.Acknowledging her own mortality, the Queen, whose health has caused concern after she decided not to attend the Glasgow conference when advised by doctors to rest, said not all would benefit from the leadersrsquo actions as ldquonone of us will live forever.But any determination to confront the planetrsquos environmental problems would benefit ldquoour childrenrsquos children.Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge listened to her message which was recorded on Friday at Windsor Castle. vw,vw,px, px"The Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall watching as the Queen makes a video message The Queen said: ldquoIn the coming days, the world has the chance to join in the shared objective of creating a safer, stabler future for our people and for the planet on which we depend.ldquoNone of us underestimates the challenges ahead: but history has shown that when nations come together in common cause, there is always room for hope. Working side by side, we have the ability to solve the most insurmountable problems and to triumph over the greatest of adversities.The head of state added: ldquoI, for one, hope that this conference will be one of those rare occasions where everyone will have the chance to rise above the politics of the moment, and achieve true statesmanship.ldquoIt is the hope of many that the legacy of this summit ndash written in history books yet to be printed ndash will describe you as the leaders who did not pass up the opportunity and that you answered the call of those future generations.ldquoThat you left this conference as a community of nations with a determination, a desire, and a plan, to address the impact of climate change and to recognise that the time for words has now moved to the time for action. vw,vw,px, px"In her video message, the Queen stressed how Philip had been such a keen environmentalist .Philip was an environmentalist before the word came into common use and he championed the natural world long before it was fashionable.He was president of the WWF ndash World Wildle Fund ndash from  to  and famously drove an eco-friendly taxi around the streets of London decades before green vehicles were more widely used.The Queen wore a butterfly brooch as she spoke, seated in front of a photograph of Philip admiring butterflies in Mexico in . vw,vw,px, px"A photograph of her late husband during a visit to Mexico in  was on display during the Queenrsquos video message In her message the Queen said she was happy to welcome the delegates as the ldquoimpact of the environment on human progress was a subject close to Philiprsquos heart.She added: ldquoI remember well that in , he told an academic gathering: lsquoIf the world pollution situation is not critical at the moment, it is as certain as anything can be, that the situation will become increasingly intolerable within a very short timehellip If we fail to cope with this challenge, all the other problems will pale into insignicance.rsquoldquoIt is a source of great pride to me that the leading role my husband played in encouraging people to protect our fragile planet, lives on through the work of our eldest son Charles and his eldest son William. I could not be more proud of them. vw,vw,px, px"The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge during the first Earthshot Prize awards ceremony at Alexandra Palace in LondonWilliam recently held the inaugural prize-giving ceremony for his environmental Earthshot Prize which aims to find solutions to the worldrsquos problems like providing clean air or clearing plastics from the sea.While Charles has spent much of his adult le highlighting the threat posed to the environment by human activity and trying to mitigate it.Teenage activist Greta Thunberg who galvanised a generation of young people across the globe with her climate change strikes joined youth climate protests outside the ldquoblue zone where the leaders were meeting.The Queen added: ldquohellipI have drawn great comfort and inspiration from the relentless enthusiasm of people of all ages ndash especially the young ndash in calling for everyone to play their part.We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: countries-make-commitments-deforestation-methane-emissions-cop26
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Climate activists during a demonstration by the River Clyde in front the Scottish Event Campus in Glasgow where Cop is being heldCountries are outlining commitments to curb deforestation and cut methane emissions at Cop as part of efforts to drive efforts to tackle the climate crisis.The announcements come after the Queen issued a rallying cry to world leaders attending Cop urging them to work together in ldquocommon cause to tackle climate change and ldquosolve the most insurmountable problems.In a video message played during a welcoming reception for presidents and prime ministers, she hoped the summitrsquos legacy would be that they recognised ldquothe time for words has now moved to the time for action.More than  world leaders will sign up to a landmark agreement to protect and restore the Earthrsquos forests, the UK Government has said.On the second day of the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow on Tuesday, leaders covering % of the worldrsquos forests will commit to halt and reverse deforestation and land degradation by .Downing Street said the pledges were backed by pound. billion of public funding with a further pound. billion in private investment.The commitment, to be formally announced at an event convened by Boris Johnson, has been welcomed by campaigners and experts, in particular the recognition of the role of indigenous people in protecting forests.The Prime Minister is expected to say: ldquoThese great teeming ecosystems, these cathedrals of nature, are the lungs of our planet.ldquoForests support communities, livelihoods and food supply, and absorb the carbon we pump into the atmosphere.ldquoThey are essential to our very survival.ldquoWith todayrsquos unprecedented pledges, we will have a chance to end humanityrsquos long history as naturersquos conqueror, and instead become its custodian." data-title"Autumn weather Oct th " data--holder"PA Wire" data--notice"PA Wire PA Images" data-credit"Andrew Matthews" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"The New Forest Meanwhile the US and EU are launching an initiative that aims at driving globalefforts to cut emissions of methane, a powerful but relatively short-lived greenhouse gas which comes from sources including fossil fuel extraction and livestock farming, as a signicant short-term contribution to climate action.Dozens of heads of state will take part in the launch of the pledge, which commits countries to cut their emissions of the gas by % by .The announcements are part of efforts at Cop in a range of sectors,characterised by Mr Johnson as ldquocoal, cars, cash and trees,to drive momentum on reducing missions, alongside national plans by countries to cut climate-warming pollution in the next decade.Current national action plans to curb emissions leave the world way off track to meet global goals to keep temperature rises to ldquowell below C above pre-industrial levels and to aim for a less dangerous .C limit.Countries at Cop are under pressure to keep the .C goal in reach, deliver on climate finance to support poorer nations tackle the crisis, and finalise parts of the global Paris climate treaty.Cop will not close the gap between the action needed and what countries have promised, even with countries such as India bringing forward new commitments on the first day of the talks, so there will also be a push to negotiate a road map to increasing ambition in the next decade.We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate title: teleconsultations-doctors-worse-convenient-study-shows
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.An empty hospital waiting roomPhone or video consultations with doctors are ldquoworse but more convenient than face-to-face appointments, according to a new study.Rheumatology patients perceived so-called telemedicine as to have ldquoincreased misdiagnoses, inequalities and barriers to accessing care.But more than % found them ldquomore convenient, according to a new analysis of telemedicine, led by researchers at the University of Cambridge.Researchers surveyed , patients, the majority of whom had inflammatory arthritis or lupus.They also polled more than  clinicians between April and July.Some of the findings, published in the journal Rheumatology, included:ndash Nine out of  medics and % of patients felt telemedicine was ldquoworse than face-to-face for building a trusting relationship.ndash Many patients felt that phone or video consultations followed an impersonal ldquotick list and felt more ldquorushed.ndash Patients and medics both said that video and phone consultations were worse than face-to-face appointments in terms of ldquoaccuracy of assessment.ndash But more than six out of  patients and doctors said telemedicine was ldquomore convenient, citing reduced waiting times, no travelling, and safety from infection as the main advantages.ndash Some doctors said that NHS technology was ldquoembarrassingly primitive for delivering telemedicine, though others cited improvements which were implemented as a result of the pandemic.ndash Telemedicine could lead to inequalities in treatment for people who had hearing, cognitive or speech dficulties and for those whose first language was not English, among others, the authors said.ndash Researchers also said that concerns were expressed that telemedicine would be ldquoover-used by NHS and hospital management as a cost and time-saving measure rather than in patientsrsquo best interests.ndash Only % of clinicians felt telemedicine was overall better than face-to-face.New measures will help GP practices improve availability so that patients who need care can get it and boost GP capacity to increase the proportion of face to face appointments. A big thank you to everyone who shared their experience of GP access with us. https:t.co bpqPPhkQJImdash Healthwatch EnglandOctober , The authors wrote: ldquoThe findings identied a place for telemedicine for certain patients, yet a strong overall preference for face-to-face consultations from both clinicians and patients.Melanie Sloan, lead author from the Primary Care Unit at the University of Cambridge, said: ldquoThe pandemic has had a major impact on the ability of healthcare professionals to see their patients face-to-face, and this has led to a signicant increase in the number of telemedicine consultations.ldquoAs the NHS develops a telemedicine strategy, we hope there will be a thorough assessment of the clinical and psychological risks and steps taken to mitigate those risks, as well as action to address the possibility of worsening existing health inequalities for those less likely to be able to benefit from remote consultations.Co-author, Professor Caroline Gordon, from the University of Birmingham, added: ldquoSome stable rheumatic disease patients can benefit from telemedicine but new patients, those with worsening symptoms or more complex conditions such as lupus, need quickly accessible, face-to face appointments to manage their conditions.Senior author, Dr Felix Naughton from the University of East Anglia, added: ldquoOf greatest concern was the great iability in accessibility to care.ldquoApproximately half of all patients felt they would not receive a prompt response when very unwell, often citing increased barriers due to some remote contact and administrative systems that are not yet efficient enough to cope with the sudden move towards telemedicine.The rise in teleconsultations throughout the pandemic has become an intense topic of debate in medical communities.Some patients have expressed preference for face-to-face appointments but others have been exasperated at not being able to see doctors when requested.The issue has been particularly fraught in GP surgeries and the NHS has mandated that patients are able to see a GP in personthey choose, and has threatened to publish league tables of practices which are offering the fewest in-person appointments.But the British Medical Association has rejected the ldquoaccess plan and said it proposes to ballot the profession on industrial action.Data published last week show some % of appointments in September were in-person. Before the pandemic this figure was about %.We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: turning-70-can-double-price-travel-insurance-says
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.An aeroplaneTurning  can double the price of travel insurance evensomeone is healthy, according to Which Policies can be markedly more expensive and harder to find once customers pass , eventhey are in good health, the consumer group said.Which  looked at common barriers to finding affordable cover, gathering the experiences of some members in the past two years.Medical conditions and age were most commonly identied as the source of problems and travel insurance was the most common problem area.In separate mystery shopping research, Which  searched for quotes for customers in perfect health buying an annual European policy, using a comparison website in September.It found that once a customer reached , they had fewer quotes to choose from and the average price of the cheapest five nearly doubled, compared with customers aged .The average of the cheapest five quotes offered to a -year-old was pound and for a -year-old this nearly doubled to pound.Posing as a -year-old travel insurance customer, Which  got  quotes, falling to just seven for an -year-old.One Which  member said declaring his wersquos irregular heartbeat resulted in ldquoeither a refusal to insure or astronomical premiums for the couplersquos annual worldwide cover ndash with one insurer quoting as much as pound,.Older, more experienced drivers are often rewarded with cheaper car insurance, butthis tends to creep up again after drivers pass their mid-s, Which  said.One Which  member, aged , was surprised to be offered quotes ranging from pound to pound, for car insurance.They said: ldquoI still run, jump in rivers and chase salmon, and run stables and horses. Itrsquos annoying to discover that at this age yoursquore deemed incapable of even driving.Which  said many specialist insurers and brokers, and even some mainstream providers, may be able to help customers struggling to find affordable deals on comparison websites.Another port of call is the British Insurance Brokersrsquo Association , which helps people find specialist brokers through the ldquofind insurance service on its website.Jenny Ross, Which  Money editor, said: ldquoIf you struggle to get insurance because of medical conditions or your age, there are some resources that can help you locate specialist insurers that lie off the beaten track of comparison websites.ldquoIf therersquos relevant context to your history or circumstances that you canrsquot communicate on an online form ndash or yoursquore unsure how to accurately fill one out ndash contact the insurer directly by phone or email to speak with a human being.Sarah Brodie, senior policy adviser, general insurance at the Association of British Insurers , said: ldquoTravel insurers aim to offer competitively priced travel insurance to as many travellers as possible.ldquoThe cost of travel insurance will reflect a number of factors, including your age and travel destination.ldquoThe older you are, oryou have a pre-existing medical condition, the more likely you are to need to claim for what can be jaw-droppingly expensive overseas emergency medical treatment costs.ldquoTravel insurance remains competitively priced, so it can pay to shop around, always making sure that you buy the policy most suited to your needs, not simply on price, and that you answer all questions, especially on any pre-existing medical conditions, fully and honestly.We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: sound hall saved from possible closure as over 20 people answer call for volunteers
story: The Sound Hall in Lerwick has been saved from the axe after over  people turned up to its annual general meeting # forming a #queue at the door# before it could begin.It comes after the hall had reached #crisis point# with four of its  committee members announcing they would stand down ahead of last night#s [Thursday#s] meeting.But now  people have volunteered to join the committee, while others have said they would carry out ious jobs for the hall.The new chairwoman is former vice chairwoman Moira Thomason. Her predecessor as chair is Ellen Anderson, who said she was delighted to be stepping down from the committee on such a high note.#We had a queue at the door # they just kept coming in,# she said.#We had  people turn up.#Of that ,  people have volunteered to come on to the committee.#She said others had shown willing to help carry out maintenance, or help during s by carrying out bar work.#But we#ve got  people who have taken the forms away to be registered as a committee member. It was super.#She added there was a ied age range in people coming forward, too # and expect to see a better gender mix in the new Sound Hall committee.#For once we had a few males,# she said.Sound Hall, which has operated since the s, had warned it may have to hold an emergency general meetinginsufficient numbers came forward. coverage, and a warning on the hall#s Facebook page, had helped make the dference.#I think people had realised that we were serious.#The news also means events which had been on hold can now go ahead at the hall. Chief among those is a clothes swap planned by the local MS group for next month.The hope is that larger s may be able toin the New Year.Ms Anderson, who is stepping down after  years as chairwoman, said being a hall committee member had been well worthwhile.#It#s been fantastic,# she said. #It really is worthwhile.#..Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.A long-standing volunteer is encouraging people to chip in with community efforts ahead of an event planned by Voluntary Action Shetland . Secretary of the#The Sound Hall in Lerwick is facing a crisis which may lead to its permanent closure within the next few weeksnew #urgently needed#Volunteers and third sector organisations went ldquoabove and beyond during the pandemic, Shetland MSP Beatrice Wishart told the Holyrood parliament. title: cheers pubs bars and nightclubs can stay open longer this festive period
story: Pubs, bars and nightclubs will be able to open later during the festive period after a general licence extension was granted.The SICrsquos licensing board approved the motion todayto apply during the fortnight between Saturdayth December and Sunday, nd January.During this time, all licensed premises will be able to open until am. All nightclubs already permitted to open until am on weekends will be able to do so on weekdays too.The board has granted a similar extension most years since , except for -, and last year due to the pandemic.Member for Shetland West Catherine Hughson, proposed the motion, saying ldquowe are in a very dferent place to where we were last year.She said licensed premises had been open for several months since the easing of restrictions and highlighted the potential economic benefit.Convener Malcolm Bell, who seconded the motion, said that not allowing premises to stay open would only encourage people to congregate in houses where ldquoall the evidence shows therersquos more danger.ldquoWhether the premises concerned can find the staff to actually open is perhaps another issue, he said.Mr Bell had also asked for confirmation that the regular Covid measures would remain in place throughout the longer opening hours...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group. When not at work, Im usually reading books, listening to records or walking around the countryside.Drivers have been warned of signicant delays while repairs are carried out to burst watermain at a busy roundabout. Three-way traffic lights have been set#Tributes were paid to former Shetland councillor and ‘unique character’ Jim Irvine.Drivers are being asked to use caution while driving after reports of oil spillages on the main road. title: newly revamped bar gets green light to host live music televised sport and outdoor drinking
story: Owners of a newly refurbished bar and restaurant in Scalloway have been permitted to host live music, televised sport and outdoor drinking.Shetland Islands Council licensing board granted Da Kiln Barrsquos licence iation application at this morningrsquos meeting .It comes after the popular bar reopened last month following an extensive refurbishment by the new owners, who announced plans for a more food-focussed approach.The proposed iation allows outdoor drinking until pm each night while the inside licensing hours of am-am Monday-Sunday remain unchanged.Young people of all ages will be permitted entry from am-pm ndash but onlythey are accompanied by an adult for meals in the lounge restaurant.Lerwick North member Stephen Leask, who seconded the motion, praised the plans for the new look venture.ldquoI can only see that this will be a huge addition and benefit, he said.Mr Leask also said the plans tied in well with Scallowayrsquos ambitions to attract more tourisms.Convener Malcolm Bell, proposed the motion, with the proviso, that the policersquos request for an earlier end for outdoor drinking be included.Police had suggested outdoor drinking to end at either pm or pm to ldquoprevent the potential for public nuisance.The board agreed a pm outdoor finish.Other approved changes include the removal of club and group meetings from the operating plan.The application was made by Colin MacLean who attended to hear the result...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group.
