title: lord frost accuses eu of ignoring political sensitivities in northern ireland
story: The unionist approach to Northern Ireland’s centenary has been a pathetic concession to the Irish nationalist narrative   Met Office issues Yellow Weather warning for NI as it reveals tornadoes may already have hit UK todayNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPoliticsLord Frost accuses EU of ignoring political sensitivities in Northern IrelandLord Frost has condemned the European Union for behaving “without regard to the huge political, economic and identity sensitivities” in Northern Ireland.By Cate McCurryMonday, st November , : pmUpdated Monday, st November , : pm  "       "  EMBARGOED TO  MONDAY NOVEMBER  File photo dated    of Lord Frost who has condemned the European Union for behaving "without regard to the huge political, economic and identity sensitivities" in Northern Ireland. The Cabinet office minister and former chief negotiator for Brexit also said the EU had "destroyed cross-community consent" with an "overly strict" enforcement of the Northern Ireland Protocol. Issue date: Monday November , .The Cabinet office minister and former chief negotiator for Brexit also said the EU had “destroyed cross-community consent” with an “overly strict” enforcement of the Northern Ireland Protocol.The attack came after the UK and the EU put forward proposals to address the dispute over the protocol, which was negotiated by Lord Frost. He made the comments in the foreword to a new paper for the Policy Exchange think tank that sets out how negotiations in the Brexit process have been hampered by decisions made in .   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The terms of the protocol effectively kept Northern Ireland in the single market, creating a border down the Irish Sea between Great Britain and the fourth nation of the UK, which has angered unionists and hit the UK’s internal market.Lord Frost said: “We mustto the protocol and deliver a more robust, and more balanced, outcome than we could in .”Lord Frost argues that a  EU-UK joint report, which set the terms for the Brexit process, was a result of the UK failing to make “the necessary mental sht from being a member of the EU to negotiating exit from the EU”.He also claimed it was a result of the “extreme weakness” of the UK Government after the June  election.The Policy Exchange paper – The Northern Ireland Protocol: The Origins of the Current Crisis, by Roderick Crawford – provides a chronology of Brexit negotiations and what went wrong in .It argues that commitments, particularly on the Irish border, in the  joint report were “a diplomatic triumph for Ireland and theCommission” but “failing to secure adequate reciprocal concessions was a staggering failure for the UK”.Mr Crawford says the joint report – and what it committed the UK to – led to a flawed February  draft withdrawal agreement and the subsequent November  Withdrawal Agreement.The paper says that led to the fall of Theresa May’s government in  and “tied the hands” of the new Government led by Boris Johnson that year as it renegotiated the terms of Brexit.Lord Frost also warns that enforcement of the Northern Ireland Protocol “has begun to damage” the Good Friday Agreement.He claims he considered resigning in December  after reading the terms of the joint report and realising “a crucial pass had been sold”.FrostNorthern IrelandBrexitProtocolGovernment  "       "  Get the latest news on the CoronavirusWe have launched a daily public interest bulletin to deliver all the updates and vital information to your inboxSign Up  Most Popular‘I mean, what ! title: ogmore by sea one uks best dog friendly beaches
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe region comes in at fth place with  beaches dogs are able to use  days a year. It comes in behind Pembrokeshire at first place with  beaches, Devon with , Cornwall with  and Anglesey with .The research comes as people are looking to continue to holiday at home as Wales and the UK begins to re-open and international travel is still looking unsure. It was carried out by Uswitch and can be viewed here: https:www.uswitch car-insurance guides uk-dog-friendly-beaches-mapped In their list of  beaches from across the UK, Ogmore Beach comes in third place behind Cayton Bay in North Yorkshire and Oxwich Beach near Swansea.MORE NEWS:Coronavirus: One in three adults in Wales now fully vaccinatedDream seaside home has seven bedrooms and an amazing al-fresco entertaining areaLaurence Llewellyn-Bowen joins campaign to transform oldest Vale homeThe Uswitch guide says that Ogmore Beach is best for fishing, walking and dog-friendly pubs and the car park costs pound a day, with dogs allowed on the beach all-year round and there are no restrictions. They say that the beach is a sand and shingle beach and has a reputation for being one of the cleanest in the region. There is a coastal walk, chance to go fishing, surfing and views of Tusker Rock.For those owners who may not yet have ventured to the beach with their pups or are concerned about behaviour while at the beach, Wood Greenrsquos dog behaviour and training specialist, Wendy Kruger, has provided some tips to prepare your dog for the beach.bull Ensure your dogrsquos microchip and collar tag details are up to date ndash just in case.bull Get used to checking ground surface temperatures before you take your dog out, as dry sand can be too hot for dogsrsquo paws on sunny days. To check the ground temperature, place the back of your hand on the ground. If its too hot to hold comfortably for five seconds, itrsquos too hot for dogsrsquo paws..removebull Practise basic, reward-based training when out and about to help your dog to maintain focus and engagement on walks.bull Recall is also an area that needs particular attention. Evenyour dog has a great recall at home, its not something that can be guaranteed in unfamiliar environments with exciting new distractions. Games with toys are a fantastic way to help your dog engage with you when there are other distractions around. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: vale author details history welsh pubs new book
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityGraham Loveluck-Edwards has announced the release of his new book Historic Pubs of Wales where he relishes in some of the more colourful myths, legends and stories from Wales ancient past and oldest pubs.Included in the book is The Captains We, in Sully,a house originally owned by a captain."I have always loved old pubs, and we are blessed to have so many belters here in Wales," added Mr Loveluck-Edwards.Graham Loveluck-Edwards out snapping some pubs for his book "For example, the pub which claims to have an elephant buried under its beer garden, or the pub where funeral parties take a short cut to the cemetery through the bar to keep an ancient right of access alive, or the pub that claims to have invented pancake day and so many more."In all, Ive compiled over  incredible stories based around  amazing old pubs - is there any truth to them "Some for sure, but this book captures them and puts them in the context of history so you can be the judge."MORE NEWS:The book also contains a travel guide so readers can go on a tour around Wales and visit all the pubs in the book.You can find out more at www.talesfromhistoricpubsofwales.The book is available to buy now "As you can imagine for such a book the research was relentless and thorough, and a lot of fun," he added."Pubs have had such a tough time in the last year with us going in and out of lockdowns and with the introduction of social distancing measures."Sixteenth centuryinns are usually a warren of tiny rooms so being two metres apart has made opening and trading near impossible for many."So, a book which celebrates all that is great about our old pubs, which tells people their history, where to find them and what to expect when you get there has been welcomed by all landlords." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - title: thought week journey life
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt records  rail journeys across Britain taken mainly on branch lines in  and .The writer is very descriptive of not just the journey and the people he met, but also the history of the lines he is writing about.Itrsquos very nostalgic and brought back memories of steam engines and their heyday.I grew up near a mainline and can recall being in bed as a child hearing the engines chugging away from a nearby signal.This made me a trainspotter as a boy and I remember being allowed on the footplate of a steam engine in Cardf General Stationand being amazed at the controls the driver used to move the engine and the heat generated from the firebox.This was in the last days of steam and even now the memory is still vivid. I think this is why my we and I enjoy a nostalgic steam journey when we visit an area with a preserved railway, which we did recently.Although more modern engines are more efficient and cleaner, they seem to me to not have the raw power of a steam locomotive and particularly those that used to haul express trains.This book has made me think of the power we need to live in our journey of le.There may seem to be more modern ways of living with many ideas offered, but the nothing beats the power of God.It may seem old fashioned and nostalgic to think like this, but when I see Godrsquos power at work all other efforts pale into insignicance.The Bible shows Godrsquos power with Jesus healing people, raising the dead and feeding large crowds among other things.It was supremely shown when He died and rose again which is central to the Christian faith.That power is still at work today with countless lives changed when people have an encounter with Jesus and see His power at work on their behalf.We all need help in the journey of le and God is always there for us.May I suggest that we do what The Bible says this week:.remove"Ask where the good way is, and walk in it and you will find rest for your souls"PhilipGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: support needed save penarth bridge club
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySupport needed to save Penarth Bridge Club" Support needed to save Penarth Bridge ClubSupport needed to save Penarth Bridge Club" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentProf. Tony Campbell CBENext year Penarth Bridge Club, founded in , will celebrate its golden jubilee.Thus, this club has made a major contribution to the culture and le of Penarth for  years.We have been lucky enough to have had several members who have played bridge for Wales in the Camrose Trophy, the annual home international competition, as well as the European championships.Also, we have members who play regularly for East Wales and in many National events, with the Penarth Menagerie team representing the club in Division  of the East Wales league.But sadly, Covid has taken its toll. We have had great success with online bridge during the pandemic, but now we have reopened for Face-to-Face bridge our numbers are too small to be viable.Please come and support this historic club. However, letrsquos be positive. We are exploring merging our Tuesday and Friday evening sessions with another club.And,all fails, we will resume online bridge. Penarth Bridge Club will live on!So, here is a recent hand played at a Face-to-Face session where careful judgment by both declarer and the defence were required to achieve the optimum result.The AuctionNorth had seven spades and just seven points, ideal for a pre-emptive opening of three spades. The aim of pre-emptive bids is to put a spanner in the wheel of the defence.However, the danger always is that, as here, your partner has a good hand and so has a dficult decision to make on whether to pass or bid on for game. After some thought, South could see at least six spade tricks, evenhis partner did not have the king of spades.There were also two certain heart tricks, and it ought to be possible to rustle up a trick in diamonds and one more from Northrsquos hand. So, South bid four spades.The playTrick  ndash East was on lead and did not fancy a diamond or a club. And the jack of hearts lead was fraught with danger. So, interestingly, East chose to lead the five of spades, reasoning that his king was safe for a trickNorth held the ace..removeAnd evenSouth held three spades to the ace, North must surely have an entry somewhere to take the spade finesse. Anyway, declarer paused to consider the hand.Without the trump lead the contract would have been secure as he could have ruffed a losing club in dummy. But now things were dficult.North decided to play the ace of spades, hoping to drop a singleton king in Westrsquos hand. But no luck. Tricks  and  ndash Declarer then played a club to his ace, followed by a small club from hand, the trick being won by Eastrsquos king.East was now quite pleased he had decided to lead a trump at the first trick. Trick  - East won the next trick with the king of spades, preventing declarer from ruffing his losing club.Trick  ndash East then led his ace of diamonds, which was ruffed by declarer in hand. Trick  ndash Declarer drew Eastrsquos last trump with his queen, discarding a heart from dummy. But he could now see he still had a losing club and a losing heart, one down, having already lost two tricks.But could there be a squeeze on  Tricks , ,  and  ndash Declarer then rattled off his last four spades, forcing four discards from both East and West. East could see that dummy had to discard before West, so he jettisoned his remaining four diamonds, keeping the jack of clubs and two hearts.Declarer decided to discard one more heart and the rest of dummyrsquos diamonds. West had to hope his partner East held the jack of clubs, otherwise he was genuinely squeezed. So, he discarded the rest of his clubs, keeping his three hearts to the queen.Declarer then played a small heart to dummyrsquos ace. He followed this with the king of hearts. Bad luck, Eastrsquos jack dropped but not Westrsquos queen. Trick  - West then won the last trick with his queen of hearts, declarer only making nine tricks - six spades, two hearts, and one club, one down for a loss of  points.Four spades was a perfectly reasonable bid by South. But well done by the defence for the opening lead and care in their discards.What have we learnt . areful judgement is needed when responding to partnerrsquos opening pre-emptive bid, particularly when non vulnerable, since the pre-emptive bid is likely to be quite weak.. Sometimes it can quite be safe to lead a trump from three to king, as here.Penarth club resultsFriday  October: . Joy Seculer and Mike Downey. Peter Craig and Sean Macdougall. Tony Campbell and Simon Brindle . Tuesday  October: . Clwyd Jones and Trish Tracey. Patsy Cohen and Carol Cochlin. Jim Elder and Meryl Skipper . Friday th October: . Tony Campbell and Mike Downey. Peter Craig and Sean Macdougall. Rod Hudson and Trish Tracey .Further informationThe Thursday group has re-opened, running from am to pm. People are requested to arrive by .am.We are starting sessions with a short discussion on the theme of how to communicate with ones partner. Because of Covid-, we have to control numbers, so people are requested to contact Peter Craig in advance at petercraig@gmail,  or .Partners will be arranged as required. Mask wearing is required and people should bring their own refreshments. People are requested to arrive by ..Attendees should have been double vaccinated. If you have any views, hands, or information you would like to share, please email me, campbellak@cf.ac.uk. Keep well. Keep safe. Bon chance. title: half term activities parents children national trust cymru
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAs the nights draw in across Wales, National Trust Cymru has a whole host of events and activities planned to keep your kids entertained.From ghoulish tricks for Halloween, to wonderful autumnal walks, here are some activities you can sink your teeth into at National Trust Cymru sites next week.Half term fun in North WalesBodnant Garden, ConwyCredit: National Trust Cymru Megan TaylorWith  acres of dazzling autumn colour, Bodnant Garden is the perfect place to let your little explorers run wild this half term. Jump across stepping-stones to play pooh sticks in the Dell, build a den or visit the willow worm at the Far End, and explore the little Play Park with zig-zag walkways, a mini suspension bridge, and rope walks.Chrik Castle, WrexhamAs autumn sweeps across the landscape, step into nature and discover Chirk Castlersquos historic estate with its veteran trees and quiet bird hides - itrsquos the ideal spot to tick off some lsquo things to do before yoursquore  and  rsquo activities. If thatrsquos not enough, let off steam as you explore the two play areas, or discover more about the creatures who make the parkland their home on a self-led nature trail.Erddig, WrexhamCredit: National Trust Cymru Oskar ProctorMake family memories together as you try your hand at campfire cooking, enjoy some spooky storytelling, or follow the self-led Welsh folklore trail around the garden. If your little explorers still have energy to spare, then fly on the rope swing, climb over obstacles and balance across beams in Wolfrsquos Den, Erddigrsquos natural play area.Penrhyn Castle and Garden, BangorVisit the dramatic Penrhyn Castle where yoursquoll find lots to keep the whole family entertained. Explore the Victorian Kitchens where the contents of the cupboards will reveal more about the castlersquos worldwide connections, and on October  and , visit the Dung Tower and listen to some Stinky Stories. Outside, explore the extensive garden and estate and discover more about its historic trees on a self-led family trail..removePlas Newydd House and Garden, AngleseyWhether its kicking through leaves, learning about nature, or searching for Red Squirrels, there are plenty of family activities happening at Plas Newydd this half term. Venture into the garden and explore autumn colour with a nature bingo guide, join one of the daily Red Squirrel walks, or hunt for willow animals on the hibernation trail.Half term fun in Mid WalesLlanerchaeron, CeredigionFrom the October  to Halloween, follow a magical hare on a family Halloween adventure through the garden. Can you and your little adventurers escape the clutches of Mari Berllan Biter by making a protective charm from the ingredients you find along the way  To find out more about Mari Berllan Biter, the local witch of Llanerchaeron, join the spooky storytelling session on October , from .am.Powis Castle and Garden, WelshpoolCredit: National Trust Cymru John MillarDust off those wellies, wrap up warm, and see how many family fun activities you can complete at Powis this half term. Hunt high and low along the terraces on the Halloween Pumpkin Trail, explore the sights, sounds, and smells of the season on the Sensory Autumn Trail, or learn fascinating facts on the Fun Fungi Trail through the woodland.Half term fun in West WalesColby Woodland Gardens, PembrokeshireColby is the perfect place to run wild and tick off some of your favourite activities so get ready to build dens, create some wild art, and discover whatrsquos hiding in a pond. If thatrsquos not enough, follow the lsquoI Am a Seedrsquo self-led exhibition to find out more about the historic trees that grow in this fascinating place.Dinefwr, CarmarthenshireCredit: National Trust CymruFollow the autumn trail through Dinefwrrsquos estate this half term and learn more about nature as you collect leaves, make bark rubbings and lots more. Inside, try shadow theatre or enjoy the Shadow Box Branches installation as you explore beautully decorated rooms, full of autumnal atmosphere.Half term fun in South WalesDyffryn Gardens, CardfCredit: National Trust Cymru John MillarFollow the Autumn All Around family trail at Dyffryn and use each of your senses to explore autumn. Theres more than just bright autumn colour to see - hear the crunch of leaves, smell the rain on damp ground, touch the bark of the trees and learn about the seasonal foods you can eat at home. During half term, celebrate the humble hedgehog by making your own spikey friend and seeyou can spot the signs of real-le hedgehogs as you explore the garden.Tredegar House, NewportDiscover the parkland in a dferent way this autumn by following the free, self-led, autumn sensory trail. Feel the crunch of the leaves beneath your feet, smell the crisp autumn air and listen to the birds as they gather to fly south for winter. If thatrsquos not enough, spark your creativity at a pumpkin carving workshop in the Riding School from October  to October . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: queens platinum jubilee cardiff vale scouts plant trees
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityCardf and Vale Scouts has hosted a special tree planting ceremony at their Jubilee campsite, at St Brides-super-Ely, to mark the Queenrsquos Platinum Jubilee .This is part of a UK-wide initiative ndash The Queenrsquos Green Canopy ndash which encourages people to ldquoplant a tree for the jubilee. The additions to the Jubilee campsite were planted by Scouts, in conjunction with The Woodland Trust and volunteers from Lloyds Bank.Even Arthur Thomas ndash a -year-old-man who was District Commissioner for the Scouts in the late s ndash helped.People of all ages got involved in the tree planting Mr Thomas planted some of the original trees at the campsite, including one which he grew from an acorn which was presented to him while on a camping trip in Canada.","description": "Cardf and Vale Scouts hosts The Queens Green Canopy ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media LpFhoH poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests LpFhoH.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.penarthtimes video  ","publisher": Area Commissioner for Cardf and Vale Scouts, Julian Jordan, said ldquoOur campsite has been mostly a green field for the past  years and wersquore currently fundraising to develop the site so it can be enjoyed - not just by the Scouts - but other community groups and local schools.ldquoIn total wersquore hoping to raise poundmillion to achieve our big ambitions of creating a valuable activity space and scout hall in the countryside. As part of the redevelopment, we unfortunately had to carry out some woodland management which meant a small number of trees needed to be felled due to ash die back disease.ldquoTo combat the loss of trees wersquove planted more than  saplings as a simple natural solution to climate change, cleaner air, a habitat for wildle and enhancement of health and wellbeing.The planting is part of the The Queens Green Canopy initativeAlong with benefitting the environment, the tree planting is part of a masterplan to redevelop the campsite.Scout leader, Gareth Johns, said: ldquoAs a user of the site for more than  years it was great to take part in the tree planting and to see the improvement works taking shape which will safeguard the space in the countryside for future generations.The Scouts are raising funds for the campsite - people can donate here.Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: meet royal british legion poppy collector mirza shahzad
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPoppy Appeal collector Mirza Shahzad " Meet the man supporting our heroes by selling poppies in PenarthTen generations of Poppy Collectors " Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE  Poppy Appeal across Wales has launched and this year, as the charity marks its centenary, the Royal British Legionis celebrating theof its collectors.This includes Mirza Shahzad, who collects alongside his Muslim youth group in South Wales, including Penarth, and who is part of  generations of poppy collectors brought together by RBL to represent each decade of the charityrsquos historyThe -year-old, representing the s, is regional co-ordinator of the Ahmadiyya Muslim Youth Associationfor the south west of the UK.He has been supporting the Poppy Appeal since moving to the UK from Pakistan in . AMYA members strongly believe in serving humanity, and Mirza is passionate about the RBL because of the extensive support it provides to the armed forces community.Mr Shahzad said: ldquoIrsquom originally from Pakistan but I live in the UK, so I regard the British Military as our heroes.ldquoAMYA takes a lot of pride in supporting the RBL, and by collecting for the Poppy Appeal we help the families of those serving men and women.ldquoI love to see the responses people on the street give when they see an Asian person collecting for the Poppy Appeal."It gives us a great feeling that wersquore doing something very positive by standing with our armed forces.ldquoItrsquos amazing to see people buy p poppies for pound and expect no change, and itrsquoll be great to have the AMYA community back with the rest of the poppy collectors, after we werenrsquot able to collect as we usually would last year.Poppy Appeal collection boxes have come in many shapes and sizes over the years. " alt"Penarth Times: Ten generations of Poppy Collectors" class"editor-image"The poppy-shaped boxfeatures the initials HF for Haig Fund. It was manufactured by Angal, a well-known manufacturer of charity collection boxes, and dates between  and .He is also wearing a limited edition lsquokhadirsquo poppy, issued in  to honour , Indian soldiers who lost their lives fighting for Britain in the First World War. It is made from the same linen worn by Mahatma Gandhi..removeOTHER NEWS:Community Fundraising Manager for the RBL in Wales, Lynne Woodyatt, said: ldquoThis year, as we mark our centenary, we are proud to be celebrating the outstanding contribution of all our Poppy Appeal collectors."Every poppy counts, which is why getting our Poppy Appeal collectors back out in local communities across Wales is so important. As the impact of Covid- continues to leave some members of the Armed Forces community in urgent need of our help, your support is as crucial as ever.ldquoWe cannot help them without you which is why we are urging the people of the north east to look out for their local collector and donate. Your contribution will make a real dference to the lives of those in our Armed Forces community who have given so much.ldquoThe RBL was formed in the aftermath of the First World War to fight for the rights of those who had given so much and come back to so little. Today, we continue to stand with the Armed Forces community, supporting them in the face of hardships, injuries and bereavements. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: family pay tribute barry journalist sharon harris
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySharon Harris was found dead in her home on Tuesday, October , aged of .She worked as a journalist in Barry for years, including a -year stint at the Barry and District News. Most recently she worked withthe newly-formedGlamorgan Star.Tributes flooded in as news of her death broke, as she was a journalist that dedicated her le to putting the community of Barry first.Her family said in a statement: "It is so dficult to find the words to sum up my beautul sister and beloved daughter."She was simply our everything and a can-do girl."She overcame so much adversity with her health, but without complaining just got on with living le to the fullest - travelling, volunteering, fundraising and making memories."She was dedicated to being a voice for the Barry community that she loved so much and it was more than a job."Like us, were sure the town will mourn the loss of the kindest, most inspirational woman you could ever wish to meet."We, her family, are devastated."Echoing these words, local politicians who saw Sharon frequently have expressed their condolences.Jane Hutt, MS for the Vale of Glamorgan and minister for social justice said: "Sharon Harris was a champion for the communities she served as local newspaper journalist."She was utterly committed to her job and always seeking the stories which would shine a light on political and public affairs."I admired her tenacity and hard work and was thrilled she was back in force as a leading member of the Glamorgan Star team after  years at Barry and District News."I will always remember taking photos and getting copy at events and requesting lsquoa commentrsquo with deadlines on many dficult but important issues..remove"Dear Sharon you will be greatly missed in the Vale of Glamorgan. RIP.":Cllr Lis Burnett, deputy leader of the Vale of Glamorgan Council, said: ldquoSharon served the Vale of Glamorgan and Barry in particular as a tenacious local reporter for many years."At the Barry and District News and the Glamorgan Star her journalism told the stories of the people that make up our communities."If someone had a story to tell then Sharon gave them a voice."Her death has shocked us all and she will be greatly missed." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: lorna prichards howl comedy nights move paget rooms
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe line-up for thenight of Howl at its new Penarth premises" Popular comedy night s with new venue - everything you need to knowHeadliner Stuart Goldsmith " Popular comedy night s with new venue - everything you need to knowLorna Prichard" Popular comedy night s with new venue - everything you need to knowSarah Bridgeman" Popular comedy night s with new venue - everything you need to knowDon Biswas" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA SELL-OUT comedy show, which will have you howling with laughter, is relaunching bigger and better than before.Howl comedy nights were founded by Lorna Prichard, starting at Cardfs Tramshed in .In  she left her job reporting for ITV Wales and ldquoswapped headlines for punchlines going into stand-up comedy Howlbecame a monthly event in Penarthrsquos Pier Pavilion in March .ldquoIt was very successful at Pier Pavilion, selling out to  maximum capacity most months, said Ms Prichard.ldquoI always try to curate a really ied, interesting line up of comedians, and my style of MCing is warm, energetic and a little bit chaotic, which seems to go down well."She planned to move the event to a bigger venue, with Penarth Town Council supporting the venture, then the Covid pandemic hit.Although live events were on hold, Ms Prichard kept busy shegot caught up in a whirlwind romance with a Brazilian called Leo ndash they dated long distance before meeting and getting engaged within  hours.ldquoThat descended into typical chaos, laughed Ms Prichard.ldquoI canrsquot wait to share my lockdown experiences with the audience.And share she will ndash with Howl ing for a monthly Saturday night show, with Glee Club level comedians, at Paget Rooms.ldquoIm so excited to be ing to Penarth, said Ms Prichard.ldquoBefore March  it was truly one of the highlights of my month.ldquoThe last  months have been so hard on us all, and we all need a laugh more than ever."Giving it a new home of the Paget Rooms means bigger shows with even bigger comedians, and I really hope Penarth is going to support us so I can keep coming back!Howl Comedy Night will , at the new venue, from .pm on Saturday November .Guests can expect an evening of fun, drinks, and laughter, featuring:STUART GOLDSMITH " alt"Penarth Times: Stuart Goldsmith " class"editor-image"Stuart Goldsmith An internationally award-winning comedian, writer, podcaster, and host. As seen on CBSrsquos Late Night With Conan OrsquoBrien, Russell Howardrsquos Stand Up Centraland As Yet Untitled ..removeHe is also the host of hit comedy podcast, The Comedians Comedian. With a reputation for smart, accessible stand-up, Stuartrsquos enthusiasm and natural charm conceal a quick wit and fearlessness.DON BISWASDon BiswasDon Biswas is one of the gems of the circuit. A politically charged gag merchant who likes to cover a wide range of subjects including his Asian upbringing, his dyspraxia and conspiracy theories.SARAH BRIDGEMANSarah BridgemanFor the last decade Sarah Bridgeman has been a hit with audiences all over the UK with her warm and friendly style. She has been a weird news commentator for BBC Radio Wales, a finalist for the Welsh national comedy competition WUSA , and has written a play based on her experiences in comedy.LORNA PRICHARDLorna PrichardLorna Prichard is a comedian from North East Wales. She is also a trusted broadcaster, having appeared regularly on TV and radio for the last  years. She can frequently be heard on BBC Radio Wales following the success of her weekly show, lsquoSummer Saturdays with Lorna Prichardrsquo.Since then she has been presenting in studio on a regular basis with rugby legends Jonathan Edwards and Nigel Owens, and covering for other presenters like Kiri Pritchard-McLean.Her warm, natural manner and charm endear her to audiences of all ages. She is a gted improviser who can keep her cool no matter what.Following the debut of Howl at Paget Rooms it willfora Christmas show on Saturday, December , with the line-up to be announced soon.Tickets for upcoming shows are available at ticketsource howl article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. We hibernated until the time was right.ldquoWeve been in Safehouse studio, in Oxford, putting together our next two EPs. We believe the world is ready to believe in us. will be the first track featured on the bandrsquos Revamped EPset to release in .The single includes a YouTube video, directed by Matik, which includes lyrics to the track, and graphics by Lee Waters.You can check it out at www.youtu.be ZlKxbMydncThe rockers, who have both been playing their instruments for more than  years, love performing to crowds ndash something thatrsquos been limited over the past  months due to the Covid pandemic.Matik has described their shows as an ldquoexhilarating clash of pantomime and mosh-pit therapy and people can get their fix at Altered Mythsrsquo upcoming headline show.They will be at Vulcan Lounge, in Cardf, on November  with support band Mawpit. title: llantwit major waterspout weather gets spooky
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityJames Thomas, , an agent in the watersports industry, spotted the unusual phenomenon at Llantwit Major Beach in south Wales on Saturday morning.ldquoAs I stood there watching, I thought to myself, this is probably the best example of a waterspout that I will ever get to see in my letime, Mr Thomas told the PA news agency.ldquoOver the years I have seen quite a few of these over the Bristol Channel, but this was by far the biggest.Also known as funnel clouds or tuba, waterspouts form when a rotating column of wind draws in cloud droplets, according to the Met Office.Mr Thomas said he spied Saturdayrsquos weather spectacle while watching a surfing contest.ldquoIt started off fairly small, and quite high in the sky, and as we continued to watch, it appeared to get darker and began angling itself towards the surface of the sea, asit was coming towards us, he said.ldquoI quickly realised it was a waterspout when I could see the rotating spray on the waterrsquos surface, like a magnetic energy.ldquoI was shouting to all the competitors to look up and see this phenomenal natural occurrence.The sighting comes as the Met Office warned parts of the UK may have seen tornadoes on Sunday, as strong winds and rain batter the country.Gusts of over mph have been recorded and yellow warnings for wind and rain are in place over large parts of the west and where. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: queen calls world leaders work together tackle climate change
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIn a video message played during a welcoming reception for presidents and prime ministers, she hoped the summitrsquos legacy would be that they recognised ldquothe time for words has now moved to the time for action.The Queen paid a heartfelt tribute to ldquomy dear late husband the Duke of Edinburgh for his environmental awareness in raising the issue more than  years ago.In a rare public expression of emotion, the monarch said it was a ldquosource of great pride the important role he played in encouraging people to look after the natural world, and she ldquocould not be more proud of the Prince of Wales and Duke of Cambridge who have continued his work.Acknowledging her own mortality, the Queen, whose health has caused concern after she decided not to attend the Glasgow conference when advised by doctors to rest, said not all would benefit from the leadersrsquo actions as ldquonone of us will live forever.But any determination to confront the planetrsquos environmental problems would benefit ldquoour childrenrsquos children.Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge listened to her message which was recorded on Friday at Windsor Castle. vw,vw,px, px"The Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall watching as the Queen makes a video message The Queen said: ldquoIn the coming days, the world has the chance to join in the shared objective of creating a safer, stabler future for our people and for the planet on which we depend.ldquoNone of us underestimates the challenges ahead: but history has shown that when nations come together in common cause, there is always room for hope. Working side by side, we have the ability to solve the most insurmountable problems and to triumph over the greatest of adversities..removeThe head of state added: ldquoI, for one, hope that this conference will be one of those rare occasions where everyone will have the chance to rise above the politics of the moment, and achieve true statesmanship.ldquoIt is the hope of many that the legacy of this summit ndash written in history books yet to be printed ndash will describe you as the leaders who did not pass up the opportunity and that you answered the call of those future generations.ldquoThat you left this conference as a community of nations with a determination, a desire, and a plan, to address the impact of climate change and to recognise that the time for words has now moved to the time for action. vw,vw,px, px"In her video message, the Queen stressed how Philip had been such a keen environmentalist .Philip was an environmentalist before the word came into common use and he championed the natural world long before it was fashionable.He was president of the WWF ndash World Wildle Fund ndash from  to  and famously drove an eco-friendly taxi around the streets of London decades before green vehicles were more widely used.The Queen wore a butterfly brooch as she spoke, seated in front of a photograph of Philip admiring butterflies in Mexico in . vw,vw,px, px"A photograph of her late husband during a visit to Mexico in  was on display during the Queenrsquos video message In her message the Queen said she was happy to welcome the delegates as the ldquoimpact of the environment on human progress was a subject close to Philiprsquos heart.She added: ldquoI remember well that in , he told an academic gathering: lsquoIf the world pollution situation is not critical at the moment, it is as certain as anything can be, that the situation will become increasingly intolerable within a very short timehellip If we fail to cope with this challenge, all the other problems will pale into insignicance.rsquoldquoIt is a source of great pride to me that the leading role my husband played in encouraging people to protect our fragile planet, lives on through the work of our eldest son Charles and his eldest son William. I could not be more proud of them. vw,vw,px, px"The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge during the first Earthshot Prize awards ceremony at Alexandra Palace in LondonWilliam recently held the inaugural prize-giving ceremony for his environmental Earthshot Prize which aims to find solutions to the worldrsquos problems like providing clean air or clearing plastics from the sea.While Charles has spent much of his adult le highlighting the threat posed to the environment by human activity and trying to mitigate it.Teenage activist Greta Thunberg who galvanised a generation of young people across the globe with her climate change strikes joined youth climate protests outside the ldquoblue zone where the leaders were meeting.The Queen added: ldquohellipI have drawn great comfort and inspiration from the relentless enthusiasm of people of all ages ndash especially the young ndash in calling for everyone to play their part..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: The Queen calls for world leaders to work together to tackle climate change article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: countries make commitments deforestation methane emissions cop
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe announcements come after the Queen issued a rallying cry to world leaders attending Cop urging them to work together in ldquocommon cause to tackle climate change and ldquosolve the most insurmountable problems.In a video message played during a welcoming reception for presidents and prime ministers, she hoped the summitrsquos legacy would be that they recognised ldquothe time for words has now moved to the time for action.More than  world leaders will sign up to a landmark agreement to protect and restore the Earthrsquos forests, the UK Government has said.On the second day of the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow on Tuesday, leaders covering % of the worldrsquos forests will commit to halt and reverse deforestation and land degradation by .Downing Street said the pledges were backed by pound. billion of public funding with a further pound. billion in private investment.The commitment, to be formally announced at an event convened by Boris Johnson, has been welcomed by campaigners and experts, in particular the recognition of the role of indigenous people in protecting forests.The Prime Minister is expected to say: ldquoThese great teeming ecosystems, these cathedrals of nature, are the lungs of our planet.ldquoForests support communities, livelihoods and food supply, and absorb the carbon we pump into the atmosphere.ldquoThey are essential to our very survival.ldquoWith todayrsquos unprecedented pledges, we will have a chance to end humanityrsquos long history as naturersquos conqueror, and instead become its custodian." data-title"Autumn weather Oct th " data--holder"PA Wire" data--notice"PA Wire PA Images" data-credit"Andrew Matthews" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production decfbfbbecfedfaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjMODkwNzM ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"The New Forest Meanwhile the US and EU are launching an initiative that aims at driving globalefforts to cut emissions of methane, a powerful but relatively short-lived greenhouse gas which comes from sources including fossil fuel extraction and livestock farming, as a signicant short-term contribution to climate action..removeDozens of heads of state will take part in the launch of the pledge, which commits countries to cut their emissions of the gas by % by .The announcements are part of efforts at Cop in a range of sectors,characterised by Mr Johnson as ldquocoal, cars, cash and trees,to drive momentum on reducing missions, alongside national plans by countries to cut climate-warming pollution in the next decade.Current national action plans to curb emissions leave the world way off track to meet global goals to keep temperature rises to ldquowell below C above pre-industrial levels and to aim for a less dangerous .C limit.Countries at Cop are under pressure to keep the .C goal in reach, deliver on climate finance to support poorer nations tackle the crisis, and finalise parts of the global Paris climate treaty.Cop will not close the gap between the action needed and what countries have promised, even with countries such as India bringing forward new commitments on the first day of the talks, so there will also be a push to negotiate a road map to increasing ambition in the next decade..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Countries to make commitments on deforestation and methane emissions at Cop article_url   content_id title: teleconsultations doctors worse convenient study shows
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityRheumatology patients perceived so-called telemedicine as to have ldquoincreased misdiagnoses, inequalities and barriers to accessing care.But more than % found them ldquomore convenient, according to a new analysis of telemedicine, led by researchers at the University of Cambridge.Researchers surveyed , patients, the majority of whom had inflammatory arthritis or lupus.They also polled more than  clinicians between April and July.Some of the findings, published in the journal Rheumatology, included:ndash Nine out of  medics and % of patients felt telemedicine was ldquoworse than face-to-face for building a trusting relationship.ndash Many patients felt that phone or video consultations followed an impersonal ldquotick list and felt more ldquorushed.ndash Patients and medics both said that video and phone consultations were worse than face-to-face appointments in terms of ldquoaccuracy of assessment.ndash But more than six out of  patients and doctors said telemedicine was ldquomore convenient, citing reduced waiting times, no travelling, and safety from infection as the main advantages.ndash Some doctors said that NHS technology was ldquoembarrassingly primitive for delivering telemedicine, though others cited improvements which were implemented as a result of the pandemic.ndash Telemedicine could lead to inequalities in treatment for people who had hearing, cognitive or speech dficulties and for those whose first language was not English, among others, the authors said.ndash Researchers also said that concerns were expressed that telemedicine would be ldquoover-used by NHS and hospital management as a cost and time-saving measure rather than in patientsrsquo best interests.ndash Only % of clinicians felt telemedicine was overall better than face-to-face.New measures will help GP practices improve availability so that patients who need care can get it and boost GP capacity to increase the proportion of face to face appointments. A big thank you to everyone who shared their experience of GP access with us. https:t.co bpqPPhkQJImdash Healthwatch EnglandOctober , The authors wrote: ldquoThe findings identied a place for telemedicine for certain patients, yet a strong overall preference for face-to-face consultations from both clinicians and patients.Melanie Sloan, lead author from the Primary Care Unit at the University of Cambridge, said: ldquoThe pandemic has had a major impact on the ability of healthcare professionals to see their patients face-to-face, and this has led to a signicant increase in the number of telemedicine consultations.ldquoAs the NHS develops a telemedicine strategy, we hope there will be a thorough assessment of the clinical and psychological risks and steps taken to mitigate those risks, as well as action to address the possibility of worsening existing health inequalities for those less likely to be able to benefit from remote consultations.Co-author, Professor Caroline Gordon, from the University of Birmingham, added: ldquoSome stable rheumatic disease patients can benefit from telemedicine but new patients, those with worsening symptoms or more complex conditions such as lupus, need quickly accessible, face-to face appointments to manage their conditions.Senior author, Dr Felix Naughton from the University of East Anglia, added: ldquoOf greatest concern was the great iability in accessibility to care.ldquoApproximately half of all patients felt they would not receive a prompt response when very unwell, often citing increased barriers due to some remote contact and administrative systems that are not yet efficient enough to cope with the sudden move towards telemedicine.The rise in teleconsultations throughout the pandemic has become an intense topic of debate in medical communities.Some patients have expressed preference for face-to-face appointments but others have been exasperated at not being able to see doctors when requested.The issue has been particularly fraught in GP surgeries and the NHS has mandated that patients are able to see a GP in personthey choose, and has threatened to publish league tables of practices which are offering the fewest in-person appointments.But the British Medical Association has rejected the ldquoaccess plan and said it proposes to ballot the profession on industrial action.Data published last week show some % of appointments in September were in-person. Before the pandemic this figure was about %..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Teleconsultations with doctors are  uworse but more convenient u, study shows article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: turning  can double price travel insurance says
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPolicies can be markedly more expensive and harder to find once customers pass , eventhey are in good health, the consumer group said.Which  looked at common barriers to finding affordable cover, gathering the experiences of some members in the past two years.Medical conditions and age were most commonly identied as the source of problems and travel insurance was the most common problem area.In separate mystery shopping research, Which  searched for quotes for customers in perfect health buying an annual European policy, using a comparison website in September.It found that once a customer reached , they had fewer quotes to choose from and the average price of the cheapest five nearly doubled, compared with customers aged .The average of the cheapest five quotes offered to a -year-old was pound and for a -year-old this nearly doubled to pound.Posing as a -year-old travel insurance customer, Which  got  quotes, falling to just seven for an -year-old.One Which  member said declaring his wersquos irregular heartbeat resulted in ldquoeither a refusal to insure or astronomical premiums for the couplersquos annual worldwide cover ndash with one insurer quoting as much as pound,.Older, more experienced drivers are often rewarded with cheaper car insurance, butthis tends to creep up again after drivers pass their mid-s, Which  said.One Which  member, aged , was surprised to be offered quotes ranging from pound to pound, for car insurance.They said: ldquoI still run, jump in rivers and chase salmon, and run stables and horses. Itrsquos annoying to discover that at this age yoursquore deemed incapable of even driving.Which  said many specialist insurers and brokers, and even some mainstream providers, may be able to help customers struggling to find affordable deals on comparison websites..removeAnother port of call is the British Insurance Brokersrsquo Association , which helps people find specialist brokers through the ldquofind insurance service on its website.Jenny Ross, Which  Money editor, said: ldquoIf you struggle to get insurance because of medical conditions or your age, there are some resources that can help you locate specialist insurers that lie off the beaten track of comparison websites.ldquoIf therersquos relevant context to your history or circumstances that you canrsquot communicate on an online form ndash or yoursquore unsure how to accurately fill one out ndash contact the insurer directly by phone or email to speak with a human being.Sarah Brodie, senior policy adviser, general insurance at the Association of British Insurers , said: ldquoTravel insurers aim to offer competitively priced travel insurance to as many travellers as possible.ldquoThe cost of travel insurance will reflect a number of factors, including your age and travel destination.ldquoThe older you are, oryou have a pre-existing medical condition, the more likely you are to need to claim for what can be jaw-droppingly expensive overseas emergency medical treatment costs.ldquoTravel insurance remains competitively priced, so it can pay to shop around, always making sure that you buy the policy most suited to your needs, not simply on price, and that you answer all questions, especially on any pre-existing medical conditions, fully and honestly..push,i[r].l*new title: tesco announce important change affecting every uk store
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBritainrsquos biggest grocer, alongside Faerch, has developed a closed loop recycling solution to make the way food is packaged is more sustainable.The move will mean the secondary plastic packaging used to transport and hold products on Tesco shelves is retained by the food packaging industry and recycled back into new food contact primary packaging.Until recently, PET shelf ready packaging ndash widely used by UK supermarkets to transport products - was used once and downcycled into non-food applications.Tescorsquos lsquotray to trayrsquo initiativersquoAs part of Tescorsquos lsquotray to trayrsquo initiative all own brand cut fruit, selected yoghurts and meat will be guaranteed to contain % rPET that originated in Tesco stores.To achieve this, Tesco will require all its own brand and branded suppliers to use food contact approved PET for shelf ready packaging.The move will see  tonnes of plastic recycled into new food-grade packaging each year.Tesco issue statement on important change to packagingWilliam Guest, Sustainable Packaging Manager at Tesco said:ldquoWherever we can, we remove or reduce packaging but where it is needed we want to improve circularity to make our packaging as sustainable as possible.ldquoOne way we can do that is by ensuring packaging that meets food contact requirements remains within the food packaging sector, being recycled back into food contact packaging.He added: ldquoThis collaboration with Faerch will ensure that each year , tonnes of PET is recycled to make new Tesco packaging that otherwise would have been downcycled into non-food applications. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - title: top tips for safe student accommodation
story: With freshers week around the corner and thousands of young people in Northern Ireland set to start University or new career paths, many will be on the hunt for rented accommodation. Northern Ireland has experienced a .% increase in average rental values this year[]. With the price increase, OFTEC, representing the liquid fuel industry in Ireland, is concerned that students may take cheaper accommodation options without properly inspecting the property. With this in mind, OFTEC has issued advise to help students ensure their accommodation is safe before they sign the dotted line. Raise the alarm – Currently, it is not a mandatory requirement for private landlords to provide smoke and carbon monoxide detectors, but the HSENI recommend that they do. It is a legal requirement to fit a carbon monoxide detector when a fossil fuel appliance has been replaced. Carbon monoxide is potentially lethal as it has no smell, taste or colour. Without a working alarm, it is impossible to identy carbon monoxide leaks. OFTEC’s advise is to ensure that there are working fire and CO alarms in the property, and that they are tested on a regular basis.Heating requirements - The Health  Safety Executive recommend that all boilers should be serviced annually and tenants should ask for evidence of recent servicing. If you have concerns, ask for a CD  Landlord Oil Installation Check which is carried out by an OFTEC registered technician and will give you peace of mind. For a gas heated property, ask for a copy of the annual gas safety check.Look for damp – It is easy to hide damp patches with a coat of paint, soyour house smells musty or you see evidence of mould, find out how the landlord is planning to fix the problem. Mould has no place in the home as it can cause respiratory problems and headaches.Furniture and fittings – Ask the landlord for a list of everything that is included and make note of any damage that is there before you move it. Check any beds, sofas and chairs are in good condition.Secure your home – burglars may target student areas because of lax security. Ask your landlord to fit key operating locks on the windows and lever deadlocks on external doors.  OFTEC Ireland Manager, David Blevings, said: “Quite often the excitement of moving in with friends can overshadow the concerns about the accommodation itself. We are urging students to play it safe this year and carry out these essential checks before signing a lease and moving in. “Asking a landlord about safety may seem awkward, but it could prevent you from living in a potentially dangerous property for the next  months. It’s vital that your new home is not a burden as you start your time at university.
